Praefatio.	Praefatio.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	Introduction.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Preamble.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Since there is a lack of good masters of this art in our time, it is because medicine is a long field of study, and the author needs to practice dissection before his art with his own hands on the anatomy taught by Galen, until he knows the movements of the members, and their forms, and their connections, and their separations, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, and veins, and their numbers, and their exit, and their palpitations, and quietus, and places of origin.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said, 'A name by itself is much, and a work by itself is little, especially in the art of the hand.'
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	However, we have already spoken about it at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since he who does not know what we have said about anatomy will certainly fall into error, leading to the destruction of humans: as I saw many of them forming a science from it, and boasting about it without knowledge or experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That is, because I saw a dull doctor cut the apostema scrofulous wound on the woman's neck, and hit some blood vessels in her throat: why did the woman's blood flow until she died between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who assumed that he would remove a large stone from a man who had been walking for a long time, and the stone was big.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So he approached him and removed the vein with a wisp of hair.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Why did the man die on the third day?
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I too had been called to extract it; and I saw from a great stone, and from the arrangement of the nurses, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician, who was taking a fee from our King for medicine: and it happened that a black eunuch, who was with him, broke his thigh near the heel; and the doctor persued with his ignorance, and bound the fracture together with thin splints and strong bindings, and did not stop the course of the wound's inflammation.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he let him go according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then after a few days he sent him away and commanded him not to loosen the bindings; and so he remained until his leg and foot had healed properly, but then he came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	So I was called to loosen the bindings; and what followed was peace, and he was freed from his pain.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But the corruption had already taken hold in the limb; and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Then the corruption ceased to spread in the limb until he died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who opened a cancerous boil; and it became ulcery after a few days, until the malignancy spread to his lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is, for when it is cancerous from the melancholic humor, then one should not approach it with iron at all unless it is present in a member that can bear it, so that it may be cut off entirely.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for that reason, O sons, you must know that the art of surgery is divided into two parts: that which is associated with health, and that which is associated with danger in many arrangements.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I too have already set forth in every part of this book wherever surgery has come up, where there is terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Why do you need to tell him that, and to decrease it? So that the dumb fool doesn't offend me with his words and dishonors me.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, receive with care and protection, and bring our sick with ease and strength, and use a better path, led by the grace of God to salvation and worthy succession: and remove from us that which makes us fear, so that it may enter upon us hesitation in our faith and our comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it remains more to remain in our glory, and higher in the world, and at last to the quantities of us.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Because Galen has already said in some of his adages.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not cure disease with medicine: do not name a doctor to disease.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	But I have already divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter on cauterization with fire and medication, on acute medication, on medicine that is hot or cold, on the shape of instruments and tools for cauterization, and on everything else needed in the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On cutting and piercing, phlebotomy and wound-cleaning, and extracts of arrows, and similar things: and the whole chapter on the shape of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, dislocation, and cure for torsion, and similar things: the whole chapter, ordered from head to foot, and with the shapes of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery of Al-Bhaks
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On cauterization and non-cauterization: with which colors the surgeon should be dressed, and at what time; and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I remember the operation with him, it is necessary that I should tell you the quality of his cauterization and non-cauterization: and in which complexion he shows it.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I therefore say that the speech on the quality of cauterization and its harm is long, subtle, scientific, and secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Also spoken was a great number of wise men, and they disagreed with each other; but for me, little of their words is sufficient, fearing the lengthiness of their speech.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I therefore say that cauterization is universal to all complexions, whether with or without substance; excepting two complexions, which are a hot, substance-less complexity and a dry, substance-less complexity.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In complexity, however, hot and dry with substance, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some, indeed, have said that cauterization is useful in that.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of that, namely that cauterization is not suitable for an illness which is hot and dry: for fire's nature is hot; and it is unsuitable, as it heals a hot and dry illness with hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite of that said: That by cauterization healing is done in any hot and dry illness which occurs in human bodies; for when you compare a human body, and its moisture, to the complexity of fire, the body's coldness disappears.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself say by that speech: for by experiment I have discovered that at times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not necessary that you make that point, except those who have already been tested and exercised in the last exercise of the chapter on cauterization, and have recognized the diversity of human complexions, and the nature of illnesses within them, and their causes, and their accidents, and the time period of their existence.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	From the other complexities there is no fear for you; and especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all doctors have already agreed upon them; and they did not disagree on cauterization in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know ye sons, that the secret of cure by cauterization with fire, and the goodness thereof, is when the medicine is burned with the fire upon the cautery: for fire is simple, whose action does not reach, unless to the member which is cauterized; and does not hurt the other member joined therewith, unless with a little injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of medicine when it is burned and increased by fire reaches that which extends from the members: and perhaps makes it happen to a member that it has difficulty in being cured, and perhaps destroys it.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire because of its subtlety and goodness of its substance does not do that, unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now this has already become known to us by trial, because of the length of practice and study with art and standing on the veracity of things: and because of this excuse from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not, because it is not allowed to this my book, I would give you the secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its action on the bodies by means of its expulsion: which expels diseases with a philosophical demonstration-phrase, which was added by the minds of your ancestors.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know ye sons, that yourselves differ in the time when it is to be made to happen cautery, and put a better time of medicine:
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cautery is suitable at all times: for the injury which happens because of time is hidden in a good will, which is attracted with the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cautery is for pains from necessary pains, firming, banquets which do not tolerate delay: for they are afraid of them, that a bad will happen which is greater than a little injury is to blame for the lack of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not fall into the minds of your sons that they should not judge, except for common and stupid doctors, namely that he who is cured of a disease by cautery does not always recover: and they put its consequence, and it is not like what they think: for cautery is not, unless in place of medicine, which changes the complexion, and dries up humidities which are the causes, wherefore pains happen.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Indeed, the cautery is superfluous on top of the medicine due to its velocity, vigor, and power, and because it belongs to the Lord: and it is possible that the sickness be restored at some time during the course of nursing, and location of sickness, and strength; and that it is prepared in his body from an excess that has accumulated in him: and that it comes to him in its acquisition from food, and similar things from causes, unless there is sickness, in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Indeed, a slight sickness in a small member is superfluous due to excess dryness and humidity, like the pain of a tooth, for its own pleasure, and other similar things; because it is possible that this pain does not return to him.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that is true only in a few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the word of the cure is again true; that the cautery is last of all medicine, it is a straight word: not to that which they intend in him; for they believe that there is no healing with medication, nor with anything else after the occasion of the cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the case is just the opposite, and the intention, that the cautery is last of all medicine, is not true; unless when we administer methods of cure in some diseases, and do not give them medicine: then we administer at the end of the matter a cautery, and it comes to pass. Then it falls, that the cautery is last of all medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many medical doctors understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancient ones have said that a gold cautery is better than an iron one: and they did not say that, except for the equality of gold, and the limitation of its substance; and they have said that it does not make a wound in the cauterizing place.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is not absolutely so; for I have tested that, and found that it does not make those wounds in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	It is good to use the cautery with it, and better than using iron, as they say.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	Indeed, when you use the fire cautery on gold, it does not show you, when lit according to the quantity you use, due to the redness of the gold: and when it is proper for it to be cold, and if you add ignition on top of it, it melts in the fire and turns into leaves.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the craftsman fall from that [practice]: and for that reason we prefer the cautery with iron among us, and more quickly and closer to the work, from truth to operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have already arranged this chapter on the cautery, according to the chapters: and I have arranged it from the head until the feet: so that you may find what you want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	About the way of cauterizing the top of the nose.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Confirm here the cauterization to the domain of humidity and coldness on the brain: which are two causes of salt, and a multitude of flow of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and a multitude of sleep, and pain of teeth, and pain of throat: and generally all sickness that happens from coldness, such as paralysis, and salting, and epilepsies, and apoplexies, and similar things from those illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The way of cauterization is, so that you prescribe to the sick: that it be drained in the first place with a solute and purifying medicine, washing the head three nights, or four, according to what the power of the sickness, and its age, and custom, demand.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then prescribe to him that he should wash his head with a soft cloth.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	So whenever your middle finger has come up to that point with uneasiness, mark that spot with an unclean mark.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then fire cautery: this is its shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then put the flesh on the marked spot with your fingers, and squeeze it gently, and then remove it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly wipe your hand, and examine the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see now a little quantity of salt on the bone, or a little quantity of licorice, then quickly wipe your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the motion with the iron, or with another one when it is chilled: until you see the bones, which I told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and immerse the cloth in it, and put it on the spot: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put on the spot the cloth immersed in butter, and leave it until the fire is completely extinguished.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of that with the four-fold ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that since the wound remains open for so long, pus is emitted: why is it better and more helpful?
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said, to cauterize the skin all the way down to the bone: and hold the cautery until a certain hardness is achieved.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then clean after that what has been burned, then cauterize it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary to do with the cautery what I have just described, so that an impression of a knot is made on the bone: or the instrument which women put in their hair with a little letter: and they cut off, that vapours of the head's essence may be emitted from this place, and the wound may heal after a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then cauterize it until it hardens.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But these two species of cautery do not seem to exist among all men, except for certain people from second-hand knowledge out of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And leave it: as far as I am concerned, it is better with the health of that person.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the resolution of its natural continuity; as we have testified in the other members; and above all when the head is weak, by nature: and the species of cautery is more sound and better with me, and I use it; so let us operate on it while it is healthy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	For the mode of cauterizing the head when it has pain throughout the whole head.
Caput III.	Chapter III: On the Mode of Causing a Head W
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head there is a chronic pain; and when it is prolonged in an invalid, and if he uses hypos, hot baths, head rinsings, oils, and applications: then operate.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if already cauterized with one kind of cautery which we have described, and gives it no benefit: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head is weak by nature's creation, and is not weak, and cold is keen: then cauterize with another kind of cautery a little below it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize itself on all the horns of its head with its own cautery, and do not let the skin be burned, and uncover a quantity from the bone, which we have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize itself with one kind of cautery at the back of its head, in the place which is called the vein; and this is a place where there is a flowing wind: and moisten your palm well in this, and do not uncover the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For an invalid will have keen pain because of this, and is far removed from the pain of the other parts of the head's cauterization.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this cautery in its place; and it should be that by which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of the head by a finer cautery, by which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the mode of cauterizing when it has a headache, just as if it were a medicine adjusted, as if with an iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV: On Causing a Head to Bleed When it has
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occurs in part of the head, or when the pain extends to the eye, and if the head is washed with medicinal solutions, and the remaining treatment is given, as I have described in the divisions of diseases, and this does not benefit him entirely: then cauterization must be done in two ways: either cauterization with a sharp medicine that burns; or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But if cauterization is to be done with a sharp medicine that burns, i.e., take one of the teeth of another, and cut it out, and cut off its ends from the two sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of pain at the time with a phlebotome on the side, until it is made into a place under the skin, in which a lump is captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then introduce it into him under the skin, until it is hidden: then tie it over it with a knot of constrictive yarn, and leave it for fifteen hours, and then dissolve it, and pull out one, and leave it for two days, or three: then put a cloth over the spot immersed in butter, until a pus place forms: then care for the wound with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you want to make it with some sharp medicines that burn, which I have written about in the second book, On Burning Medications.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	But cauterization with iron is according to this method.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Fire Cauterization, whose form is this:
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a Clavicle: because the form of the head is like the form of a clavicle, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it is a small eminence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place the iron on the spot, and hold your hand: and you will turn the iron gradually with speed: and let the amount that burns be of the thickness of the skin, such as half of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand so that the artery below does not burn, and an outflow of blood does not occur.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then dip the wound in saline water and put it on the place and leave it for three days; then put the wound with butter: later care with ointment until healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you see, cauterize this headache with an edge of scalpel second cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And do not cut the artery in this half-headache, but old one his own.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	The mode of cauterizing in an old headache.
Caput V.	Head
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat a headache, with what we have said before in the preceding cure, and that which we have said in the divisions of diseases, and there is no cure: and you see from the disease that it does not suffice to him what we have said from the first cauterization with medicine, or with cauterization with fire, then it must be that you bring the fires of Cauterie, until it becomes white after the signs on the place of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or almost like it: and put your hand out one way, and squeeze it until you touch the artery, and reach as far as the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you, so that you cauterize the continuation of the jaw, which moves when chewing, does not burn on the side, or nerve that moves it, from which happens a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be on guard, and beware of the flow of blood of the artery, which is cut off.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is a fear in the cutting off of it, and especially to him who does not know what he does, and is not learned, nor expert: and dismisses the operation with it at first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with a reminder of the regime of the flow of blood from an artery according to its own way, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	That if you see from the disease that this cauterization is not sufficient for him, and you see the body bearing the cauterization in the middle of the head, as we have told, care about the sore, until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you see, administer cautery, which we have said in the chapter on arteriotomy with a cautery having two scalpels.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For cauterization is better and more effective in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	§ On the method of cauterizing in ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens that there is pain in the ear from cold, and cauterize with water, and the rest of the cure as we have said in the division, and the pain does not disappear, then fire Cautery: and that is what is called a point, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the points with it after its ignition around the whole ear, as it swells: or in the circumference of each, if at the same time pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And stretch it with the cautery from the root of the ear slightly, after you have marked the places with wax: and let the quantity of cauterium be ten points all over the ear, and almost the same.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then care for the place, until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	§ On the method of cauterizing in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.In cumque cauterium ignis fac
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	For the torture which is cured with cauterization, is not except for the kinds that happen from phlegm, according to what we have said in divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And prolonged cauterization of a species that happens from drying up, and the spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this species of torture with hyoscyamus, and caputpurums, and gargarisms, and your cure does not bring about a result, then you should cauterize the sick three times: one near the root of the ear, and a second slightly below its place, and a third at the meeting of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And put your cautery on the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not happen except in the part that appears to be healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterizing is so that it cauterizes itself with the cautery in the direct extremity of the upper ear near the hairline slightly: and another in the time: whose length is according to the length of the finger.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And lay your hand with the cautery, until the amount of half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery; and it has a kind of blade whose form is as follows: indeed, it is not too fine, as you see; and it is necessary that the blade should be somewhat thin, because of its thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with this; until such time as it heals: unless you want to suffer a great deal of pain and loss.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	(On the way of cauterizing in ancient apoplexia.)
Caput VIII.	CHAPTER VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexia is old, and you take care of it with that which I have said, and your medicine does not avail, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every corner of his head, and with one in the middle of his head, as we have said, and with one at the back of his head, according to what preceded: and let the mode of the cautery be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Also cauterize with the cautery on the mouth of the stomach: and it is more the last.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then take care of it with that which preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	(On the way of cauterizing in obliteration.)
Caput IX.	CHAPTER IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that they be given to the first patient with great fever, and pills that clean the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then cut off his head entirely, and put on his scalp an ointment described in the book of ointments: and apply it sometimes.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the way to make a poultice: and do it according to the order which I have mentioned there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If then he recovers by means of it, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then do to him three cauterizations in the posterior part of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and put between every cauterization a thickness of finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then take care of the poultice, with what preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you want to add something, and the sick man endures that: then do to him a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	That if you want to add something: then cauterize him over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then take care of the head until it is healed: and let the poultice be oiled according to the form which I have mentioned above.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	As to the way of cauterizing in paralysis and softening.
Caput X.	Head
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed in cleaning out the head with fever, and with what I have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then cut off the head and nurse it: then cauterize him in the middle of the head, and on all the horns of the head, and on the posterior part of it, and three on the spine of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however you are not able to endure the softening of the body in many places, and the sick person endures that and the illness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauterizations on the spine of the back, and the last one while it is burning up from his skin, and wash your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then take care of the head until it is healed: and let the poultice be oiled in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	As to the way of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	He should not cauterize an epileptic patient unless he is certain that the epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, to begin with, he should wash out his brain with water and with the other remedies which we have mentioned in the section on general treatment; for a sick man is great or tolerant of medicine.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if he is a boy who does not tolerate medicines, then let him be given gargles and mouthwashes to wash out the brain; before many days of good diet.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then rinse his head, and afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of his head, and according to what has been said before in the method; and another cautery on his occiput, and over all the ridges of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the sick man is strong and tolerant, then cauterize him with the medicines which I have mentioned for paralysis and softening of the body on the neck and back; and let there be olive oil as a second method of cautery.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the sick man is a boy, then place the fine cautery, according to this method:
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	The way of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupt moisture and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the medicines which we have mentioned for paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of vapor going into melancholy, and his body is wet with moisture; then give him in a vessel which washes out his brain, according to what has been said in the division: and afterwards rinse his head, and then make a loop made loosely of linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of his head: and let the sick man sit holding himself upright.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more honorable from old butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	Let him heat him on a moderate fire; and let him put his hand into him when he bears the heat, as he enters into him.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then he cleared him out in the middle of his head in a circle, and let him go until he became cold.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Then let him have this treatment once a week with the rest of the regimen, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you want to put a ring around him, a small circle of fire, except that you hold your hand with the cauldron: and let it emit odour.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This kind of fire moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place a cloth soaked in butter, or chicken fat, on him.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	The way of treating with fire going down to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13:
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you see the beginning of the water in the eye, which I mentioned in the division, then begin to drink and make the sick person drink, so that he may refresh his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him away from all moisture, and let him sit in a bath, on a few days' fast.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to wash his head, and let him treat himself with fire in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then let him treat himself with fire on either side of the head with two torches, if the beginning is the descent of water into both eyes at once: or from one side, if the beginning is the entrance of water into one eye: and cut off with the torch all the veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let there be torches long in length. And let him guard against the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything of this, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting off, and their carefulness against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And whenever he is treated with fire in wax, under two bones, with two torches at the end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	The way of treating with fire in ancient tears:
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 18:
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient and constant, and they are on the veins, and the arteries that are in the front of the head, it is certain that it is from cold and phlegm: then let him treat himself with fire by means of the same torch that I mentioned at the beginning of the entrance of water, a fire in the middle of the head, and two torches on either side of the head, and two torches in wax under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if it does not heal with addition, then cauterize him in all sides carefully the eye, on the extremity of the superciliary arch with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	De mode cauterizandi in foetore nasi: cum vir entero esset, prope nasum ad pedem ad sinum, sub maxilla,
Caput XV.	The method of cauterizing the nose fetid. When
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it, as we have said in the division, and the remedy does not take place: then approach, and give three nights of infirmary to him: then shave his head, and cauterize him with a medium cauldron, with an olive cauldron.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize him with two caulters, on the two supercilias under the hair a little.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of cauterization with claws.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	De mode cauterizandi in mollificatione palpebrae: cum vir entero esset, prope nasum ad pedem ad sinum, sub maxilla, cum caut
Caput XVI.	The method of cauterizing the eyelids for softening: when
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened by sickness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with a lunar cauldron, with this cauldron of the moon.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if the eye is (to be) opened, then cauterize him above the two supercilias with two caulters on all parts: and they are extended by the two times: and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the supercilium: and do not remove your hand from the cautery, but according to the quantity that is burned the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	This is the form of cauterization according to this method of lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	De mode cauterizandi palpebra cum pilis invisserunt pungentes oculum: tunc prope nasum ad pedem ad sinum, sub maxilla, cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno cum hoc cauterio lunari
Caput XVII.	The method of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs are
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	is fire: or is with medicine-burning.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cauterium but with fire: however, before that, recommend that he stops his hairs from coming off, if he is of those who wash them, until they grow out and become even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If I puncture him near his eye: then constrict his eyes with putty, so that they do not move until they have healed.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have healed and been brought to a steady state, then place the head of the patient in your lap: afterwards mark the eyelids of his eyes with caustice, a mark that is shaped like a leaf of myrrh: and let the mark begin from near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a damp cloth soaked in albumen, or in a slippery substance made from the mucilage of psyllum, on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply fire to the mark, its shape being this:
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the mark, slowly and repeatedly, until the surface of the skin is completely burnt away, leaving a shape that resembles the leaf of myrrh, all by itself.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the mark of your work is this: so that if you press the eyelids of his eyes together, and feel the hair near the mark of the wound, you will know that the patient's eye has been healed.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So then let go of your hand, and send him away for a few days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place on the patient's skin a cloth soaked in butter, until the scar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then tend to the patient with ointment, until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any of his hair falls out an hour later and the eyelid becomes soft, then apply fire to the same place as before, as you did in the beginning.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If, however, the hair has fallen out at the lower eyelid, then cauterize that place until it has returned to its natural position: and make sure that the eyes do not tickle after.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	The way of cauterizing with burning medicine at the same time.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is as you command for the sick person: let him forgo shaving his hair, until it has grown and settled down.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make in the shape of a leaf of myrrh out of a piece of cloth or a patch of linen.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take out of a known soap, and from a clay that is not soaked in any weight or almost like it: then rub it together with good rubbing, and make it with speed, so that it does not grow cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then from that take a piece, and put it on the paper that you made like the form of an oak leaf, and place [it] on the eyelid of one eye or two eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And put under the eye a cotton wodge soaked in albumin or: and let the head of the patient lie in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And put your finger like an index on the medicine, and press it a little.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move [it] whenever the sick person feels a tingling sensation from the medicine: for its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While he was persisting in doing so because he found the bite of the medicine, then let go of the medicine, and move  [it] yourself with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	While he was calming down from the bite, then let go of the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider, if you see the eyelid close up, like it closes during burning or incising, is good: and if not, then repeat again on top of that place from the medicine where it does not impress the medicine, and does not harm, until your operation is completed, and the eye closes.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then put on the eye a cotton wodge with butter, until the skin of the burn is peeled off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the eye with a diaphenicon ointment, or any other, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you near the operation, to guard the last guards, so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	That if the eyelid softens after a few days, and fights with some hair in the eye, then repeat again on that place the medicine where it softens from the eyelid of itself, like you did in the beginning.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the eye, until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of an oak leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that human eyes differ from each other in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	So therefore according to this consideration be your thought: and do not conceal the straightness of its direction, which is the study of this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	To cauterize a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, as we have said in the division of diseases, and your treatment does not help: then you should cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Order the sick person to put his head in your lap, and hold his head between your hands so that he does not move or shake it.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put the cotton wisp soaked in alumen, or in mucilage of psillium, on his eye; then hold it over the fire, which should be shaped like this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Sit facing the fire, as the shape of a flute's feather extends from one end, so that it is heated on one side; and if the wisp sits so as to penetrate all the way to the other end, and if the wisp sits so as to be held up towards the sky.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this kind of fire is better suited to your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula if it is open, and remove anything from it, and dry it out; and if it is not open, then open it and remove any pus from it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put the fire on it, which should burn fiercely.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold it with your hand somewhat near the fire, towards the nose, so that your hand does not move or shake the sick person; and place the fire on the eye fat, and dissolve it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If then you see any pus at the beginning of your fire up to the mouth, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the fire once or twice, if you can bear it; and discharge him after three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then put the cotton wisp with butter on, and take care of the patient with drying ointment until he is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	That if he does not heal after fourty days, then put on him an acute corrosive medicine until the mouth is detected; and cut it according to what it says in his own chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	There is another mode of cautery, which some said first.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 intend to the place of the fistula, and find it: then put into it a narrow needle, that is, a fine cannula, whose form this is.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of liquid lead, and hold your hand with the cannula in good hold, so that it does not move at all, so that it does not run, or come to the eye of him.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And you should put on a patch over his eye that is made with an infusion in albumin or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Because lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a wonderful cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	That if the fistula is healed, as well as what we said from cautery, and cure, is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a nostrum hole, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what comes into his own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the mode of cauterizing in the fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	Head XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Often occur in the lip fissures, which are called hairs, and especially on the lips of boys.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you care for these fissures, as well as what we said regarding the distribution of diseases, and there is no cure, then a small paring iron from fire, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let it be sharp according to the subtility of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the lit iron quickly into the cracks of the fissures, until the fire reaches the bottom of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with a patch, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the mode of cauterizing in the fistula of the mouth.
Caput XXI.	Head 21.Si enim Oris est inf
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	If it is that an apostema occurs in the root of the gums, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus is made, and breaks out: afterwards, it is healed over, and pus runs, and a fistula forms: then care for it, and there is no cure in it, then you should put fire cauterium according to the quantity, which he takes into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce the litmus into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the litmus reaches its bottom, and its tip: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for the patient after that, as we have said regarding the cure until he is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore is chopped off pus, and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to detect the place, and remove the corrupted bone according to what comes into its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	Regarding the way of cauterizing in gingival and molified teeth.
Caput XXII.	Head 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are softened by moisture, and the teeth move, and do not respond to treatment, then put the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then the fire-tip, of whose shape you have made after these things, so that you put it on a tooth: and introduce the ignited fire quickly into it; and hold your hand slightly, until the sick one feels the heat of the fire already reaching its root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And wipe your hand: then repeat the fire a few times, according to what you want.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then fill the patient's mouth with salt water, and keep it for an hour: and spits it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth will become steady in its place, and the corrupted moisture will be tightened and dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Regarding the way of cauterizing in toothache.
Caput XXIII.	Head 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is due to coldness, or there is coldness in it, or skin, and does not respond to treatment with medicines: then the fire within it is second according to two ways: either with butter; or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the fire of it is as follows: to take butter that is yellow, and heat it up, and hold it on the tooth in an iron fork, or in a vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a piece of cloth and wrap it around the end of the tentacle.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip the end of the tentacle in butter that has been heated: and place the end on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it begins to freeze: then repeat this several times until the fire's power reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you can't hold it, dip the cloth or the bandage in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth: and place a hot iron on top of it, until the fire reaches deep into the hollow of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But cauterization with fire is so that you can see towards the hole in the air, or a iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And sit in his body some grease, so that the fire' sharp point does not reach the sick mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then hold the cautery, its shape depending on the case: and place it on the tooth: and hold your hand so that the cauterization begins to freeze.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be relieved, or do it on the same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary that the cauterization impression be filled so that the sick mouth is filled with good balm, and holds it for an hour: then let it open widely.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whichever end you will, as well as it can be: and this is the form of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	The way to cauterize in staphylas.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the staphylas are from phlegm, and from cold humors, and are not submissive to digestion through medicines, and want to digest them quickly: then take a careful fire, whose shape is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	It has two open ends so that the smoke can come out through the other end of the cautery: and place the fire on the apostema once, and a second time if you tolerate it, until it reaches deep into the apostema.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the wound is small: then place the cautery according to the quantity of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let him lie for three days, and put over him a cloth dampened with vinegar until he is healed from the burn.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for the wound with a dental ointment until it has healed in shape of a tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	The way of cauterizing in a raucous voice and constriction of a breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When there is an excess of moisture above the tube of the lung, and especially when it is accompanied by a cold complexion, then it is necessary that the sick person be discharged at once with soluable medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize the throat with a mild caustic at the root of the tonsils in a depressed place; and be careful, so that you do not apply the caustic to the throat or skin, unless there is something on it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize the throat with another caustic at the joint of the neck in the last part of the spine of the last; and let the caustic be a nail according to the manner which has preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for the person with what has preceded, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	The way of cauterizing in respiratory ailments of the lung and throat.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the cough and illness of the lung are due to cold humidities, and the sick person does not have a fever or consumption, and the illness is old: then cauterize the throat with two caustics above the jawbone in depressed places, gently and mildly.
