Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another caustic in the middle of the breast between two nipples; and let the caustic be a tube according to the shape which has preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if your cauterization is by piercing with a cautery which is called a 'Punctum', whose shape has preceded in the piercing of pain in the ears: and let there be points of twenty points up to almost another.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for the person with what has preceded, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And it has also three branches for sitting cautery: in this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why should you be comforted by the cauterization with him, when you make a one-three cauterization with him.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	De the mode of cauterizing in the titillum, in the dislocation of the humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the adductor is causing humidity and is not returning to its place at the time of dislocation, until it has become accustomed to its return, then dislocate it by a slight movement; for this we have already testified that it should be reduced;
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then let the sick person lie on his back or on his healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then rub with oil, which is within the titillum on the upper part with your left-hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated inwardly.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take the cautery with two wires.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize with oil, until it penetrates to another side, and the shape of the cauterization is made with four cauterizations.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when the cauterization is made with a cautery having three wires, why does the shape of the cauterization then become six smaller ones? And the wires are according to the subtlety of the touch.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the cauterization having three wires.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added to this mode, why are there eight cauterizations?
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place on the cautery crushed peppercorns with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make so that it adheres to the tranquility of the sick, so that no member moves at any time, until it is comforted.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upward and rarely does so, then cauterize it on the shoulder with a clauvus cautery, or with many punctures.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint becomes secure, and removes humidity: and the sick person is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	To cauterize the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and moisture accumulate in the stomach, until they are removed from his own skin, and there are many discharge to it, and persist in treatment methods, and do not work: then it should lie down on his back, and spread out his legs, and stretch his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with six cauterization, cauterization under the cochlea in the quantity of one finger with cauterization of the nail, and two cauterization below from the two sides a cautery of one, until the figure of the cauterization is triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each other so that they do not join together, when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And be the depth of cauterization quantity of two thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And be the figure of the cauterization as such without addition: and if you want to cauterize with a large cauterization in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and be the cauterization that is made this way one according to the shape of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And be cauterized the stomach by piercing it who shudders at this cauterization: and it is as the signs on the stomach point according to quantity that you do with caustics: then cauterize the pierce it: then care for the stomach with treatment, which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	To cauterize the cold stomach.
Caput XXIX.	De modo cauterizandi Epatorum.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it is painful in the back due to cold and moisture, or due to rough winds, until it comes out of his own skin natural exit of waste, and care for the sick with what we have said, and does not benefit in it: then let the sick person lie on his back on his scalp, and place three cauterization according to this form, and the same quantity above the spine, where the bed of a man is located: and be the space that is between each other according to the thickness of the finger: and be the cauterization according to the length of the body straight: and do not squeeze your hand with a large cauterization.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let there be an amount that is heated by the thickness of the skin, and a half of it not added: and let the sick stand on his own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if he is not standing, then he should lie down, for he has already extended his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And you too can do this cauterization with a knife, when there is subtlety and wisdom with you in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself so that you do not proceed last in the cauterization, and let the thickness of the skin be heated throughout, since the thickness of the skin is there, know that one.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	[On the mode of cauterizing the liver.]
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30:
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an ulcer is seen to be coming out, and you need to know if it is in the liver or in its membrane: then if it is in the liver, you will see a dull pain, and there is a mild acuteness: and you will see that the treatment of the doctors for it tires them out.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It should be so that the sick person lies down on his own bed.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then figure out the position of the ulcer with a mirror: then light the cauterizing fire so that it is heated by radiation.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize it with one cauterizing fire until the skin throughout is burned, and reaches the siphum, until the pus comes out entirely: then take care of the cure for the healing of ulcers, until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not appropriate that this cauterization be done with the appearance of someone who has been studying medicine for a long time: and because, at times, some diseases come to those who carry out such an operation: in fact, let one dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But I think it is better to leave it alone.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	To cauterize in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that the cauterization with the roots of aristochoea is applied to cold pleurisy in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is as follows: you shall receive from the dry roots of aristochoea a long root, which is found in it, and make it as large as the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil: and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with a long cautery in that which is between the rib and the collarbone, and two small cauteries under the guide a little inclined on either side, which are under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs inclined towards the back a little: and a long cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from the back: one in that which is between two spatulas; and two cauteries from the sides of the chest, the lower cautery being in that which is between two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not necessary that you should squeeze your hand with the cautery, but let it be held out in front of your skin smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient men said that they who use a cautery of iron similar to a radium: and light it up, and put it in that which is between the ribs until it reaches the pus, and the pus comes out: as we have said in the pustule of the liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this piercing with the cautery there is a fear, that either the sick man dies immediately, or a fistula happens to the place which does not heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are curing a disease of the spleen, with that which we have said about dividing the diseases, and your cure does not bring forth its effect, then cauterize it in three ways, all of which are straight.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One is enough to make three wounds or four by tracing along the length of the splenic section according to the figure of the smaller liver, which preceded in form.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And between each wound there should be a quantity of thickness of the finger, or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the distance between the wounds be equal to that which we mentioned in the cauterization of the liver.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not compress your hand when you cauterize; and let him lie on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another mode of cauterization is that which we mentioned in the chapter on shoulder dislocations: and dry up the skin, which lies directly in front of the spleen where it reaches the bed of the left side; and let your hand rise while you dry up the skin according to the width of the body, so that the wounds may reach according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce two hot knives deeply, until you penetrate through with them the skin on the opposite side; then remove the cautery; so there will be four wounds.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a knife having three knives.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care of the cautery after you have removed it, if it should emit pus for many days: for it is more healing than each that has preceded in the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	The mode of cauterization in the Hydropsys.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not fall into the Hydropsis if it is properly raised up.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you cure the Hydropsis with the modes of cure which we mentioned in the division, and there is no cure, then you should cauterize four times around the navel, and once over the stomach, and once over the liver, and once behind each spine, and one in front of the chest, and another in front of the stomach: and let the distance between each cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then remove the cautery so that it opens up, to emit pus after a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not let the patient depart from you after the cauterization, for he should gather up two purposes, and the healing will be quick to him with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	Indeed, the form of the cautery with which the abdomen is cauterized, should be a closure: second because it precedes its form: and its back, with which he is cauterized, should be an olive, because it precedes its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	The mode of cauterizing the feet and the legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV. The Head.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they are put out into the Hydroptic, and are filled with yellow water: you should cauterize on the back of the foot in the noccere, which is between the auricular and the ring finger: and wash your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then wash your hand: and do not touch it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the yellow water will make a mark, and the cautery will be made according to this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauteries on the two legs, and let the cautery be made with the tip of a knife-edge cautery: and let the cautery be made according to the length of the leg, one under the knee, and the other below it, about in the middle of the leg: and let there be two cauteries on the whole loin, and do not let the cautery be closed for a long time: so that it will come out from it some water: then care for him with the rest that we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	The mode of cauterizing in the abdominal solution.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV. The Abdominal Solution.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the stomach is loosened by cold and moisture, until the retaining virtue and digesting power, which are in the stomach and intestines, has weakened: and care for it with the methods of care, and does not heal: and you will see a sick person who tolerates an exuberant virtue, then cauterize him with a great cautery on his stomach, second because it precedes in the cauterization of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four small cauteries around the navel, with a small tip-shaped cautery: and a cautery over the alcatine above the loins, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see moistures that are abundant, and the sickly one bearing it, then cauterize him with cautery over the ribcage, and cautery over the entire ileum: and perhaps you added two small cauteries near the great stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For cure is accomplished by a surgeon whose skill is not in error.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the mode of cauterizing Hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36. On the Mode of Cauterizing Hemorr
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many ancient Hemorrhoids, or one, and they are of gross humors, cold, or corrupt moistures, and so cure them along with what we have said in the division, and there is no cure: then cauterize three cauteries on the lower part of the spine behind a slightly triangular almighty, and a cautery under the navel almost like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cold, and his food is not digested, and you see his face turn pale, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cautery, according to what preceded it: and cauterize on his Epopeus, and with another on his Splenium, with a clavicle cautery: and leave the cautery open for some time: and then cure him, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the mode of cauterizing athel after their division.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37. On the Mode of Cauterizing Athel
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut off the athel, then you light a cautery which is radiated with fire.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the lit athel into the cut athel: and with your hand, until the cautery reaches the opening of the anus, from which runs blood: do this once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many athel, then cauterize each one according to what we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then cure them with the ointment, along with what is appropriate for them, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery over the sacrum, it is more final in its effect.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	To cauterize the fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38 on Head.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not submit to cutting and the operation that we have described in its place, and trembles at it, perhaps he will be healed with cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When then happens to someone a fistula, and it is old, pus runs out of it, and corrupt moisture.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is fitting that you should test it with a subtle touch.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the depth of its quantity by testing.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then light a cautery fire, which is like a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert yourself with the lit cautery into the fistula and measure how much it enters.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeatedly pass the cautery over it until all corrupt bodies are burned up, once, or twice, or three times, depending on the need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself from burning of the nerve, if there is one, or a large vein: or if the fistula opens into the body of the uterus, or the body of the intestine, then guard yourself from all such places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do this unless the fistula is in a fleshy place: and consider that it does not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it is healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place seals itself and no more material is shed from it for a long time: then know that it has been completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if no material is shed from it, then know that it is penetrating, or has an opening into its depth, or almost like it: of which remember the place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	The way to cauterize the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39 on Head.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain from cold or a gross wind afflicts the kidneys and they are aching because of it, then you should cauterize each kidney individually from above, with a cautery on all the kidneys with a nail, whose reminder was this.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterized him himself second by himself almeidatu.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Why are there three lined.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore will be the last in iuuamento.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	§ On the way to cauterize the Vesica.
Caput XL.	Head 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When it happens in Vesica weakness, and softening from cold re and moisture, until he does not retain weak urinarv, then cauterize him himself at the bottom of the supply over Vesica, where begin the hair of the comb, and cautery from the right supply, and another from his left: and sit length of his cauterization later side according to quantity of knuckle pollicis: and cauterize him himself cauterio lower back, or two cauteries if you tolerate that: and sit according to what came before cauterium claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	§ On the way to cauterize the Matrix.
Caput XLI.	Head 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When it happens in Matrix cold and moisture, and it is forbidden by him from impregnation, and his menstrua corrupt, and is delayed their provocation, and happens to him at the aduentum of them a pain, then it should be ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, and cautery on alcatim lower back, or two cauteries: and sit cautery claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	§ On the way to cauterize the Anus in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Head 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When are poured out humidities of the mucous Anus to the faeces, and is a cause of exit from its place: and the sign of it is that he prolongs his crus over another, when they face one to another: and is found the location of dislocation in that vacuus.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it should be that cauterizes the weak on the Anus of himself similar circle: after which you have the signs with the caustice in circumitu pixidis, like a refolded: and let fall itself pixis in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And set the cautery whose form preceded in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	That if you do not have this cautery present, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive oil cautery: and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin of all.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	The mode of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When it happens that there is pain in the sciatic nerve, and there is a cause for this pain, cold and wetness: and the sick person is treated with it as we have said in the division, and there is no cure, and it becomes stale: then it is necessary that you should separate the sick person from gross humors with fetid pills, or with artificial pills, and others.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of the cautery in her is according to two ways: either the cautery with burning medicines, or the cautery with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cautery with fire is according to many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of these is, that you cauterize over the sciatic plexus with three triangular cauteries, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And let them be of good depth, or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there is a space which is according to the thickness of the finger between every cautery; and let there be an olive oil cautery.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When however it happens that the cautery is made in the middle on top of the sciatic plexus itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded in the cauterization of the sciatic dislocation, one: that it is a circle containing all the sciatica.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn up the thickness of the skin of all.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the mode of cauterizing in sciatica, when there is a painful adherence to the sciatic itself, and does not extend until the pelvis and legs.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	But if it extends until the pelvis and legs, then cauterize it with two cauteries on top of the pelvis, on the place where the pain is, and with your cautery on the four fingers slightly towards the outside: and let there be a scalpel-like cautery.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the incision correspond to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient complains that the pain extends up to the toes, then cauterize him at that place with a single, double, triple or multiple punctures, depending on his tolerance.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if the patient complains of pain under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize him there with a single knife cut.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And make sure that with all your cauterizations, you do not end up with the knife burning nerves, or a large artery, and do not cause harm to any bad disease or contraction on it.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have seen one and another who cauterized on top of the thigh, and were finished with the cauterization, and their leg became swollen, until a tumor was formed, and it was perforate all over, and corrupted all over: then there happened a solution of the blood, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is on both sides at the same time, cauterize one side according to this method:
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise people have said about the cauterization of the anchal, whose cauterization is this way:
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar shape out of iron, whose diameter is half the size of the palm, and let it be placed at the opening according to the thickness of the finger nail or less, and let there be another one inside that third.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be a space between each anchal that is the quantity of the thumb nail: and let there be openings on both sides: and make their height almost like a knot, or two knots: and make them handle-like by bending them in the anchae.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be heated in fire until it turns red, and let sparks come off: then place it on a plate of the anchal lying down on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	So cauterize it with three round cuts in one direction.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let him leave the wound to the tribes for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then bind it with butter: and let the open wound stand many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with ointment, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Says Al-Bu-Kaas, with this kind of burn, we use very little because of the fearsome appearance of it: and therefore, because there are few who wait over it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	However, it is from good cauterization that he suffers, and remains with him the place of his wound.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	But the cauterium with doctors who attend him is, so that you make two knots with a loop that comes down with the bar of his door from iron, or from brass, its length to their height: and there are two knots on them, or almost like themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there should be a space that is between the two equal amounts of thickness of the finger, and they are open upper and lower: and there should be one that holds itself in the opposite direction, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it on ash-paste, the sick man lying on the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand hard on the ash-paste.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between the two circles of hot water, which is warmed with fire slightly, and hold it for a quantity of time: and let the sick man feel the tingling of it, and his own burning, for he finds the tingling like fire, until he sleeps from it.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then wash your hand with an instrument, and rinse all the ash completely with sweet water: then let it stand for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put butter on it, until it removes the blackness of burning: and let it stand for a few days, and let the pus run out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For it is the latest in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of that with ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip, or the foot: let him have a standing position in it that holds water, according to what you did in the ash equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method for hot and cold water: I have already written about it in my treatise on rectifying medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take the two medicines, one part alkaline and one part non-extinct calcis; mix them together, and put them into a new jug with a small hole at the bottom of one part only, according to the quantity that is to be added: and put under the bottom of the jug another jug empty: and pour on the water from the sweet well which immerses both of them with the finger: then squeeze them together firmly with your hand; and let the jugs go until the sharp water comes out at the bottom of the jug.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then collect the whole water, and pour it on the other calcis; and drink it up, until it returns again.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	This will then be very strong in acidity, which is administered in many medicinal operations, and in the cauterization of the remaining members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it efficacious in operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from medicines are, with which they cauterize the broad, also as theriacakis, and honey of anacardium, and calcic soap, so that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galenus himself reported, relating of a man of the ancient cure, who was cured of pain in the ankle and sciatic pain: and he praised it very much.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, "He did not like any other cure, and was cured from one foot only, until he reported, that perhaps he entered into a hot bath, and came out already well.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And this is to be taken from the seitaragi man: and if a viride is not found, it is taken just as it is, fresh: and it is massaged much with some fat, and placed on the ankle, where the pain is, or on the hip: and it is bound up, and left for three hours, or for such a quantity that the patient feels the sensation of painful tedium.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore the body becomes hot, introduce it into the heat.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain has subsided, and he is recovering.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you should know that it is not appropriate to use any medicine with these medicines unless after the body has been evacuated.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides, who said that when the dung of goats is applied with fire to a sciatic pain, it will be cured; and it becomes a fire in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	The wool is dried, and imbibes the old oil, and is placed on a deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the fire, and is closer to the fire.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the goat dung as it is, and set it on fire in the fire, until it becomes a coal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place the coal on the wool, and leave it until it goes out.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat this.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	So do not stop doing that, until the sense has become accustomed to the mediation up to the ankle, and the pain has rested.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cautery is called Vaccinium cautery.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	§ On the cauterization of the pain of the back.
Caput XLIIII.	Head 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When pain occurs in the back from various causes, or from injury, or from excessive discharge, and such like, by means of cold and wet material: and cauterization does not take place unless in this one form alone, which is made by applying cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after the discharge of the wounds with pungent pills, and similar ones, that they may be placed on the back where there is pain, three lines according to the length of the spine itself, after having marked them with fire in every line; five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity which comes from the tolerance of the wound's virtue: and let cauterization be made with cautery punctures.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize three cauterizations, or four, with the middle clavus, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	To cauterize in the cauldron of gibbosity.
Caput XLV.	Ch. De modo cauterizandi in incaept
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness often occurs in small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of this illness in children is: that which happens to him a rigor in hunger when they are lifted up, and movement: and an swelling in the last spine of the back and knots of him, which already began to emerge over the other spines.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this, and want to make it, then cauterize him with the cauldron that sits in this form a circle.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And he takes the cautery over all parts of the spine equally: and if you want to cauterize around the spine with the cauldron of a dot two lines, or three: and let be dots nearby side by side.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for the place, until it is healed with him that I said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be careful, do not administer the cauldron to gibbosity, which is done in a spasm of a nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	Ch. On the mode cauterizing in podagra, and pains of joints.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of joints are from cold humidities that are poured out to any member of the body, then when these pains occur in the feet, it is the custom of the doctors to name it podagra by right.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When this podagra of cold cause is cured with modes of curing, and the pains do not move away, then remove the cautery to move them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And is, as cauterizes him after his evacuation in the circumférence of the joint of the feet, caulteries many: and let be the cauldron Olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose this form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you can stand as dots on the face of the foot, then do it with a dot of cauldron.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	That if they ascend pains up to the knees, or other joints, and often this happens: then cauterize him over all knee with four cauldron, or six from every part, with this same cauldron of Olive oil.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If, however, you need more of this remedy, then cauterize him then.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the caustic, but rather sit around it with only the spiciness of the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If, however, the pains rise up to the knees, and the back: then administer what we said above from the caustic in our chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	That if the pains are only in the hands, then poke around with fire, as they return like two lines.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If, however, there remains any pain in the fingers, then poke them, over every lump a point, and over the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If, however, the pains rise up after days to the elbows, or to the shoulders, then cauterize both of them from all parts.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not let the sick person recover from a good regimen, from the reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if the regimen is made good, and the phlegm is excreted, it will be healed by the help of God with this caustic.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the Manner of Causing a Burn to Heale Broken Bones.
Caput XLVII.	Head XLVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a Rupture has occurred in the groin, and has descended into the bowels, or to the testicle, and it is beginning to be near to the scrotum: then you shall order the sick person to cease from food in his own day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use laxatives, so that the dung may descend from his own gut.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and order him that he hold his breath until he has gone forth, or show his buttocks, or his intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then let him reduce the man with your fingers, and mark with the caustic under a Rupture on the top of the pelvis, with the sign whose end is similar to half a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then let the caustic fire be held, with this form, until it has become white, and throw off sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then let the intestine be reduced, or the buttocks to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the attendant place his hand upon the place so that he does not exit the intestines: and you have already opened between the ribs of the sick person, and placed under it the penis, and one servant stands on his ribs, and another on his chest who holds the hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then let him deposit the caustic on the spot, with your hand holding the caustic upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold him, until you are satisfied with him: or else go again with him by another route, if you are not satisfied with him in the first place up to the mouth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe that there is no exit from the intestines at the time of your cauterization, so that he does not burn himself, and let him go through it to the sick or to death, or great mischief.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not achieve the mouth with the caustic, your operation is fruitless.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it should be that the caustic of infants is subtle, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with the rest of the ointment, until he recovers.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the sick person lie on his back for forty days, until the wound is closed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And let him take food by length of time of his cure, which softens his gut: so that he does not exit the intestines through desire and defecation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he should rise after forty days, then give him a looser ligature, and let him hold for forty more days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him abstain from work, and be filled with food and drink, and loud speeches.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regimen, he is healed by a whole cure.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will tell the cure of ruptures with an incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, ruptures occur in the remaining gut, and are incipient, and do not enter, then cauterize his rupture with your round caustic according to its quantity: and let it be what is burned from then on as the third one.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then take care of yourself, as we have said: and do not be led astray.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some have said first: that it should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	Afterwards sign it with encaustic, and place the line which is across from the lateral upper part of the rupture, and another line towards the bottom.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And put your hand in the middle with the cautery closed.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But it is easier and better to use the cautery first.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	The mode of cauterizing in pains by accident, or by percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens in some member by accident, or by percussion: and that pain persists a long time, and does not respond to treatment with medicines: then it should be cauterized with the Pointed cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be to all members according to its size, and its health, and its weakness, and its virtue, and its location of twist, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	But if it is healed by the first cauterization, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat on top of it the cauterization.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For these pains are used to pass from one member to another as it approaches that which is affected.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Why should the consequences be caused by the cautery, until the sick is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	The mode of cauterizing in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter LIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	But the lepers should be cauterized by a sharp instrument.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the characteristic of Leprosy, which is caused by putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: so that you consider carefully how to cauterize it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If this Leprosy is not open, and you have treated it with the one we have mentioned in the division, and it has not come down, nor stayed: and you wait for the disease to encompass the whole complexion: then cauterize him on top of the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the hairline, and a second lower down towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two above the two ears, and one behind the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And last, you shall hold your hand with the cautery just a little while, until it prints upon the mouth an impression of pallor, and the membranes are displaced from it; that the expiration of the vapors of great heat may be relieved, and the cautery also over the splenetic organ, according to what went before.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leper has already spread on the sick person and appears clearly: then you shall cauterize with these cauteries which we said in the beginning, and with a cautery on the tip of the nose, and two cauteries on the two cheeks, and two cauteries on the two sides of the neck, and six on the sides of the back, and one great one on the hahosas near the tail end and one above it: and two on the shoulders and two on the elbows, and two on the breasts, and one on the entire chest, from the connection of the fingers of his hands and feet: and cauterize him on all joints, from the connection of the fingers of his hands and the feet of his feet: and cauterize him on all heels of his feet, and on the knuckles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And so that you do not burn them, take care from the nerves that are at the very end of the heel.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when one is cauterized with a cautery on the bone of the chest, and another on the bone of the stomach, and another on the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you should know that the more you add cautery, the greater is the benefit, and the more it confers.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you should know that a sick person does not feel pain in the cautery, unlike a healthy person: therefore because his body is already stunned.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is fitting that the cauteries should be of a size and proportion appropriate to the limbs and joints: according to what went before from the appearance of the tools of the trade.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cauteries with flour of herb and honey, and with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	To cauterize in a stupor.
Caput L.	Head.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a limb is stuporous and does not heal with medicines, oils, plasters, and so on, then cauterize the limb that is stuporous with cautery, according as the magnitude of the limb is increased, or its diminutio
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And place your cautery instrument within the thickness of the skin a little.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the limb with ointment until it is healed.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes when cauterization occurs for some stupefaction which befalls the hand, or foot, in the spine of the back near the exit of nerves which stir that limb: and the stupefaction is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But he does not do this [cauterization] unless he is wise in the anatomy of limbs, and knows the exit of nerves which stir the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	The way to cauterize in Albucasis.
Caput LI.	Head.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albucasis is burned and does not bear any of the artifice of medicine: then cauterize on top of it a little with deep cautery, according as the thickness of the skin, until the hue is removed, and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for the limb with herb flour, with rose oil and leaves of arglochea, and pigeon blood, and duck blood: let one part be mixed, let them spread on a cloth, and let them adhere to the place until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	The way to cauterize in cancer.Caput LII.
Caput LII.	Head.De modo etiam, si est male olidus, aut
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and the eye is affected: then cauterize the eye with a circular cautery according as it turns.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But the wise have said, that the last cautery in the middle should be used.Et quandoque cauterizatur, non facit utrique oculo, sed mediocoelo, et postea
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	But to me that does not seem right: for I fear that it will ulcerate: and I have seen it sometimes.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that he be cauterized around his wound with a circle, as we have said: or with many caustics.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in ablation.
Caput LIII.	Chapter III. On Ablation.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has ablation and it is delayed in maturing, or because of superfluous reasons that cause it, or because of old age, when the blood is little, or because of time, and the pulse rushes to mature ablation, then cauterize around his wound with a few caustics by pricking.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let go of him.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hurry with the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	But if you pierce his wound with a caustic, then take this kind of caustic, which is in the form of:
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place him in the middle of the ablation until it enters the skin; and let the caustic remain with him because it will weaken, so that the flow of blood may be eased.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then take care of him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Regarding the method of cauterizing with a caustic that corrupts.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter III. On Corrupted Wounds.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	Corrosion is not but corruption in a walking member, and it corrupts the member itself; just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	But if you see corrosion in a place that tolerates caustic with fire, then take many caustics, small and large, as is suitable for the place where corrosion is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize him from all parts until you eradicate the entire corruption, and do not leave any trace of it.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then let him go for three days, and place sulfur, reduced with oil, on the cauterized places until all the eschar and corruption are eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then take care of him with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	But if you see that after three days healthy flesh is born by a kind of rebirth, and there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then apply cautery to that which remains in the corrupted locations.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And sometimes when it is infected it is cured with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it itself rises up at the place of cauterization.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, cauterization with fire is faster in effect: and I have indeed already said that cauterization with acute medicine is applied in division: so take it there when it tolerates it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the method of cauterizing in slits and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This disease often occurs in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a gross, filter-like growth that hurts the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And there are two ways of applying cauterization to them: cauterization with fire and cauterization with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As for the cauterization with fire, like the feathers of a penning torch it is prepared from iron, according to the quantity that contains the clap when all parts are covered: and its edge should be sharp.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the burned thing on the clap.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn the hand with the cautery around the clap, until the cauterization reaches the depth of the clap: and leave it for three days, until pus begins to be discharged.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then bind the thing with wet silkworm threads, crushed with salt: and leave the plaster on the thing at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it itself will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with a soft salve of meat, until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not turned inside out and often occur on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then apply to them cauterization with hot water: and it is like receiving a tube made of brass, iron, or a feather of a penning torch: and place it on the clap, or on an atharel.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour into the tube a little amount of hot water: hold your hand so that it is turned around with your finger to such an extent that the edge of the tube is pressed into the root of the clap, and the hot water is found at the bottom: and let stand for a while on the prickling of the hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release him, for the wound to be cured with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	So do with them one after another until you have done all that are in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they have been eradicated, with the same unguent that generates flesh from the wax.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	The method for cauterizing in a tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to someone who has a tremor due to cold in a nerve, or from quartan fever, or otherwise: then you should cauterize the spot four times, or five on top of the spine, and between each vertebrae with cautery, and in the pit of the stomach with cautery, and above the stomach with cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For a tremor ceases when it is oiled with cauterization, and a feverish health is hastened by the health of cold.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	The method for cauterizing with Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When albater are expelled from the body, that is to say, pus that is produced from corrupted coarse material.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Then, when it first appears, it should be cauterized all over the head with fine cautery and a piece of myrrh, whose tip is lit with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with long roots of aristochnema.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lenticular cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they are cauterized with fire, at first during their expulsion in this way: and they do not increase: and they are broken up by the excess, and are healed from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it should be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	The method for cauterizing in a flux of blood from an artery in the ulnar:
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.De modo autem hic cauterizandi f
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	However, it often happens that a flux of blood comes from an artery that has been cut near the ulnar, whether from outside, or at the site of an abscess, or when cauterizing a member, and similar things: and it is difficult to stop it. Oportet itaque ex parte, ubi accidit, aduersus haec caute
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	So when this happens to someone, then grasp the affected artery with your hand and place your finger over it as an indicator: and grip it very tightly until the blood is stopped under your finger and nothing comes out of it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put on a small amount of olive oil fire, and a great many more: and blow on them until they are very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or small, or large, according to the size and place of the broken artery, and place the fire on it: then remove your hand quickly: and hold the fire until the blood is completely stopped.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.
