If you should release your hand from the opening of the artery and put out the fire, then take another fire quickly from those that are prepared in the fire:
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	So do not stop doing this with one after the other until the blood is completely stopped.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful so that you do not burn the fire that is there, and do not bring on another injury to a healthy person.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, it is then impossible to stop it: especially if the artery is large, unless with four fingers.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with fire, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends are drawn back, and the blood stops flowing.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with a strong knot of thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or are placed on the top of a drug that stops the flow of blood and is tightened with a decreasing constriction.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But he who gives the cut with a knot, and constriction with a cloth, or puts burning things together, and similar things, does not give it deeply unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if this happens to someone and there is no present physician or medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the opening of the wound, as we have related, and its constriction very tightly until the blood is stopped from the upper part of the wound, and around the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved away, above it with cold water always stirring the cold, until the blood has congealed, and has thickened, and has been cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And while that is considered, what does not require a poultice or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	The end of the first part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The book of surgery by Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On incising, perforating, and draining wounds, and similar matters.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the first chapter about all illness that is treated with a burning cauterization and medicine, and its causes, instruments, forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed those chapters from the top to the bottom.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter in the same way: so that the one who is inquiring may find what he seeks easily.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, you should learn from your son, that horror is in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of that, it is necessary to be more careful, since there are many things in this operation that cause a tremor and fear, and they lead to death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not allow that hesitation to come about, for sometimes those who are in this art of surgery get into a difficult situation with the diseases of people, and that leads to their own death.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For some of them become angry with their own illness, and they are easily killed because of the severity of their disease and the length of their suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when ill health comes from fear, which indicates death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And some of them give you a gift, and they promise you health, but their illness is destructive.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it is not necessary that you should assent to him who comes to you from them, whose way is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And be your prudence greater than your cupidity and your avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presumptively surmise anything from him, unless after having certain knowledge that confirms it with you as regards the success of what is worthy of praise.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And for the treatment of all your sick patients, with prognosis and indication of that which is appropriate for their recovery.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in him is an aid to you in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O son, with his understanding and not take away from you his guidance and inspiration: for it is in his power.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have ordered this chapter distinguishing it into chapters, according to which precedes in the chapter of Cautery from the crown to the feet: that you may be aided with what you wish from him and for which you are in need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the treatment of water which is added to the heads of boys.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this sickness often occurs in boys at birth; or when the midwife squeezes the head of the boy without gentle touch.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it also happens for an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this disease in any other than in boys; and I wished to see all of them die, because of that, therefore I have left off the operation on it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen a boy from among them, of whom the head was filled with water, and his head increased in size every day, until he could not sit himself up on his own, because of the size of his head: and his moisture increased, until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture, or it is added between the skin and the jaw: or it is added under the bone over the Mandible.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that, if there is humidity between the skin and bone, and the apostema is small, then you should find a fissure in the middle of the head in width; and its length be almost two knots until the humidity has run out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of the scalpel.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	But if the humidity is increased and the apostema is larger, then place two fissures according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	But if the humidity is under the bone and the sign of it is that you see the comissures of the head open from all parts: and the water is depressed when you press it with your hand towards the inside, and is not hidden from you: then you should find in the middle of the head three fissures, according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, remove all the humidity.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tighten the fissures with rags and flour.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then dip it in vinegar and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then dissolve the ligaments, and care for the wounded joints with linen, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not cease to tighten the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick with dry and little-humidity food until their member is comforted, and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another way of incision is that you consider where the appearance of the size of the apostema and the collection of water appears.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Since when ever it is in the back more, or in the front, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So climb up with an incision where you see the apostema and the filling appear: and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, so that you do not hit the artery, and does not happen a flow of blood, and the sick dies from that flow with the evacuation of water.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Of the incisions of arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Head 2.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When there happens to someone a catarrh to the eyes, or to the chest, and it does not improve with medicines: then the last treatment is in that, incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	So when you want to cut them, let the sick person carry his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then cover the place with a sharp cloth so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the sick person tie his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is beating.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places are those which are behind the ears: and rarely they are hidden, except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with caustic on each: and cut both with a sharp scalpel, cutting towards the mouth: and let it be made through the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you want, insert the scalpels under the arteries, and cut them from above with a cut.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the cut be almost two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood flows out with a pulsating movement, which climbs to the inside at an frequent interval.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear by touch, then it is necessary that measurements are taken from the color of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with caustic and find until you reach the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what needs to be emitted from blood, is six minutes and perhaps you emit more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All this depends on the amount that appears to you from the vein and filling of the artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider towards the neck.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there is something stuck in the throat, then cut it so that it does not cause a boil to form: and tie the neck with linen thread from a cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the patient with ointment, until he recovers.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Regarding the extraction of arteries, which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Head
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a man has an old headache, or sharp cataracts because of the acrid and sour liquids, and heat in the temples, or old sodas, stinging, and similar things: and he is treated with the methods of medicine, and does not report it: then we are expert in these diseases, extracting the arteries from the temples, or cauterizing them, as we have described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them, is, as the patient has hair on his temples, and it points to an apparent artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	And himself he shows you from his pulse, and rarely is hidden except in a few men, or when he shudders with cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then the patient should tie his head with any cloth: and then he should cover the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or he should moisten the place with warm water, until it appears to you in a manifest way.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a spikelet, which has been slightly bent.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scratch the skin with it easily, until you reach an artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw it into her and extract it from above, until you draw it out of the skin, and make it ooze with sweat from tunics which are under it on all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is thin: then wrap it up with the end of the spikelet.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part a little more than the length of its ends, and turn them in opposite directions, and do not let there be any flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it does not cut, and if it does not split, the deep blood will not rise.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then make ooze with blood for six ounces, up to three drops.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it should be tied in two places with double thread, strong, from silk: or with string of the hair, so that it does not come under putrefaction before hardening of the wound, and let there be a flow of blood.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the superfluity, which is between the two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Make it do this thing at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if there is a wound, cauterize it with the knife until it reaches the mouth, with a surgical knife: until the ends of it stand still in its place.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And this work is better if the patient has no fever, or if his complexion is tepid.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cautery is from those which remain to finish the wetnesses.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to use a ligature.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries, that the place may be filled with the old cooked substance: and let them be placed on the flesh from afar made pulli.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the solution of the ointment with dry medicines which make the flesh grow, and with ligatures, until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	That if during the operation a flow of blood comes from an artery, then you should proceed to cut it off with the cautery, or to fill the place with a bandage: and hold your hand firm, until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	That if you have nothing present for this, then place your finger on the place, until the blood has congealed.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And dip the place in the water of cold frothiness, until the sharpness is calmed down, and hold it firm according to what is necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from that which is easier and more easily extracted the artery, it is, as if a pin has two points, like an almond;
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, there are much less sharpness than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp, like two knives, it is necessary for both to have coldness: and do not cut into the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	And when there is a little roughness on them, it is held in them the heat of fire, and the flesh is cut off quickly: and so this work is better on all operations, and lighter and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And set a space which is the quantity of the roughness of the finger between the two knives, after you have marked the two places with the caustic: and put both on well alight, until they come to the nose, and fall into only two places: that it may be stretched out what is between their extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For with this cautery, deep parts are not consolidated.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of cauterization.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment of acute, chronic, and stinging eye wounds.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the tears are persistent and there is a course of blood from the veins that run along the outside of the skull: when this does not respond to medical treatment, his eyes will begin to turn red, and he will feel a crawling sensation on his forehead, as if it were caused by ants walking over it; his eyes will become dry and irritated, so they have been corroded by their hair with corrosion; and his eyelids will become heated from the pain of the tears. Then the ancient people used to treat them with this operation, and called it the Ense cure.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And is, as you command, to shave off the hair on the forehead of the sick.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions in the forehead that are equally spaced according to its length: and let the length of each incision be almost as long as two fingers, and let one incision be equally distant from the middle of the nose, and the second according to half the distance between the two mandibular teeth, and the third from the side of the second: and pay no attention to the arteries that are on either side: and extend your hand out from the joint of the two jaws, and let the space between each incision be the length of three joined fingers: and have a sponge plug or a dry cloth ready for stopping up the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a long sharp instrument into the two ends of the incision, whose end is soon followed by this form:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision that is from the temporal side, all the way to the second incision: and scrape with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the waxy membrane that is on top of the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do this also from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then pull out this spoon and introduce into the first incision again a different instrument, which is called a sharp chisel from one side of the lather, not acute from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is his form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And this is his form.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then place the acute side of him towards the flesh attached with skin, and the soft side towards the bone: and push him, until he reaches the middle crack: and cut off with him
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when an equal quantity of blood runs out, then express the places from the clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place into every crack a chip of hard-boiled bread, and place on them wet rags soaked in wine, or oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And check so that the swelling does not become hot.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, loosen the ligaments, and give a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for him with basilic ointment, and with the other ointments that heal wounds: until he is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	§ On the treatment of acute tears and cataracts in the eyes from within the head.
Caput V.	Head
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute, sharp, and frequent tears occur in someone's eyes, and their eyes appear weak, pale, and already weakened: and the eyelids become ulcerated, and hair falls out from them, and there is a sharp pain in the deep part of the head, and resulting sneezing: then remove these accidents, so that those materials do not come, unless they are removed with many.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is as you instruct the sick person to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in the middle of his forehead, or to the right or left of its width, and start from the left-hand side of the temple until it reaches the right-hand side: and push it up to the bone: and extend your hand away from the jaw bones that move during mastication: until it is detected by the bone: and dry out all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the wound with a hot sponge, or with linen bandages.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind above with flannel: and dip the flannel in wine and oil so that a hot pus does not form.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you have removed it, and you see that a hot pus is about to appear: then it is necessary that the surgeon should come, until it has begun to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then take care of the man with the dry cure that makes the flesh grow: as if you had taken two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony: and prepare an ointment from it, and administer it to the birth of meat in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	Regarding the cure that falls on gold.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls on gold is of four kinds: either mineral rock, or similar stones, such as iron and lead; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a fluid, such as water and vinegar, and things like them; or some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When, however, a stone falls on gold, or a kind of rock that does not add to it, and does not grow in gold, expose gold to the sun: but if you see a stone, then distill into gold some of the oil of olive nuts, or sesame seeds.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction, and make it snort with ointment, and paint the nose at the approach of the snorting, after you have put on around the ears rolls of cloth or wool, and extend the ear towards the top.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For often with this cure one goes wrong.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if he does not go wrong, then administer the extraction with gentle hand, that is, with thin gestures: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	But if he goes wrong with his hand, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer the extraction with a thin, blind hook, made in a few places.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore he does not come out through that [incision], then make a tube of brass, and introduce the end of the tube into the ear hole a lot, and the dust that is around the tube with the softened gold with oil, so that there is no way for the wind except through the tube: then draw it out with your breath strongly.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For many times he went out with it when we told him.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out in this way: then take from the alum-pot or from the water, that is, the gluten prepared, with which gold is woven, a little piece: and put it on the end of the ear after you have dried the ear with moisture. Then introduce it into the ear hole easily, after you have removed the wax from the ear.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	But if it does not come out with all that we have told you, then prepare yourself to split it, before a hot blister or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the way to split it is so that the phlebotomist takes blood from the head first: and draw out the blood according to the measure of its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear towards the top, and find a small hole at the base of his ear next to his fat there: and make the hole round in shape, until you reach a stone: then take it out with that, which is possible for you from instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then close up the hole from your side with speed, and care for that, until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	That if what falls into the ear is from one grain, which grows, and swells up: then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you to come out, then take a thin spike, subtle, according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with that from the grain, which falls into the ear, a little spike, according to this shape. And do not consider it, when you think, that this grain is already moistened by the moisture of the ear, until you put it on many thorns: then draw it out with a hook, or with a gentle gesture, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction alleviates it.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But the water that is poured into the ear should be used by the sick with sternutation first, and also to fill his ear a little cooked old: and lying down on it his ear, where there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If so then leave it through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, fine, soft, and heat them slightly with fire, and insert one of them into the ear hole of the sick: and let him sit on one leg from there, and hit it with another stone against the ear bone.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	So he will not cease to do this with stones and pebbles, until all the water has come out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And already the water is coming out so that you take it from a torch or from one branch and insert the end of it into the ear: and light the end with fire, until it is burned up completely.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the branch a few times, until all the water has come out: and take it out with a tube according to what has been said before in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In extraction however of an animal inside it, if it is a small body, like a flea, and similar to it, take care of it as I have said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body, which seems to the sense: then administer its extraction with gestures and hooks: and the work of it is easier for all those who hold it in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the extraction of scabs from the ear, when you care for it with what we have said in division and in the book of distillation, and your cure does not bring about this: then it is necessary that you observe the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If so then appears there something like scabs, then extract it with gestures, or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if there does not appear anything there, then take a tube whose this form, narrow below, wide above: and insert the end into the ear according to the quantity that the sick can bear it: and then suck with it a strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Here he was quite often, until all the wounds had healed.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to go out, then bind around the catheter with plaster, as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	That if they do not go out with him which we have said: then administer the distillations which the ancient ones know about in the infection of wounds: and you will find it in the book on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And be your pour forth which you pour forth oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see make it from silver, or from brass, lower part tight, in which sits a small hole, wide upper.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Then sit as if you push forth what is in the constriction of the catheter, sit from brass slightly made.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you want, take radium, and pour it on the end of the cotton in a gentle boiling: then pour forth oil, or broth, or what you want from these medicines into the catheter: and let it sit in brass: then insert radium with the cotton coming out, and squeeze it forth by your hand gently, until it pushes forth oil in the constriction of the ear, and feels it within: and that which is poured into the ear, may already be warmed a little with fire: and may not be cold so as to distillate it in there: for these medicines do not tolerate it.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Regarding the treatment of auricular accidents.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When certain children come out of their mothers' wombs with their ears not pierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has happened also to some people that they have an auricular ojection from a scar, or from flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this ojection, when it comes to be in a deep pore of the ear, which does not result from a cut: and when it happens to be on the outside of a pore little, and results from that cut.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which has happened in a deep pore of the ear, and which does not comprehend in its appearance, is in many dispositions difficult to heal.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows the opening of the wound, you should put the gold nurse on the sun, and look at it: if you see the operation apparent, open it with a thin spatula, whose form is this which follows, let the end of it be in a small width, some of it being acute: and let the rest of the spatula be soft on both sides: so that it may not hurt the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If then the operation is from the flesh born in the meatus of the ear: then hold it with a small hook, and cut it with ease of cutting, until all the flesh is taken away.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	That if the operation is in the deep of the ear: then take a small ray, soft, and heat it slightly with fire: then put it into the meatus of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If then you feel the operation with it, that it remains weak with the weight of hearing, be careful in opening it with ease: and with care, so as not to hurt the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the ear a little linen according to the quantity of width of the foramen, which you have inserted into the Egyptian ointment: let it be a few days, until you are sure of the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take linen, and pour into it water rose, and powder over it some fine powder, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	That if you see the ear already separated: then it is necessary that you should take out linen, and let it with other linen which you have inserted into the green which you make with rose oil, until it is healed: then take care of the ear until it is cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If then blood flows: then dip a sponge, or cloth, into cold water, and put it on the ear: and use the remaining cure, which stops the predicted flow of blood in the book of distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Of the care of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Head VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the signs of Althelil which occur in the eyelids when they are moist and dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	You should therefore hold them with tenails; or with an anchor, and strike them with a mallet from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then put on the ground the three-sided piece of wood.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lenticular cauldron.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterizing them is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For many times they run away when something remains of their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not run away.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	In regard to the care of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	This often happens to the eyelids which is a accumulation of moisture which is thick and hard, and for that reason it is called Grando; and it is an aggregation of moistness which is thick on the upper eyelid, and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation in them is therefore, that you should consider then, if there is Grando proceeding from it, which appears from the eyelid, and moves to all parts, and the thing is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	So then put a slit across the width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then peel off that skin from all parts with ease until it is peeled off.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hang it on a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if you are not prepared to cut it off, unless after you have made a slight incision in the eyelid, then that will hurt the sick person.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	That if the slit is large: then aggregate it with a stitch; and take care of it, until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, you will not have any trouble from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The unguents restore that skin and make it flesh again.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if Grando is a discharge towards the inner part of the ear towards the inside surface, then reverse the eyelid and hang up Grando on a hook: except that you should make a slight incision, and press it from all parts.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is made longer by an incision, this does not hurt in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then, after the incision has been made with a blade, wash the eye with salty water; and take care of the place where it is swollen, until the wound heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10: Head.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a grease that is generated in the eyelids; and it often happens that this affects young people: it damages their eyes, causing them to have cataracts in the morning, and they cannot see the light of the sun, because their tears flow towards them, and for that reason they always rest their faces on their hands, and lie upon them when they sleep, and their eyelids are moist with an inflammation, which has already been caused by the swelling: and the protuberance of Axirnath is apparent to the eye; and when you press the spot with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And its mode of action is such that he who has the illness places his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen cloth, and prepare it with a knot, and make from it a circle which will encompass all the Axirnath.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put it on that, and press with your fingers from all parts so that the Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of it with a sharp knife an incision that is not larger than a toothpick, and does not extend to the deeper part.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should find the whole skin, so that you reach the Axirnath; for in several positions the Axirnath proceeds from a crack of a second kind, as if by the loss of snow on the white hair.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Then pull it out with the cloth which you have soaked between your fingers towards the outside: and you should move your hand to the right and left until it has spread out; and carefully so that you do not add to the incision with the knife at the eye, and let it go.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If however it does not appear to you at first in the fissure, you add a little to the fissure with ease, until the axil comes out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then take it out, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then dip the cloth in vinegar and water, and place it on the spot, and squeeze it with flour.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are people who grind salt, and put it in the concavity of the wound, so that what remains of the moisture is liquid.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If however a blister arises in the place, then take care of it with soothed plasters, until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Regarding the methods of Ataxmir for the eyes: that is, when the eyelid becomes soft to the eye, so that it rubs as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs grow out of the eyelids besides their usual course under the natural lashes, and turn backwards: then they harm the eye, and produce diseases such as constant tears, softening of the eyelids, and cloudiness, until they cause the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir treats the eyes according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or with a caustic and fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicines, according to what is set down in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Ataxmir treats with incision and stitchings.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with blisters, according to what I say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you put the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then take the left hand and turn the eyelid of the eye with your fingers.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is turned, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it is not turned: push the point into it, where there is a hair from the lower part of the eyelid, and make it penetrate with the wire from above, and let it lie close to the hairs themselves, that is, close to the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow out: and pull the wire upwards with the lid, and turn it outwards.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelids under the hairs with the spatula incident from the greater tear up to the smaller tear.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the filament, and put under the eyelid a thin bit of wool from wool or cloth: then mark on the eyelid with the caustic, which is like the shape of the leaf of mint.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that it be made according to the amount and height of the eyelid: for this varies from person to person.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	From these is one who needs it so that it should strike out from the eyelid a large amount, according to the amount which softens from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the spatula find over the two lines which you marked, and begin from the greater tear up to the smaller tear, and let there be a single crack near the natural hairs, as is the roughness of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce the hook into one of two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape all that.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then collect with a stitch the two lips, with ac and fine wool thread: and wipe away the blood, and let it adhere what is superfluous from the hairs over the two eyelids, with which some things are to be seen, if you wish to do so: and if not, then don't worry.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then let go of the stitch and the thread up to three or four days: then take care of that.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, let go of the knot without a stitch, and take care of itself with it, which dries up and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid becomes detached at the seal of the wound and aggregation of it: but the future is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This way of treating has been taught by the ancient Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is concern over the weak one, and it is from a good operation, and it is not in it any fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is also with Ataxmir: and that is, as the signs on the eyelid are made like the shape of the leaf of mint, which we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then clean the eyelids with three separate hooks, or gathered together, according to this form which follows; then cut what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this form, with equality of the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if you are not able to hold the hook, and it does not match: then take an acumen where the hair is, and insert it in the middle of the form: and introduce another hair near the larger tear, and a second hair near the smaller tear: and gather the hairs between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then clean your hand with equal cleaning: and clean the skin above where the mark of the knot is, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a stitch: and care for it, until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if there is an abscess by your incision, or a hole: but this abscess with caustics, and those similar, from a wax sitting.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelids also happen, so that his hair turns.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore it is necessary that you use in this what we have said in the incision: but the stitch on both sides is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Of the care of Ataxmir with the scissors.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	AND It is, so that you turn the eyelid, and cut the hole which is within, according to what we have told.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then with art make two scissors, or two thin sticks: whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width is less than the width of a hair: and you have already incised at the ends of each side where you hold the hairs.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each with subtlety above what is superfluous from the eyelid of the eye, and tightly tighten the two scissors from both sides, and let it go after a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin is tight to kill, and will be covered with rust, and will rot, until it falls by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	But if it delays, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for her, until she recovers.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore she is healed, take away the plaster; and do not prick the cicatrice with a pin.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two cans, which you shall make according to this figure, and their quantity in length and breadth.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	De the creation of two canisters for puncturing the eye with an aiguille.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in that case is, that you should take an aiguille sharp, and stick it into the eye with a thread of silk.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then bind the ends together, and tie each with a small knot; and make the length of the threads be half an inch.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then take another thin thread and put it under the first bandage, and tie the ends together if you wish to.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then place the sick person's head in your lap, and hold it near the light that the operation may be seen; for it is a delicate operation, or a minute one.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then stick the aiguille with the bandage into the root of the eyelid, and let it penetrate quickly into the eyelid, until you draw out a natural pimple.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the pimple up above the bandage: and stick it into the bandage; if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then take your hand with it, until the pimple and the bandage go out of the eyelid with a natural pimple.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the bandage is pulled out, and does not come out with it: take the bandage from below, with the thread which you have put into it, until you draw out the bandage from the upper aperture, and cover the eye; then take both of them away, and close the eye; and let him be closed for two days, or three, until the pimple adheres to its place, and grows on the flesh.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If however the pimple is short, then either join it with a long natural pimple, and take it away with it; or dismiss him, until he grows longer in space, and then stick him.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of a wound on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII. On the treatment of a wound on the upper
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When it affects the eye, this is called Leporine.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Al-Xatrati is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	So the accidental one is caused by the consolidation of a wound, or a section, or a cauterization, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of operation in it is such that you find her consolidation, and so that you separate her lips, and put into it what is between them from a linen cloth, and bind her, until she heal.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary, that you use in her cure the things which dry and tighten: for if you do so, Al-Xatrati will be worse than it was: but you should use in her cure the things which soften, such as fenugreek: and dip with it into water, in which has been boiled aloe, linseed: and apply with it an unguent, which melts when mixed with some oils: and wrap it up with the linen, and apply the unguent with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your cure is such that you may keep all art, so that she does not consolidate, according to the form which it had in the beginning.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have described, is but a certain correction of Al-Xatrati, so that the form of the place may not be completely changed, altogether.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On the treatment of Al-Xatrati when it affects the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkling or contraction upward toward the right or left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XVIII. On the treatment of Al-Xatrati when it
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Al-Xatrati which affects below is what is called Al-Xatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is either natural or accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental one is caused by a wound, or a nick, or a cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the mode of operation in it is such that you take up the akh (a substance used in medicine), in which there is a double thread, and dip it into flesh, and let it penetrate from the left tear gland to the right tear gland, until the thread reaches both extremities of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh to the upper parts with an awl, and cut it with a chisel.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If, then, the figure returns to the eyelid according to what is necessary, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take the ray, and put it in the notch, and turn it with it the eyelid: and find two notches in the inner side between the eyelids, and are the ends of the two notches from two angles of incision until they meet and make the figure this figure, and it is a Greek letter.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by quantity, which is the acute lower side of it, from him who follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather together the separated parts: sew them with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what I have said, about medicated salves, and liniments, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if an alien body comes out of the notch, and sewing, or cauterizing: then you should find a flat notch under the eyelids' hairs, also according to what has preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a liniment, according to what I have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the whole speech about the cure of an alien body, when it is on top, or below, it is, that it runs in this operation, according to what is prepared from the form of Al-Xatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it is itself a multitude of different forms: and the prudent artisan prepares the mind with whatever way is possible for him, until he makes the figure return to its natural form, or close to it, and himself becomes infirm, according to what suits him, from operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Regarding the adhesion of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	When this consolidation happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid is consolidated with the white of the eye, and prevents itself from its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, it is necessary that you introduce the radius end under the eyelid and lift it up; or extend it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a fine blade, which should not be too sharp, but rather a little blunt: so that the sick person does not disturb during the operation, and does not move the blade, and does not hurt his eye with its sharpness: and your incision should be as you remove this adhesion easily, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and heals all the adhesion.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then, at that time, pour into the eye salty water to wash it, with water Ablute him: or distill in him from a mixture of distilled water and dissolved zinc:
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then, after a day, use a thread to separate the eyelid from the eye: and place on the eye wool dipped in Albughine: and after three days use a blade, and with solids, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Regarding the incision of the nail and the eminence of the flesh of tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous: and it is similar to a soft, thin wood.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen moisture as snow: which when it touches metal, iron, or tin takes it with a hook, and does not stick to it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin, unless from the greater tear, until it is slowly discharged, until it dries up, and prevents the light, and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of working on his incision is: so that the sick person puts his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and lift his eyelids with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then take the nail with a little hook, and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a sharp needle, and insert it into the nail with a horsehair thread, or a hook: and make the thread strong, and double the end of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce it with a pin, and tie the nail to the thread, and extend it upwards: and cut it with a sharp blade, and remove it from the nail, and extend it again upwards: and scrape it with the hair of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you were holding it with a hair until its tip.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the residue on the lacrimal root with a fine scalpel, or with small forceps; and release the natural flesh of the lacrimal so that its course of tears is not interrupted by the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And when ever the nail extends itself in the sole with a hook: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape it with a soft scalpel, whose shape is like this.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful not to touch the horny tunic with the scraper, lest it cause a break, and pierce the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then, after the incision, pour into the eye some crushed salt, or make a paste of zinc, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the eye with whatever is necessary, until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is not nervuous, and you cannot get into it, nor does the hook hurt it, then often cure this nail condition with medicines, and it heals as well as that in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you need to cut it, then open the eye for nursing, and take a fine scalpel, gentle of sharpness, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And scrape the nail from above with subtlety.
