Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it is getting thinner and drying up, and the rasion becomes imprinted in it, then distil from your own blood into the eye, made of zinc paste, or of red ochre, or of fine salt: and pamper the eye until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat this operation on it again, until it is completely removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless you have a warm apostema in the eye: for then let go of it, and take care of the apostema until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on the nail with the rasp, until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	Except that the flesh of the lacrimal, if it hurts greatly in the eye, be suspended with a hook, and cut off from it: and do not make the last incision, lest the course of tears be interrupted.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then pour the eye-wash into the tear-vessels with red rub, or made from za'atar, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	In regard to the incision and the flesh that has come out of the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	This flesh sometimes becomes attached to the eye of some men, mixed with red color or laid on top of it, until it covers the pupil, or approaches it, or presses against the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outward; and is absorbed into the rose-colored cheeks.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation on it is also that he who is lame should put his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes and pluck out all the flesh with a suitable hook; and hold it with a forceps, or grasp it.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then make the incision on the flesh first, until you have cut off all of it with the scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And keep away from the eye so that you do not wound it during the operation: and let your incision be where you incise, or with a scalpel, which we have mentioned in the incision of the nail: or with small forceps, with which Așbel is caught, according to what its form will be after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is complete and all the algardenium has been removed, then fill the eye with ground salt: or distil into it red powder, and similar medicines that are corrossives: and put on top of the eye a cotton wool with alumen, so that it is protected from the burning heat.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If there remains any algardenium, and hot blood reigns over you, and you are worried about the heat of the aposteme; then let go of the eye, and take care of it with him when he sits down.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on the flesh again, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do likewise with the meat that has come out of the eye from this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary that you keep away from natural or accidental causes of eye disease, operating with iron: and do not put your hand into any of these operations, until you are certain, for that member is able to bear that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	About collecting sevel from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Of sevel that are small red sores that grow on the eye, and that prevent vision; and also weaken the eye with the passage of time.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	It is therefore necessary for you to consider, first of all, whether the eye in which there is sevel is strong and has no other disease except the sevel; then collect the sevel from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And if you command the sick person to place his head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then hang the sores by one or two hooks according to your skill: and let the hook be thin, double-shaped, or there may be two hooks on a single bar, according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then take with delicate hooks the sores with carefulness, and wipe away the blood hour after hour, until you see the sore spots coming out of the eye and healing up; and do not touch the eyes with your fingertips.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your surgery take place in the middle of the day, and be very firm in your surgery: so that you do not fall except for the sores.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have cleaned it out, then pour into the eye a little saffron liquid or a little red liquid; so that its own acuity may corrode what is left of the sevel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if you are not able to collect all of it in that hour, then plug the eye with something that soothes its pain; and let it rest for a few days, until the pain subsides: and protect it from the heat of the sun: and then repeat the same operation on it again according to this method, until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the hook.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Chapter XVIII.
Caput XIX.	Of reducing ari-sat to the nose.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	They named the medical instrument a fistula, which is used with caustic or acute fire according to what came before in its account.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if you do not heal it, then there is no skill in it: unless you discover a pimple at the time of its birth and drain all the moisture that is in it and the pus, until the bone is detected.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	And when the bone is detected, and you see corruption or discoloration in it, then scrape it out with this instrument, whose shape is like this.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the chisel of the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of iron and let the head be round like a chisel, which is marked with the file or with fine sand: and place the instrument on the corrupted place of the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then turn the instrument between your fingers and press your hand lightly, until you know that that corruption has now been shaved: and do it sometimes.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with dry leeching.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If then the place is healed, and a bone grows up in it, and the wound heals over: and remains forty days, and does not break again, and does not get infected, then you shall know that it has now been healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no skill in it, unless a tube is reduced to the nostril, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is so that you may extract the second bone with iron, or with sharp medicine: and when the bone has been detected, then take a chisel according to this form, whose end is metal, triangular: and let the wood of it extend to an edge like a pyramid, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then put it on the bone itself: and let it be near the tear: and extend your hand from the eye a little way.And when tu sentias in oculo, et vidisti strabismus, et non ponit caput tuum secundum naturalem locum suum: tunc scias quae ueneat cor
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then feel with your hand if you can feel the eye, and see if it is strabismus, and does not put your head into its natural place: then you shall know that the disease is coming out of it, whenever it feels weak.And then turn your hand with the chisel, until it enters the bone, and feels sick: by this means let it be known that the disease is leaving it, whenever it holds its hand over its nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with stictical medicines that are drying out, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When the flesh is then born and the place hardens: then the substance that flows out to the outside returns to the nose: so it is lighter on the sick.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the reduction of vision.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye shoots out with all its power and does not cause damage or loss of vision, then it is necessary to let go of the sick person: then let him bleed; afterwards put vents on the scalp without scarification but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then put on the eye a liniment that is made of Acacia, and Aloes, and Olibanum, and Sarcocolla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then tighten the eye from above over a plaster with many powders.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the mode of the powders is this: that you take soft cloths, many and double all the cloths out of them on four sides: make out of them a lot: then put them one over another according to the amount which the eye needs: then tighten them strongly with a hard cloth.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeatedly apply vents without scarification.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the vents and let go of the tightened eye during the day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If, however, the ligament again softens, then it is necessary to tighten it a lot: then remove the ligament after day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If the eye then is already clean with new wounds of the ligature, it is good: and if not, then repeatedly apply vents, and tightness, and vents, until the healing.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	On the incision of the ligament.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When the break-out occurs in the Veal ligament, then it shoots out and proceeds outside the eyelids like a grain of corn, and moves in the form of a man because of it, and the eye incises it: then the operation on it is this: and it is as if you were to insert an acorn in the root of the Veal from below to above.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another instrument into the space between the lacrimal and nasal bones, and let it penetrate: and then remove the first one according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut a space with a double-bladed knife, and fasten one end to the area around the nose with a ligature: and tighten it very much.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove it now, and place a woollen thread soaked in white of egg on the eyeball: and let go of it until the thread falls with the lacrimal filament.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with it, that it may comfort itself, until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the thread is tightened around the entire area with a circle of cloth, until the eye has developed great prominence.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a thin spatulum, which reaches to the depth of the eye, and let moisture from the white of egg flow in, and let the eye fall down, and immediately put it back in: then tighten it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	§ On the Cure of Alconey.
Caput XXII.	CHAPTER XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This condition called Alconey, is not anything but the white accumulating in the eye, similar to water dropping down, and it itself is not.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the method of treatment for it is, that you should make the sick person sit on a prepared bench, or directly.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head in your hands from both sides, and gently move it, until you feel the white moving to the lower part of his eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then bind it, and let it not fall down, and make the light complete: and the sick person shall see as he used to; and if it does not fall down below, you shall know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If, however, the descent of the white with it has not been prepared as we have said, then make the sick person sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a thin spatulum, and find it with him slightly above the connection of the corium with the corneal layer in the crown, until the white comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	So then when you have walked out, then distill into the eye hot water in which you mixed honey: or water in which you have already boiled fenugreek and honey; and then treat with the remaining treatment, until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water that has entered the eye, or a cascade.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII On the Treatment of Water That Has Entered the Eye
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	I have already spoken on the species of water, which are divided, and which suit the diagnosis and explanation, then take that same one according to the cure.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then you should make the patient sit with his two hands between himself and the light, near the sun: and bind his healthy eye, and tighten it: then you can blink his eye with your right hand, if the water has entered his left eye: or with your left hand, if it is his right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take alum with your right hand, if the eye is on the left: or with your left hand, if it is on the right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then put the end of the alum towards the crown by the thickness of the radius in the white of the eye which appears to be the tear: then push the alum with force: and you can turn your hand while doing so, until it penetrates into the socket of the eye: and you will feel that the alum has already reached the dry spot.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it should be such a measure of distance for the alum to the depth, which is the space between the pupil and the end of the blackness: and that is the crown of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see it in the same pupil with a red eye, on account of the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then put the alum until you reach the place where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it down with a gentle force.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	But if the water has already descended, then the sick person will see it right away, and the alum in his own eye immediately.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water has fallen, then deposit it second, except for what has exited as almonds.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When, however, it is formed and does not rise up: then extract the Almonds with ease: and you shall move your hand gradually.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in water a little of the clear salt of the gem: and wash with it the inner eye.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put on the whole eye a drop, or a wool dipped in rose-oil, and white of egg: and bind it with it the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those who are our companions at this time, put on him powdered cumin, mixed with white of egg.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	That if the Almond does not obey you at the entrance to the eye through its durezza, since it is from a man, whose eye is very hard: then you should take the spikelet which is called Alberid, whose this form.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Open it then with him only the conjunction so much, and not the last your hand in the hole: and is there only to do you make a small space for the Almond.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the Almond, according to what we have said above.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the completion of your work, let be prepared for the sick an uneven-made bed, in which he may sleep on his back in a dark house: and let be forbidden from all movements, and from coughing: and place before him food by which nature heals him: and let not move his head to the right, or at all to the left.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let sit the ligature according to its position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then dissolve it in that dark house, and test his vision: and let him see objects.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligature until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	But it is not necessary that he do this at the time of healing, or immediately after the incision: but rather, let him keep it away: because water rises quickly through a steep aspect.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If, however, the apoplexy is hot: then it is necessary that you release the eye before the seventh; and correct it with that which is settled when the apoplexy is settled: then absolve his sight, and put over his face the oral part in which the sight of him under lies for a few days, while he remains in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him leave the house gradually, and turn round in his seats.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that the student is not excused from sight sometimes in the zalah: then let him dare to look at the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed one of those who are from Al-Ayrah has already come to us; he said that it was done in Al-Ayrah a hole made with the magdan by which water is sucked up.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But verily you will not see anyone on earth who did that: and it is not written about him in any of the old books: and it is possible that it should be new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of the eyes from the magdan, so that they stand on her who does not know them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of pure brass: and let their ends be with this same subtle triangular shape, and the acute end.
Formae magda.	The forms of the magdan.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Regarding the care of a birthmark on the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Head 24th.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When and what different meats are added to the nose, from which there is something that resembles a scorpion of many feet: and from it is that cancerous meat, stone-like in colour, which is soft; and from it is that flesh which is soft, not stone-like in colour.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In that which of these meats is soft, not deceitful, and not cancerous, you should make it sit between your hands opposite the sun, and open its nostrils, and throw in a hook made of thin sharp iron from one side; then pull it out to the outside, and cut off what you have caught with it by means of a fine sharp chisel: then draw it towards you, and see if all the meat has gone.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If anything remains that cannot be cut off: then cut it with a slender instrument easily, until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if blood rules over you, or a fever occurs: then oppose it with that which is necessary; or if it is a malignant abscess, then approach it by cauterizing it, until the blood is cut off and all the flesh is taken away.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then let it be poured into the nose after an incision with vinegar, and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	But if the nose is opened, and moisture proceeds from it to the palate, then you should know that he is already well.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	But if the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then you should know that within himself there is a birth in the upper bones of the nose, to which the knife does not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then it is necessary that you introduce a thread of linen, of which there is some grossness, and spots in it many: and place between each spot the amount of a finger, or less: and he will be relieved, so that he lets one end of the thread into his nose with a ray, or with whatever is possible for him after he has done himself similar azur: and he should carry his odor, until it reaches as far as his throat, and he should come out onto his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And often indeed do this boys like this in school: and it is a simple thing for him who wants to.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the thread, the end that comes out onto the nose, and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then also close the opening of the skin with the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Let him be until you know that the flesh is already there with the spots on the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then pull out the thread: and put into the nose after drying up of the blood a liquid that you soaked in Egyptian ointment: let him be for three days, or more, until the ointment eats away all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put in the end of the nose a canula of lead, for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If it needs more cure than to dry it up, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For making the lavage, when it is distilled with oil and other medicines to the nose, make it of silver or brass: that it be like a little lamp, open-ended like a seashell: and its bore also.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you want to make a closed canula, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for making the lavage be full, fixed: which has a handle at the end, so that you hold it when you heat it with oil, or what you want to use and liquid things.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the cure for the nose.
Caput XXV.	Head 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	The Thelul of the nose often begins at the end and grows larger, and increases in appearance over several days until it appears like a festering wound.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of that, you should cut off all of its growth at the beginning of its appearance, and scrape it out completely.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then put over the place, or cautery, or burning medicine that stays in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If the cutting then lags behind until it grows larger, then examine it, if it is hard and has a dull color and few senses: then do not touch it with iron: because it is a cancerous growth.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For often the eye that has cut into a person's head develops a large, evil growth on top of it from which bad things arise.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the growth is soft to the touch and not dull in color, and you see that the cutting may have reached its whole extent, then wash it with water that is cool and cut the person without fear or trepidation: and heal the place along with it by drying it up and constricting it, until it heals over.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On sewing up the nose, mouth, and ears.
Caput XXVI.	Head and neck.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	For when a break in the continuity of one of these cartilage pieces occurs, little operation is effective on it, except in some men.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary, therefore, when it has happened to anyone of these things, as you should consider if the bone is recent with its blood: and then gather the pain of the wound with a suture: then take care of it, until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the continuity of the solution has already separated the lips, and some healthy part has been made: then it is necessary that you remove all of its own skin, until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then gather the two lips with a suture, and tie them tightly, and powder them over the wound with dragon's blood, and olive oil, ground: and put over the powders a fragment of a plaster of diafinicon, and some other of a consolidated plaster: and leave it tied for two days, or three.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then dissolve it, and change the medicine: and leave it, until the threads separate by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with ointment, until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	But the method of the suture is, to gather the solution of continuity, or with the knuckles, as we have told you about the suture of the foot: or to gather the solution with a thread, as I have made you aware.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	The extraction of nodules from the lips.
Caput XXVII.	Head and neck.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	In fact, it happens to many men, and especially in the inner lips there are similar hard little lumps of herbs: and some smaller, and some larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary that you open the lips, and find out on every lump, and hang it up with a hook, and drop it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after cutting dry, ground, until the blood dries.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then clean it with vinegar, and take care of the place with it, where there is a stinging sensation, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	Of the incision of flesh that has grown on the gums.
Caput XXVIII.	De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Often a sore grows on the gums, which the ancients called abluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	It is necessary that you should hang it by a hook: or hold it with tongs and cut it close to its root, and allow the wound to discharge its pus or blood.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then put on a place of poultice of ground pepper, or other astringent powders, drying agents.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	That if that sore returns after treatment, for often it does return, then cut it again and causticate it: for this does not return after the cauterisation.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	As regards shaving the teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	De rasione dentium cum ferro.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When they have gathered on the surface of the teeth from within and from outside, and between the gums are rough, knots, and sometimes corroding them, and becoming yellow, and white, until the corruption reaches the gums, and the teeth are decayed by it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is necessary that you should put the sick person between your hands, and his head in your lap, and shave off the rotten molars and teeth on which you see the gums, and similar ground powder: until there remains nothing of it, and likewise do with the blackness, rustiness, yellowness, and other discolourations, until they are cleansed.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If then what is removed from them at the beginning of the shaving is good: and if not, then repeat the shaving another day, and a third time, until you have come to the last study in it that you wish.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that the teeth respond to various shapes of blades: and also, as regards preparing your operation, this blade with which you cut from below is different from the blade which cuts between the teeth, according to their shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these forms of blades are prepared for you, which you will see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the extraction of toothache.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary that he who seeks to extract a tooth should be very careful and diligent in its extraction and late in its eradication.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For the tooth cannot be made to yield when it is eradicated: since the substance is soft; until, indeed, there is no excuse for its eradication, then let him who seeks to extract a tooth when he is ill consider eradicating it so that it hardens, and certify with you, the toothache.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Often the illness deceives the sick person and he supposes that the pain is in the tooth and eradicates it himself: then the pain does not retreat until the tooth is eradicated.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen from the operation of bleeding.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	Then, when the toothache is certified with you, let him who seeks to extract it scrape around the tooth with a file, in which there is some virtue, until it has healed the gum entirely: then, with your fingers or with delicate forceps little by little, until you have struck it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then, when the place is good and you have located it well, and your head is between your knees, which you hold firmly so that it does not move: then, with a firm grip, draw out the tooth according to its straight line, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If then it does not come out, then take one of these instruments and push it under it from all sides with ease, and try to move it, as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If then the tooth is pierced or corroded: then it is necessary to fill the cavity with cloth: and you should hold it tight with a narrow forceps so that it does not break at the time of your constriction on it with the forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary, that you should carefully examine with scraping around the gum entirely.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And keep your strength, so that you do not break it and a part of it remains, and returns to the sick one from that evil which causes him greater pain first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And for that reason, do not do what the phlebotomators do when they are in a hurry and their boldness overcomes them in eradicating it, except that they administer it which we have said.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For this reason, repeatedly they bring about great illnesses in men, which are more difficult to break than to heal and leave all the roots of it or some of its parts; or take it out with some of the bones of the jaw: as we have been told many times that thing.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then they wash it after eradicating it with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	That if it should happen that the flow of blood comes from the places (for it often happens) then dry up a little of the wound, and fill it with it: and if not, cauterize it, if it does not give you any relief.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shapes of the forceps which move with subtlety in the first place are long at their ends, short in the handle, thick so that they do not double when pressed against the tooth: they are like the thick handles which you see, until when you press them together they do not bite into themselves, nor double; and the shorter ends, and they are made of iron ingot or a twisted bar of iron, straightened out: and in their ends there are teeth, some of which enter into some things, and by constricting them tightly, they hold fast with force.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when the ends become like the shape of an ear which is called a ciconia, and are strong constriction:
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	of the eradication of teeth and extraction of fractures of the mandible bones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When a tooth that is broken remains after eradication, then you should place it on the cot with butter for one or two days, until it softens: and then introduce into it the gouge or the forceps; whose ends are like an ear which is called a ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The shape of this forceps is.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Make the ends smooth like a file: or like an awl.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	But if he does not yield to you at the exit with these pincers, then you should cut off the root, and peel off all the flesh, and insert the instrument which is called a small palanquin, whose shape is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	The short end should be slightly thicker; and it should not be wet, lest it break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	But if the root comes out by means of that, it is good; and if not, you should help with these other instruments whose shapes are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first triangular end, in which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The shape of the second triangular end, which is thinner.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	Also help with this instrument having two branches, whose shape is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with the other instruments and tools which have gone before in the description of the teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also help with this instrument which is like a large hook, of the shape of the second triangular end, twisted, in which there is some thickness so that it does not break; and let it not be wet.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many instruments for the teeth; and likewise the other instruments do not count; and the prudent artisan finds out by himself the instrument, according to which it is necessary for him to operate and to cure his own ailments.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For from the diseases of the teeth, there are instruments which the ancient ones did not describe, because of the diversity of their forms.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	But if the jaw is broken by the molar, or by any other bone of the mouth, then examine it carefully in its place with what belongs to it from the instruments and pincers which I have described for extracting the root, and help with these gestures, whose shape is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let it be slightly thicker so that it holds together, or let it be held with the jaw, and do not let it move or vibrate until the jaw comes out; and restore its place with the suitable medicines for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is putrid pus in bone then scrape it off and cure it until sound.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On the removal of the teeth from the jaw-bone.
Caput XXXII.	Of the dismembering of a tooth from the jaw-bone.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth become dislocated from their natural course, they get foul through the shape of the jaw, especially when it happens to women and girls, that is to say, young.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary for you to consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if one tooth has come after another, and does not fit into its place, or is possible to open it with a file, then scrape it out: and if it is joined with another tooth, then cut it out with this instrument, of which the following is the form.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a little chisel, made of iron, with a sharp end.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And your cut should be deep so that it can go through the bone, and for the hardness of the tooth, and so that another tooth does not move.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If it is exposed by the wear of its own file: then scrape it with a file made of iron, of which the following is the form.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	It should all be made of iron, and its little end pointed with the point of an awl, like a file with which nails are made: and with this the tooth is scraped little by little over several days with ease, so that another tooth does not move, and it falls off: then it is to be smoothed, in the end, scraped with some rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If it is a tooth that breaks off a piece and hurts the tongue: then you must also smooth out this piece, until its roughness has gone, and make it even: and it should be smoothed, so as not to hurt the tongue, or damage the speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Of the retaining of teeth when they are decayed with gold.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33: Of the extraction of teeth when they are decay
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the anterior teeth have a shock or movement by reason of a blow, or accident: and cannot hold firm on them, and they do not taste good after the use of medicines for their relief, then it is clever in them to fasten them with gold wire: because silver becomes yellow, and decayed after a few days: but gold does not change.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let there be a thread medium in fineness and coarseness according to the quantity that it takes between teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the shape of the retention is so that you take the thread and insert it twice its length between two healthy teeth: then you knit it with its two extremities in a thread between the teeth of both parts until you reach the other healthy tooth.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the texture until you reach the side from which you began: and tightly with subtlety and wisdom, until it does not move completely: and let your constriction be where you tighten the thread, near the roots of the teeth, so that it does not move.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the excess ends of the thread with the pincer: and gather both sides, and turn them towards each other: and hide them between the healthy tooth and the moted one so that they do not hurt the tongue: then let it be loosened in such a way that there is left only a small amount.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If however it loosens or cuts, tighten them with another thread and let it stand with it in such a way for a whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of the teeth, and the shape of the retention of two healthy teeth and two moted teeth as you see them.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes, when one tooth falls and heals again in its place, and the retainers remain as we have described, and do not hurt it - this is done only by a skilled, prudent, and experienced artisan.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a bone is broken by a jab: and it is made like the form of a tooth, and put in place, from which it is protected and tightened, as we have said: and remains, and stays with it for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Regarding the incision of the ligament that happens under the tongue, and prevents one from talking.
Caput XXXIIII.	Head 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament that happens under the tongue is either natural with which man is born, or accidental due to an arrow that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation is, so that you open the mouth of the patient on his head in your bosom, and relieve his tongue: then cut this neural ligament across its width, until the tongue is released from its retention.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is something hard and rigid in it and it is a result of injury and the wound is healed: then insert a hook into it and cut across its width until you reach the ligament, and release the rigidity.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And do not make a cut at the bottom of the flesh, and do not cut an artery there, and do not cause blood to flow.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then wash the incision with pink water or vinegar or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a lymph from linen, which holds the sick one every night: so that it does not become consolidated again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if there is blood flow, then place on the spot a lump of dried clay.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if you are pricked by blood, then cauterize the spot with a burning coals, which suits it: then take care of yourself with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	The Extraction of a Wound That Occurs Under the Tongue
Caput XXXV.	Head XXXV
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When a little pustule forms under the tongue that absorbs the small wound, preventing the tongue from its natural function: and perhaps it increases so much, until the bone is filled up.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation is, to open the jaw without pain by the sun: and consider the pustule.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	But if you see that the color of it is dark or black, and hard, and the sick person does not have a feeling: then do not touch it, for it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it declines to whiteness, in which there is moisture, then insert into it a hook, and cut it with a very fine scalpel, and free it from all parts.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If you are pricked by blood during your operation, then place on the spot a lump of dried clay, until the blood stops: and then resume your operation, taking off the skin with its appendages.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then wash with vinegar and salt: and care for that wound with suitable cure until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	¶ On the treatment of abscesses of the two amygdaloids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36. On the treatment of abscesses of the two
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When abscesses occur between the tonsils, that is, glands which resemble abscesses and occur in the jaw: they are called the two amygdaloids; when treated as described in the division, and yet do not heal, then consider.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If then there is an abscess that is hard, of a pale colour, with little sensation: then do not touch the abscess with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is of a red colour, and the root is thick: then do not touch it with iron, fearing that there will be a flow of blood; but leave it, until it has grown dry.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either you pierce it: or it will burst of itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is of a white colour, round, and its root is thin: then the wound should be allowed to bleed.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is such, that you should consider before the operation itself, if its abscess is hot, and has become quiet and complete, or is somehow imminent: then therefore make the person sit in front of the sun, and place his head in your lap: and open the mouth, and let him take hold of the tongue from below with an instrument, which has this form.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or of brass, that it is fine like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When then you press with it on the tongue, and it shows itself to you, falling on your side: then take a hook, and fasten it in the amygdaloid, and pull it out as far as you can, pulling off some of the skin with it.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with an instrument, which has this form following.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It is joined with ligatures: however, its ends are curled up, so that the opening of each of them is on the acute side of the other: wherefore it should be so made of iron, or of a felled skin, that it may absorb.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If it is not present this instrument, then cut it with a chisel, whose this is the shape.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Let it be sharp on one part, not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And having cut one side of the amigdalon, cut the other second to this same form of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision gargle the sick with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if it happens that there is a flow of blood, gargle with water in which the skins of apples are boiled: or leaves of myrtle, and such like from stypics, until the flow of blood has stopped: then take care of the wound, until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when ever there arise in the throat lumps, except two amigdalons.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Then cut them as I said above for the cutting of the two amigdalons.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I too have already treated a woman from an apostematous lump that was born between her throat and which she would put out into froth, little feeling, which had almost closed up her throat: and the woman breathed through my mouth, and had stopped eating, drinking water, and had come close to death, if it had remained one day, or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the lump had risen so much that it had thrown up two sprigs, until they had come out at two holes in the nose.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	So I ran faster, and fixed my hook into one of them.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and a big piece came out with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it off where it was caught in the hole of the nose.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I made it come out of the other hole of the nose.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth, and pressed her tongue: and then I fixed my hook into it: then cut off a part of it, and there was not much blood coming out: so the woman's throat is entirely stopped, and she began to drink water right away, and then took food to eat.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I have ceased to strike at that place for a long time; and the scar which I struck has given way to another, until it was too late and was joined to that one.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I therefore used cautery on the scar between the teeth.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	So it stood firm from the addition; then I walked away from that part, and did not know what God did with it after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the scar of the wound on the mouth.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37 (head)
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When the discharge comes down to the lip, and is scarred, and is long; then it is called a vertical scar; and if it is on the lower part and thick, round, then it is called a mole.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When cauterizing with it as we have said in the division, and the cure does not manifest itself; and you see that the scar has become cold from it, and is thin; then you should strike at it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And what is joined to it that is round and has no length, and is bloody or dark-colored or black, and has no feeling; then you should strike off its scar.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For fear is in the scar on the sick.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	So you should do when you see it like the way I have described from whiteness and its length, so that you set the sick person before the sun; and press his tongue with an instrument which has gone before in narration: then fasten a hook into the lip, and pull it down: and strike it with one or two instruments which I have mentioned in cutting the two palates.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not strike from it, unless it is added to the natural term without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you strike from it any more, you will hurt speech and conversation.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the scar has been struck from it, use that which I have described in cutting the two palates: and take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the sick person trembles from the scar; then you should use your skill in cauterizing it without fear and worry.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	The mode of cautery with her is not, unless with sharp water: and it is, that you put the head of the nurse in your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press her tongue with the instrument which we have said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I have told you in the chapter of cauterizing, and mix it with her foot not extinct, and put it not thick, nor thin, and fill it with this instrument, whose is this shape.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Sit at the end of her where the medicine is placed, as placed on the cochlea of the radius.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on her uvula: and the sick lie on his side, so that the salve comes from her mouth from within the medicine, so that it does not go down from it to his throat, and hurts him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then take your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first put it on her uvula of half-dose hour, until you see it has become blackened, and has calmed its itching with the medicine's mordication.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you want to take the cup and roll it on the end of the radius, and pour the cup with the medicine, and insert the radius with the cup into the tube from above, until it adheres to the uvula.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you get what you want of the new cauterizing.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let go of her: for she will heal and fall after three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	That if you want to drink the medicine, repeat it: and after cauterizing wash around her with a new cup dipped in butter, and clean with it what is in around her from the medicine: and let it sit with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And be cured from outside with embrocations, and inside with gargles, until he is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This then species of cure is more beneficial than the incising and further distant from the fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes it is also cured with a sound that is finer than cautery and incision: for this reason it is cured with suffumigation, in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take sumac, hyssop, oregano, rue, sseah, chamomile, abrotanums, and other herbs like them; put all of these together in a bowl, and add some vinegar and boil it: the pot should be well covered with litter: and there should be an opening in the middle of the pot above which a fine instrument is placed, as follows.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or brass; and the end, in which is the grain, should be inserted into the opening of the tube, until the steam ascends to the edge of the tube, until it is much obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this many times, until it is healed.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And if there is a wound, do not begin this cure at the very beginning.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it adds something to the wound: and you should not do this cure unless it is near the time of the warmth of the wound.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if you do not have this instrument with you, then take a tube and fit a bit of wood to the end of it, so that the smoke does not burn the opening: for the wood prevents the steam from burning; and this is good cure with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Regarding the extraction of spine, and bone from the stomach.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38 (on) surgery.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times an object like a tooth or a spine attached to the stomach, or some other foreign body.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Then, so that what is extraneous to it appears on the surface where the bite has taken place, having pressed the tongue with an instrument at the sun, and shown you what is inside,
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which does not appear to you, or is hidden in the stomach, must be taken out before the food is digested in the stomach: for this will be effective with health.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps, however, it will come out through the bile.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	He should swallow the end of a rope, or the root of a lettuce, or chew dry bread; or he should take the end of a sea sponge that is dry and soft; and bind it with a string, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore he has come to the place where there are spines or an oss, and is drawn out, then he goes out.
