Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	But if he does not go out with it as I have said: then use the instrument of lead in this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius somewhat, and let there be a curved end at its end, which he may introduce into his throat with ease: and let him hold his head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware that he does not touch his epiglottis with his tongue, so that it should not give rise to a cough, and drive out the bone or the spine, or introduce the medicine into himself with his own hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But as for the sick person who is to be examined, this is better: through his knowledge of the site of the wound; and let him push below, or lift up his hand with the instrument upwards, all this according to the quantity that has been prepared for him, until he has gone out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of Blood-Sucker.
Caput XXXIX.	CHAPTER XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When you are treating with the blood-sucker, and he does not yield, consider whether there is a sore throat before the sun, or after it, when you press his tongue with the instrument that I have told you of.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	But if your yawning falls on the blood-sucker, extract it with a small hook, or with subtle movements, and turn away from it.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if it is not possible with them: then take a tightly-coiled tube, and introduce it into the throat as far as the throat; and then introduce into the coiled tube an iron that is ignited with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Make this many times over: and let the sick person refrain from all water for a whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full wash with cold water and open his mouth into it; and let him put his own jaw into it and swallow nothing from it; and let him moisten the water with his hand for an hour after another.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For a frog immediately falls when he feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not leave with him as we have said, then let him smoke the sick with ants or with an axe as a tool that we have used in smoking with it.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, because he will fall himself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in smoking is that you take a pot in which are fire-roasted frog legs and cover it with a lid, and make a hole in that lid, and fix the end of the tool in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the smoking, and let him put his own jaw on the end of the tube, and close it so that he does not come out from smoking until you know that smoking has reached the frog.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For a frog immediately falls.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If he does not fall, then repeat the smoking many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the sick appetite endure, and eat sauce and other things, and do not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is therefore necessary that he should go out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the tool from which the frog is taken out of its throat when it falls on it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like a claw, as you see: unless because of the agility that enters into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And the end of it is like an egg-shaped bird called a kikonis, in which there is a sharpness of chisel: and when it catches anything, does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Regarding the opening of the Apotomates, and its sectioning, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many species of Apotomates, many ways, according to the memory of them, that is to say, one, and there is one in this book: and they differ in their perforation, and in the cutting of them from two kinds.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	There is one from the species of aphemia within itself, and because it comprehends from the humidity.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is because of the places, in which it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For aphemia happens in the head, it is different from the accident of aphemia in the anus; and the aphemia that happens in a fleshy place, it is different from the accident of aphemia in joints; and each of them has its own judgment according to the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from the aphemia are those that do not need to pierce, unless they have matured blood in them, and its completion; and from these are those that need to pierce when they are raw, and do not mature according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As aphemia that is near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when aphemia happens nearby a joint and its length is prolonged until it rots what is around it, perhaps the ligaments rot, or the nerve of that joint: so it is the cause of the closer contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or is an aphemia in a main member; for if you delay the piercing of it until it matures, it will hurt or damage it or through that main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or is nearby a nail, so pierce it when it is immature: and do not need to pierce, the raw aphemia, that is not complete digestion, unless it is nearby a nail, lest it rot deeply, and extends to the inside of the anus, and becomes a fistula, or forms in its term that does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You need to know the time of piercing the aphemia, that is mature according to its completion; and it is at the rest from pain, the withdrawal of fever, and the decrease of redness, and pulsation, and the sharpness of the head of the aphemia: and the other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you need to make the same piercing in the lower place of the aphemia, and more prominent; and let the piercing go in the length of the body, if the aphemia is in the parts of the hand and foot, and the places of the fingers, and the chords, and the nerves, and the arteries, and up to the last in all equal places, where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	And in those that are reflected, go with the perforation to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When, however, there is a hematoma in fleshy places: then it is better that you should desist from perforating it until its digestion has been confirmed as we have said according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, the course of the virus will be prolonged from it, and there will be much pus and corruption, and perhaps the lips will become thicker, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some hematomas are perforated according to the width of the body in case of necessity: or according to that by which the member is stretched.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small perforation in small hematomas and a wide perforation in large hematomas: or sections of different sizes of hematomas.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are hematomas from which the skin must be closed together: and it happens when it has already been done like a cloth, and has reached its term, for it is dead: such as happened to many, such as the poultices, and boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are those that cut off by section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there is one in which it incises like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like a hematoma of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are those in which a round section is administered, and a lunar section: and similar ones from sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	In fact, in those that have no head, such as are the small superficial hematomas, it is necessary to pierce them with a superficial perforation, or simply flat.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary that when the hematoma is thick, and has already gathered a lot of blood, you pierce it so that it does not flow out and throw all of it out at once: but take off a part from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then dust the hematoma until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then remove some pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Then do this many times according to the degree, until it comes out: especially if it is a weak animal, or a pregnant woman, or a young boy, or an old man: for the animal spirit often dissolves from the animal with the exit of blood: and perhaps the sick one dies, and you don't notice it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Then this chapter therefore with great care.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have made the incision, as you make those incisions that are in front of you, it is necessary that you wipe away the sweat: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	But if there is a small wound in front of the incision, or it is a flat section, then he should administer a liniment made from linen, or an old poultice.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a large wound, and there are many holes made by the incision, then he should put liniment into all the cracks, until they are closed up together.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off part of the skin in the wound, or if it has been torn around the circumference: then he should fill it with an old poultice, or as when the fabric is smooth, or is rubbed with a layer of hair without moisture: and tighten him up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then you should pour it out, and care for that with him as you need to from an ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if blood flows in your hour of operation, then he should administer cold water, and vinegar, after it is soaked up by a cloth: and you should place him over the site of the flow many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flow of blood persiste, then he should administer a regime, and cure, and powders, which I have narrated in many places of our book, and from a division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the time of winter, and the location of the wound has many nerves: then you should pour in powders with wine, and hot oil: and place them on the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer, and the places are fleshy: then you should pour in powders soaked in water, and oil, or in wine and oil, and all of that cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then you should remove the wound, and wipe him clean, and administer to him whatever cure is appropriate for him, until he heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is why it is necessary to know about the treatment of different types of wounds universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	However, as for the halfway point of the distinction, I have already said regarding all kinds of wounds, how to treat each one separately.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	[On the section dealing with wounds that occur on the scalp.]
Caput XLI.	[Head]
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Wounds that occur on the scalp are small, and they are of two kinds: nods, which are surrounded by a membrane, which is like a bag for them; as if they were little hens' nests.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these wounds.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of these wounds, some are small; and of these wounds, there are those that contain moisture similar to lime; and of these wounds, there is moisture similar to rain and pus; and there are similar ones, and among these there are hard stones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the cutting of all of them, nor is there any danger in their extraction, provided that you do not make any difference when cutting at the site of the wound itself, where the arteries are opposed.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation on these wounds is that you test it with an instrument, whose form has come after these things, which is called the "intromission", until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if that is what contains moisture, then dry up the section at right angles to the surface of the wound: in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin the cutting from line B to line G. When therefore the moisture is drained out, then remove the skin that contains that moisture, and do not leave any of it behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Many times it will return if some of it remains.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then dip the cloth in Egyptian ointment if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill it with oil, and leave it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	That ointment will corrode what remains of the skin.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the application of the Egyptian ointment a second and third time, and if you find it tolerable, until you are confident that nothing remains in the skin, then, since you are comfortable with it, apply the oil with ointment, until the wound heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the abscess contains a pimple: then dry it up according to this form, having the section in the form of a cross; and throw away the hooks between the clefts of the section, and scrub it off entirely; and try your skill in extracting the tunica that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if it contradicts you, then do as I shall tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And also do the same in an abscess, if it is rocky, from the section, and cure in the same way, as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section on a rocky abscess is easier: for there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes some of these abscesses are in the head of certain men, where there is no moisture within.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I followed on an abscess in the head of a married woman, and found it like a solid stone hard, sharp, white, which could not be broken: and if anyone struck it with a punch, he wounded the flesh.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other abscesses of accidents in the head, aside from these abscesses that occur in the heads of boys, and at the roots of the ears, all of them are superficial sections.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or put a hole in them always from their lower part, that the course of the juice may run to the bottom.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then take care for these with what is fitting when they are cured.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the section of Strophulus in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Head 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur in the neck, and under the cheeks, and in the groin, and sometimes in the whole body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And above those which occur from them in the neck, there is one kind, and many: and they spring from a common source; and all Strophulus comes from its own tunica, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the kinds of Strophulus are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these are the leaves; and from these are those that retain moisture; and from these are the evil ones, which do not obey cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	For from these are the leaves; and from these are those that retain moisture; and from these are the evil ones, which do not obey cure.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is on guard that it should not strike the vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let it not be sharp; so that it should not cause your hand to tremble or trouble you in any way, and let you fall down, for this is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you strike a vein or an artery, or prevents you from carrying out the operation, then put a wooden stake and some powder that stops the blood, and tighten the stake and let go of it, until the edge of the wound has healed, and the wood has become soft: or else it begins to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is stopped by powder; so that you can put yourself back in the preparation for your work, until you are finished with it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your index finger whether there is anything left of the stitches; so that you can cut them off and clean them out.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If there is a large vein at the base of the stitch; then it should not be cut from its root; but it should be tied with strong thread and let go until it falls out by itself without doing any harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the stitch with old cotton that you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for the wound.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole stitch has been cut, then you should collect two leaves of the wound; and clean it immediately, as soon as you see that there is no excess remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there is excess because of the size of the stroma, then it is necessary that you understand to cut off its root and extract it: and administer the suture which we have mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And which of the stroma contains moisture, pierce it with a superficial puncture: so that you see the place of maturity of it: and put the puncture from there because it follows below the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then, after the puncture, administer the licking with ointment and similar things so that it corrupts what remained from corruption, until when you see the scar already healed: then take care of it with a generate ointment of flesh, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	§ On the section of the epiglottis from the hernia inside the throat by accident.
Caput XLIII.	CHAPTER XLVIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancient ones said that this section of the epiglottis, and no one in our land has done it, and this is a writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have a synachium, the section of the epiglottis should be removed: not to do it because of the following thing: for all nostrils and lung are feeble.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those, however, who have a hot hernia in the mouth or throat or both the walnuts, when there is no disease in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the epiglottis, to avoid the destruction that is done by pre-condensation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary, therefore, when we want to do that thing, that we remove the epiglottis under a circle of the epiglottis, or four, small section by its length, which is the section in the sifil, not in the cartilage: and this place is suitable for the section, because it is separated from flesh, and the blood vessels are far away from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the doctor is a timid one, then it is necessary that he extends the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he finds the skin, until when it reaches to the canal: remove the blood vessel, if he sees any from it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut away the skin that we have described: and it signifies upon the section of the canal from the phlegm which comes out of it, with that which is cut off, and the ablation of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the raw area be left open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the place is moved by the hour, in which there is a fear of hernia, the two lips of the wound of the skin are gathered together and are sutured alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines that make the flesh grow again until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Says Albucasis. The summary of this speech that we have described is an exposition, unless it is clear that one of these lumps has already been drained by the throat being infected: and the sick person has risen up higher than death, and his hernia has grown larger between the larynx and the windpipe, so that he can breathe more freely, and save himself from death: and for this reason they have ordered to leave the lump open, until the malice of the illness is consumed, and it is a malice of three days, and almost the same: then they order to put a lump on it, and to take care of him, until he is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw myself, that a servant took a knife, and put it into his throat, and cut off with it a part of the canal of the lung.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure him, and I found it gurgling, as it is the sound of a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore took away from the lump, and I found blood that was coming out of the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I therefore confessed, that he had not cut off any part, nor sewed it up: and the wind came out from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore took away the lump, and I cured him, until he was well: and there happened to the servant nothing, except that his voice became hoarse: and after a few days he recovered to better health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Thus I say: for there is no fear in the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	De the section of the hernia of the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter LXXIV.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This hernial growth, named hernia of the throat, is a large one, second in size only to the color of the body; and it occurs frequently in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it has two causes: either it is natural or, on the other hand, it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly there is no talent in the natural one.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental one, on the other hand, has two causes; one is similar to the nodules and pus, and the other is...
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode, is similar to an aphtem that is formed from the knotting of a blood vessel.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is a fear in it; and one should not dare to make an incision on it unless it is small; and you should test it and investigate it with the probe.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then the aphem is similar to a large nodule and is not suspended with any veins: then dry it up as you do nodules; and take it out with it if it is contained in a sack, for if it is not, then inspect it all over.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with what needs to be done in curing, until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	De the section on the types of nodules.
Caput XLV.	Chapter L.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many types of nodules, and I have already spoken about their various types; and it is necessary for me to describe the difference between a nodule and an excrescence when there is doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, then, that when there is heat and fever and acute pain, until effusion subsides and putrefaction is complete; for then the fever and the heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But when there is no heat or fever or pain, and they are contained in sacks of their own sinuses, which are like beans, and resemble a plumskin, and are larger and smaller: this is how nodules begin.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two species: either they are thin: or they retain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I have said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you apply the poultice to the wound, so that you may feel it and examine it, use the instrument called the intromissor first, according to what will come about from its form in the following chapter.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of examining abscesses and all kinds of boils is, when you take this instrument, to introduce it into a moist place which you have made in the abscess: and you shall move your fingers with it slowly, until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then take the last hand according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove the intromissor, and see what comes out into the hole.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore it comes out running with moisture, whatever its color is: then dry him by a superficial cut, as I have said for the rest of the abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if the intromissor does not bring out moisture in the hole, then you will know that it is fat: so dry him over the top with a V-shaped cut, according to this shape, as I have taught you: and suspend it by hooks, and scrape off the skin from all parts with ease: and if you can keep a box over it, so take out the healthy flesh with a nodule.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the skin ruptures during the operation, and it is not possible to take out the healthy flesh, often because this happens: then take it away hastily, until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if there remains a little or much of it, the nodule returns according to most of them.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	For if it hurts you, and there remains a little of it: then fill the wound with some powdered caustic substance sharp: and tighten the poultice, and place it over the abscess that sits warm, and take care of the rest of the wound with the usual cure, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then there is a large knot, then cut it in two, and take care that what is incorporeal remains with it.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however you have a new swelling that pulsates, or does not pulsate: then approach it and fill the space with three-fold powder, and leave it strict for two days, or three, until the pus has putrefied and the fever has subsided: then return to incision of what is left from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	¶ Of external instruments for section and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter LVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From these are the forms of intromissions, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For there is a large one, and there is a medium one, and there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let there be made of iron four-squared extremities deviated, so that they may make the entrance into an apotome.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of exsertions, and there is one, that is to say, piercing: and it is of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	Let them be made to project through the apotomes, and the exits, and the tubes, and the abscesses from him who is between them of the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, and sharp, and smooth, such as the large needles with which the backs of the ears are pierced, made of citrine, or of brass, or of iron, or of silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better ones are those made of citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And there are also exsertions of black lead which are made to project so that the tubes may be examined by it; for with its softness they reflect with mildness to themselves those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again they are of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For there are long ones, and medium ones, and short ones, according to the quantity of the width of the tube and its strictness.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Form of the coracoi, and they are of many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For they are simples, that is to say, those in which there is one length: and they are of three species as you see, great, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And out of these are the blind Vincess: and they are of three species.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And out of these are the hooks having two lengths, and they are of three species: and out of these are the hooks having three lengths, and they are of three species: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the shapes of Scalpels, with which they cut and scarify nodes and abscesses: and they are of three species: for out of these is great, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which they make the section are acute, other extremities are not acute: and they are not placed so, unless it is done with them that makes incision in a nodule out of fear of wound of the skin, or in a nerve: and to heal him who is ill through the heat which he has received less than that which heals by scarification of abscesses.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the magdas, and they are of three species.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of brass, and they are similar to the wire by which is made the alcohol: and in the long end there is a concealed pin-head: and in it runs towards the inside, and towards the outside when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the pin-head which is concealed between the fingers at the perforation of abscesses: and do not feel it with the touch: and they are of three species, great, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of Wind-pockets with which the flow of blood is cut off: and they are of three species, great, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of brass, or of copper, round, a little long, as you see: and let them be delicate.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And let these species of wind-pockets be with you great, and small: that you may cut off the blood with them at speed when you are in need, and then when medicine is not present with you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	Indeed, you should not use them for ablation of blood in any part of the body, and you should not use them unless in meaty places: such as the legs, pelvis, arms, breasts, palms, ankles, and similar, from meaty places, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when they are made from them small instruments like the blade of a chisel, in accordance with their shape: which ablate blood when it flows from a phlebotomy site, or at a cut to a vein or artery: and sometimes they are made round in this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Now concerning the care of the mammary glands in men which resemble the mammary glands of women:
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 57: The Care of the Breast
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When and if the breasts of some men swell at the time of sleep (that is, as they begin to become erect in sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and remain soft to the touch.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever then dislikes this, should tie a bandage over the breasts with the moon shape, according to this form from a line, to a line, and so on. And then scrape the whole of the swelling.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill up the breasts with an ointment made from the ink of the murex shell.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then attach two strips of skin to the nipples with a stitch, and look after it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the nipple sways downward and softens because of its size, as is the case with women: then let it be found in its two sides on top in two sections like the moon shape, and each one is held by another at the ends like this line from a line to line, g. Then scrape the skin that is between the two lips, and remove the swelling, and apply what we have said about the stitch and the powders, which is necessary in the treatment, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however you do not like the incision that needs to be made on it because of the unease of the disease or the flow of blood: then let you fill the breasts with a submerged cotting ointment that is corrosive, and let go of them, until what remains of the swelling is corroded.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then the care for him, until he is healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Regarding the perforation of the abscess, which occurred during the reign of Titus.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 58.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur during the reign of Titus are of a hard species of staph, which contains blisters and from them emerge fluid.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Since these are of the type that contains moisture, they should be cut open with a lunar section, according to this form, from line B to line G; and when all that is in the abscess has been drained out of its fluid, then fill it with old skin, and leave it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the dressing is removed, and care is taken with the ointment suited to it, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the species of nodules of the staph, then cut it over the top, as we have said in the section on how to cut staphylae equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if it extends a knuckle, so that it spits out pus, then administer cauterization to it, as we have said in the preceding passage.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Regarding the section of an abscess that occurs due to an artery or a vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 59.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is interrupted and the skin that is above it hardens, it often occurs that a abscess develops there: and likewise it happens with veins, so that a abscess and swelling occur there.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and swelling are due to an artery or a vein are these: for when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long and gathered in the depths of the body; and when you press your fingers upon the abscess, you feel as if there were a hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round in appearance on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section upon this abscess is an error, especially if it is under the armpits, and in the groin, and on the neck, and in many other places of the body; and it is great to a remarkable degree.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, so that his care may be with iron, and that which is also from them in the extremities, or in the head, let it be made.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	So therefore, since it is from them, that which is from the inflammation of the opening of the artery, find on the skin in a section in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with the hook, then the artery: and free it from the tunics, until it is detected.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce it under it, and let it penetrate as far as another side, and tighten the artery with a double thread at two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of two arteries which are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then pierce the place, which is between the two ligaments with a scalpel, until all the blood that is in it comes out, and dissolve the hematoma.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure which generates pus, until the ligaments fall: then treat that with ointments suitable for it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is a hematoma because of the section of a vein, then you must hold your hand so that you can get it from the hematoma with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce the hook under the place which you held with your hand, and let it penetrate: and let it be in it a double thread, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with it the hematoma with a good ligament: according as I told you in binding a ligament, from the two parts with the two extremities of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you should suppose that a thread is to be extracted, then introduce another hook with another thread under the hematoma from all around the incision of the hook: press, and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry up the hematoma in its middle, until when it comes out what is in it: then make an incision on the skin, and let go what was tied from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on the top a little wool which you immersed in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the cure, which is done with liniments and unguents, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	That which happens from a twist of the neck.
Caput L.	The head.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As has happened with the artery and vein, so has also happened with the nerves: which has happened from a beating, or from excessive work, and in like manner: and it is very useful for them in places of support, or heel, and in any place where the ligaments move: and it is a dark spot.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It resembles the color of the rest of the body, and is present in many dispositions without pain: and when it is held with a vibratory movement, it feels in it a similar stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And is not an aggregate pustule under the skin, but lies beneath the skin, and moves itself to all parts, and does not affect toward the front, or before, nor behind:
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	That which then is present in the ligaments does not need to be pricked with a needle.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps, however, it may happen that contraction occurs:
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that, however, which is present in the head or forehead, find skin with a bristle.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If then it is a small pustule, then hold it with tweezers and cut it off at the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then hang it by a hook and scrub it off: then remove it, and add the suture: and care for it, until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the cutting of the pustules, which happens in the belly.
Caput LI.	The head.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	To some people often happens again and again in their bellies, and in the rest of their bodies, a kind of fungi, which they call "fungii", on account of the similarity of these to fungi.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root of these is fine, and their heads are thick, and their lips are turned down.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there are some who grow very large: and there are some who become very thin.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I have already seen a man, and within his abdomen there were two small things, which were greater than other similar fungi: there was no difference between them, white, with minute roots, and their lips were intertwined, and they ended, and moisture always ran out of them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	So I have cut them open, and I found in weight one as if ten and eight ounces and the other as if six ounces; And the operation of cutting them is so that you consider then, if he is weak, moist, and the color of the fungus is white, moist, with a thin root: Then cut him with a broad chisel, and let cauterization be in your presence on fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For many times blood is discharged during the incision: so then if you are overcome by blood, then cauterize him.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	That if you see him weak, trembling because of the incision with iron, then take a wire made from lead that is made to waver, and hold it with him: whose way is what we have said, and let him go after two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the constriction of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	So do not cease to constrict lead, whenever it presses on the fungus, until it is cut off, and falls of itself without work.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If the fungus is large in root, then there is some fear and trembling in the incision: especially since it is in the abdomen.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible that you cut off half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize him, so that he does not shed.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the wound, until it heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not suspect that the fungus which is of a dark color, little sense, and an appetizing appearance: for it is an ulcerous cancer: and I come with a remembrance of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the care of the eminence of the umbilicus.
Caput LII.	Head II.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Emancipation of the umbilicus is due to various causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	It comes out from the fissures that are above the navel: and it issues forth from it, either as anus or intestine, according to what happens in the other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from the blood that flows out of a vein, or from an artery, according to what has been said above.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the windiness confined within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if, on the other hand, it comes out through a fissure that is sifac, and the discharge is dirty: then it is like the color of bloody pus: and it is slimy, without pain: and it seems to be in different locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if, on the other hand, it is because of the exit of the intestine: then its site is with that which we have described, more varied in character.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you press it with your fingers, it is hidden: but then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it makes a lot of noise at the entrance to the wind, and a rumbling noise.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if, on the other hand, it is because of humidity, it is slimy, then it does not hide when you press it with your hand, nor does it become tighter, nor does it get added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If, on the other hand, it is because of blood, then with these signs appears a swelling that turns black at the edge.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is because of a born flesh: then it is a grayish, thick, hard swelling, and it forms one unit in quantity.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if it is because of windiness, then the touch of it is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in it is this: if you note that the prominent umbilicus is because of blood from an artery, or vein, or windiness: then you should refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is danger and fear in it, as I taught you in the chapter where I said that swelling comes because of an artery or vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominent umbilicus is because of an intestine or a hernia: then you should order the sick person to hold his breath and stand with his arms extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then the signs with caustic around the navel of the whole.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to lie down on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround the navel with a hot iron knife at the place you marked with caustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle part of the skin from above, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him tightly around the navel with a strong thread or silk cord: and let the knot of the tied cord be attached.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle part of the skin that has been extended above the ligment.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you have already found the navel caught on the ligment: then remove the ligment and push it into the navel with the index finger: and if there is a hernia, then take it with the hook and cut off its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the opposite side is a blood vessel or an artery: then surround it very much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then turn to your own operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and introduce two strong threads into them: and introduce the two needles around the one you have made around the swelling in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the swelling at four places on the needles: and if there is a vein, remove the needle, and let it rest until the flesh has rotted away: and let it fall of itself: or cut it off when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the swelling with the ointment as needed until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	That if the prominence of the navel is from flesh inside or from moisture: then you should seal up the swelling, as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out the blood, or the moisture that has entered it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of the swelling to make the place solidify.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Of the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken at some length about the types of cancer and how to treat it with medicine: and how to beware of treating it with iron so that it does not ulcerate: and we spoke about cancer generated in the womb, and about caution in its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said, that whenever cancer is at a place where its eradication is possible: such as cancer that is in the breast, or in the thigh, and those similar to it, from the member located to extract all of it: especially when it is beginning to parous.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When, however, the cancer has been long established, and is great, it is not necessary that you approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I cannot heal from it myself: nor did I see anyone else who has recovered from it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in it, when it is located as we have said, is, as it were, to go before and to loosen the sick from black cholera sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then phlebotomy itself if it is with evident swelling of the venes.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick with preparation, in which he is located with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw into the cancer the hooks that suit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then wrap up the whole with skin, according to the examination, until there is nothing left of its roots: and let not the blood flow, and do not tear it away quickly, except you express the places, and wipe off the gross blood entirely by hand, or with whatever is possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, the opposite makes you flow of gross blood from the incision of an artery or a vein: then cauterize the vein until the blood is separated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cancer with the remaining cure, until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	§ On curative hydropesis.
Caput LIIII.	CHAPTER LII. ON THE TREATMENT OF WATER IN THE B
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	I have spoken so far on the division of species of hydropesis and how the aggregation of water is made: and the signs of each species, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And those that are cured by iron do not approach except a single species of asclepius: and does not approach the iron of the hyposarcis species: for this is deadly.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you had begun to treat with this species of hydropesis as a tympanic with medicines, and your treatment did not succeed: then reflect.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	If the disease has already advanced and there is a concomitant weakness or other infirmity besides hydropisis: as if there is a cough with him, or a loosing of the eye, and things like these: then beware that you do not meddle with him with iron: for there is fear in this.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a person with an abundance of vigor and strength who is not sick except for hydropisis: and he is not a boy, nor an old man: then the method of operation in him is, that you stand him between your hands, and let him squirt the fluid from his hand toward the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a small piece of wood with thorns, shaped like this.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Set the two sharp ends, one long, and the acute extremity like a sputumile.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	But in him there should be something that opens gradually, so that you do not harm him with the operation up to the intestine, and you leave him alone.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the generation of hydropisis is from the part of the intestines, then it should be extended with a section of three fingers' length from the navel directly below the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if the generation of hydropisis is due to liver disease: then your section should be on the left from the navel by three fingers' length.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the generation of it is due to the spleen, then your section should be on the right side: and it should not also be that the sick person lies on his back, so that fluids do not run to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce the skin with a tool all around.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then introduce into that section, and squeeze with your hand with the sputumile between the skin, and rub it as if you were cleaning him out: and let the amount that is squeezed be the amount of a nail, or around that area.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce the skin until the sputumile reaches a vacuum spot: and that is a place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract the flesh, and insert an instrument into this opening.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is similar to a tube: it is made from silver, or brass, or gold, or linden wood, or tin: and in its lower part there is a small opening, and on the sides of it there are three openings, two on one side, and one on the other side: and the end of it should be sharpened according to the way that a penknife is sharpened, as you see; and at the top of its end there is an armlet.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches the water, it descends immediately on top of the instrument; therefore it drains from the water at a medium rate of quantity.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	For if you drain from it more than is necessary, perhaps a weak person may die through the loss of his animal spirit: or something may happen to him that approaches death.
