Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then suit two places of oozing out on the end of the ray from the syph, and join them with a stitch one to the other: then take away the end of the ray.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not at all touch the syph, nor pull out any one, nor any other, as I have told you in the cure for intestinal worms.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then the cure for this cure of a wound.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have cut the thread, then clean it out, and restore the bone, until it has been hardened.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	The thread is broken, and no oozing out is added to the rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cauterium is better in this place: because it is nearer to salvation.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	Regarding the softening of the skin of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of the testicles is sometimes softened in some people, because the flesh that is between them becomes softened, and its appearance is changed.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who asks to be cured of it, that he lie on his back, and incise all the softened skin over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then join the two lips together with a stitch: and if the eye, first of all, excess skin is softened by three or four stitches, and a firm stitch.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then open between the stitches.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then care for the cure of the other wounds, until they are healed, and let the threads drop off.
¶ De Castratione.	§ On castration.
Caput LXIX.	Head 99.
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is excommunicated by our law; and for that reason it would be well if I should not remember it in my book here; and the remembering of it is not necessary except for two reasons.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Of which one is, that it may be in the knowledge of the physician when he is questioned about it: and so that he may know how to cure him who has had it happen to him.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other mode is that we often lack castration of certain animals for our own benefit through it, such as goats, horses, and cats, and similar from animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say then, that castration is done according to two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by friction.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by a slits and sections.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In that which is done by friction the course of operation is this: that we make the animal sit in warm water until his testicles become soft and loosen and hang down: then we strike them with our hand until they are completely broken and do not appear under the touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration however by a slit and sections, you must hold the animal, and press the skin of his testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie the suspenders and dry completely on all one section, until when the two balls come out: then open them after you have dried them both, and do not let slip anything except the thin skin, which is over the scrotum.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this mode of castration is better than that which is done by friction: for friction may leave some of the testicles behind, so that the animal desires to have sex.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Heal then the fracture until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	The treatment for hermaphroditism has two methods.
Caput LXX.	Chapter LXX.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	(Hermaphrodite is from a single testicle according to two modes.)
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	(The male is from one testicle because it seems to follow a gap, or on the skin of the testes, between the two testes, in the form of a small woman, with hair: and sometimes urine flows from it from the skin of the testes.)
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	(But in women there is one form, and it is a small woman over the skin of the breast like a small testicle of the penis completely, prominent to the outside: of which one is like a penis of a man, and two like two testes.)
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	(And the treatment of three forms, two of a male and one of a female, is this: because you must burn away the added flesh, until you remove the impression of them.)
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then heal these wounds with care.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	(As for the second form of men, from which urine flows on the skin of the testes, there is no operation or cure at all.)
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On the cutting of tenting and prominent flesh in women's genitals:
Caput LXXI.	Chapter LXXI.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	(The tenting should perhaps be added to the natural part until it is well fed and ugly in appearance; and sometimes becomes enlarged in certain women so much that it resembles a penis, and reaches up to the bed.)
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	(So you should hold back the excess of the tenting by hand, or with a hook, and cut it down; and not finally in the cutting, especially in the deep root: lest there be an outflow of blood.)
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then heal this wound with care until it heals.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	(But the central flesh is that which is born in the womb of the mother until it fills itself up: and perhaps comes out to the outside according to the similarity of a tail: and for this reason certain call it sickly tail.)
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary that we cut into it as we did with Tentigine, and treat it until it heals.
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	On the treatment of a torn and unperforated hernia in a woman.
Caput LXXII.	Chapter LVII. On the treatment of a torn and unperforated h
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	Hernia Alratica is either in a woman or a small hole.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	and it may be either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	Accidental is due to an earlier illness and may itself be either of native growth added, or a small thread-like substance, or a lump: it may be in the depths of the lake, or in its sides, or in its upper part, or in its lower part; and it prohibits coitus and fertilization, and childbirth, and perhaps menstruation.
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And the knowledge of this is obtained by the examination of midwives, if the swelling is apparent and near.
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If it is not apparent, then seek it with your fingers or a ray of light.
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If the swelling is caused by a small thread-like substance and is near to the two lips: then bring them together, and unravel it.
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is, as if you place two lips on a pair of woolen balls.
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then put your fingers from both hands together, and let the woman lie on her back with her legs spread wide.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then open the two lips firmly, until the small thread-like substance is unravelled and the swelling opens.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then take a piece of wool, dip it in oil, and place it on the spot; and let the woman sit for all day so that the spot does not harden by other force.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If the thread-like substance is thick and dense: then it is necessary to separate it with a flat leaf of myrtle similar to a spatulum.
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If the swelling is of native growth, then suspend it with a hook and cut it: and let there be with you medicines that will stop the flow of blood without biting, such as acacia and dragon's blood, and such aggregate with alum and chalk.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then administer a large pipe from lead, so that the ulcer does not heal quickly, hold it for a few days: and administer lymph from dry linen, then cure the rest with the remaining cure, until it is healed.
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when ever a birth takes place in the womb of the mother there are births of other creatures; therefore they should take place according to this method: so that there is no contrario between iron and cancerous tumor, for cancer is not born in the womb with an opposite relationship to iron at all.
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	On the treatment of hemorrhoids, Athelyl and Bochor's red rash on the genitals of women.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter LIII.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	The hemorrhoids are an opening of the anal orifices, from which much blood runs frequently.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	Now when the hemorrhoids have been long, they become thorns; and I have already, in the division of their species and the signs thereof, said here that which receives the cure, and that which does not.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, therefore, that the hemorrhoids which are in the opening of the womb, and do not appear to be sensible: then there is no cure for them with iron.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	But those which are out of the womb, above which there is a sense, are those which are cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary that you should put the woman into a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then extend Athelyl with forceps or with a rough cloth, and cut them from their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then dust them over with a powder at the flow of blood from one that has been cut without mortifying it: as acacia and dragon's blood, and thistle, and such like to it.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then push her feet against the wall for an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her into cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the flow of blood persists: then make her sit in a decoction of sumach, and cutlar root, and gall, and such like.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take flour of barley, and make it into a paste with honey and vinegar, and make a ointment with it for her back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If then blood is cut with it, it is good; and if not, let the back wound heal with a furrow and without scarification.
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take a cloth and soak it in taraxacum juice, or arnica juice, or oak sap juice, that is, without taste, with Pontic wine, and let the back wound heal.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When then the apotheosis has subsided, then take care of the place with ointment, until it is healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Albarth is actually similar to red caps and is rough in appearance.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore let it be known what appears from it, according to which I said in the litil equal: and take care of it, until it is healed.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Regarding the exit that happens in the womb.
Caput LXXIIII.	Head 74.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	In the womb there are many kinds of apotheosis, such as cancer, and a hard apotheosis, and sores, and blisters, and scabs, and worms, and warts, and roughness, and hot apotheosis.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I have already said all these diseases and their kinds, and their signs, and their cures, in a division: it is necessary for me to say in this book about hot apotheosis which happens in the womb, when it is from apotheosis that collect blood, and to know how its opening takes place with iron.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore let it be known.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	Then if the pain of apotheosis in its beginning is acute with its percussion, and flame, and fever: and you see it red: if it falls on top of itself, then do not like the opening of it: and take care of it with him so that he may please on maturation, until when it has subsided acuity of accidents.
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then let the woman sit on a seat that she may touch two chairs, and lean back, or lie down on her back, and put her feet towards the lower side of her body: and let her legs be spread out, and let her arms rest under her knees, and let her bind each leg with a binding that suits it.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the midwife sit to the right rear, and let her administer the instrument with which she opens the womb's orifice.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose form came to those who are behind.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary when you administer this instrument that you hold it with the arm's depth towards the woman's womb, so that the thing that enters from the instrument does not enter more than the depth of the womb and hurts the weak one.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	But if the instrument is more than the depth then it is necessary that you put the pulley on top of the depth of the womb so that the introduction of the instrument into all of the womb is prevented; and it is necessary that you hold the instrument, and turn back the pulley, which runs in the instrument, from the upper side: and that he holds the instrument, and turns back the pulley, until the womb'
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	So when it appears that it is coming out, and touches the hand, and is soft and smooth: then you must separate it from its head with a smooth edge.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	So when the pus is drained then you must put the licinus, which has been dipped in rose oil', in the oil of violet", and put the licinus, and take out a piece from the depth of the womb.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And put the outside on top of the womb, and on the woollen cloth, which has been dipped in water, in which the salt has been boiled.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then he will take care after two days with the ointment that suits it, until it heals up.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the womb is washed and the scar is so that it can be cleansed with water and honey: then he will return to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	Which if the scar is hidden inside the womb then it is necessary to prevent its cure with fire, indeed take care of itself with what we have said in division.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Doctrines of obstetrics, how they treat the fetus of a woman, according to the form that is not natural for the exit.
Caput Lxxu.	Head 76.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the obstetrician to recognize the natural puerperal form at first.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	From the signs then, it is that when you see a woman compressing herself from below and wanting to smell the air and relieve herself because she feels the baby's exit on her, then you know that this birth is in the natural form, and its exit is above her head and with it the second, or suspended from the navel.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When then you see these signs, so it is necessary for the womb to compress, that the baby may descend quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when he has descended above his head, the second has descended with him, and it is cleansed from it with good purgations.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	But if this birth is not like that, it is unnatural, unworthy of praise.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the baby has come out of his feet, and the body has come out in front of his head, and his feet and hands are one, or his foot or hand is: or when his head and hands have come out: or when the womb has come out: and perhaps it turns over on its neck, and similar signs that cannot be praised.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is therefore necessary for the obstetrician to be prudent and cautious in all these matters, and to beware of error and deception: and I show you all the figures from them, and how the mind works in it, and signals it through it, and calls out on it.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the baby has come out of his head with his natural exit, and he becomes heavy on the woman, and her birth is difficult, and you see her strength failing already: then make her sit down on a chair, or let women support her: and sprinkle her with fenugreek tea, and with wet oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the obstetrician will introduce his finger between her fingers a small spittle, and find with him the second, and dry it up with his nail until it is clean, and press the woman's womb, until the baby has come out.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it has not come down, then a woman should be made to spit out the foamgrape mucus with sesame oil.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then order her to compress herself after the enema, and have her sneeze with a condescending tone, and hold her nose and mouth for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	For fear that the fetus will come out at once.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	What if two hands of the fetus come out first, then it is necessary that you reduce them with ease gradually.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If she does not obey when led into, then place the woman on a chair, and raise her feet up: then push the chair down on the ground: and let the woman hold on, so that she does not fall by the jolt.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If then the hands do not come out, and the fetus dies: then cut them open, and remove the residue of the fetus: and bind her hand with a cloth, and remove it with equality: for he will come out.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	Exit of the embryo on his own feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus comes out on his own feet, then it is necessary that you push him up: and gradually turn the fetus over: and then make him even.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then take one of her feet, and stretch it out gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	For when they have come out as far as the hips, then order her to compress herself, and have her sneeze with a condescending tone: for one will come out if God wills it.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if he does not come out with what we have described, then gradually reduce the fetus, until you put him back in his natural shape.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For he will come out then by an easy exit.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	What if you stop completely all that we have described: then take from the foamgrape, with sesame oil and a dissolved gum: and strike it all in a mortar with a good hammer: then let a woman's ulna hit it from below, and her feet.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then I make him sit in tepid water until the hypochondriac becomes visible.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When you see that his lower parts have already become warm, then make him sit on Myrrh and support him.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When he has held the seat for an hour, then I make her sit on a chair.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then I make him sneeze: and tightening his mouth and nose, I press the lower part of his leg with a gentle compression.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the heat will soon come out.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	Exit the fetus over the knees and hands.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it comes out in this form, then she will come by slowly inserting her hands.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman should lie on her back and hang her feet down to the ground: and she herself should lie on a bed and interlace her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then I press upon her belly little by little.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then I pull out what is under her feet from the armpits until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then take her feet and move them violently.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then I press what is above the hypochondria little by little until the fetus rises to the upper parts.
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then he should interlace his hands and smooth the fetus little by little: and he should order the woman to compress, until the fetus comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	Exit the fetus hanging from the arms.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	He should be prevented from reducing his hands.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If he cannot reduce it, then the woman should be rubbed and made to walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	But if walking is not possible, then make her lie on a bed: and shake her legs violently.
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then administer the ointment which you have prepared from mucilaginous substances.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she accepts the birth, then make her sit on a chair.
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then study the reduction of her hands and the fetus in a natural position: and make the woman sneeze, and order her to compress herself, until she comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The baby's head comes out above its shoulder, with its hands spread wide, and its face turned towards the back of its mother's body.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	It is necessary that the obstetrician hold the baby's hand, then turn it gradually and easily.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	But when it has become calm, then place it on its back that we spoke of with oil and mucus.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then order him to move his arms slowly.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	But when you have done this, then make her sit down on a seat, and order her to lean against the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then order him to compress himself: and make him sneeze with a handkerchief.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The prepared baby is on the side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it descended into the mother' s opening in this way with the second, then cut the second with your finger, until it is discharged from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	But if he should hang above the baby' s face and its neck, then cut him from the umbilical cord: lest he hold on and die.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the baby into the insides, until you place it as is necessary: and order the woman to compress herself sometimes: for he will come out easily.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins, or of many babies.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born: and sometimes three, and four.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	But that is unusual, and seldom happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five is a thing outside nature, and they do not live long apart: and it holds them together, however they multiply, only two at a time: and separates them by the scaph, distinguishing between them with tied cords around each of their navels.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And when they go out as does one baby from a natural exit easily: and they go out with a loud noise, as we have told.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	That if any of them are difficult at the time of birth, and seek to go to that which we have spoken from unnatural figures, then take care of them as we have told: and let it sit on a soft cloth, and do what it does easily and tardily, and make it take all shapes with it as it is prepared by nature leading to salvation.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remembering that he is formed in the womb from embryos and is aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When he is formed in the womb one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and more than ten: and I have already verified it with myself that a woman who aborts has emitted seven, and another fifteen, all formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	That which was measured by the glorious sage.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	This then is what should be understood in the science of obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	For it may perhaps come to that which is similar to it: then oppose it with it that which is necessary
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	On the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter LXVII.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you are concerned with the extraction of a dead fetus as I have said in the division on surgery and do not exit, and you urge that you use the hand operation, then you should consider.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If then the woman is of sound virtue and is not with any of the accidents from which she fears destruction: then it should be that the woman reclines on her bed, on her back, and has her head inclined downward, and her legs raised: and he should hold her by two sides, or tie her to the bed, so that her body is not extracted along with the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the mother's mouth with moist oil with mucilaginous althaea, and fenugrecum, and flax seed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the midwife should wash her hands with these oils and mucilages: then she should enter the woman' s womb with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then she should ask where to place the knot of the fetus, and the suitable places for it.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Then consider, if the fetus is prepared to descend over its head: then place the knot in her eyes, or her throat, or her mouth, or her palate, or under her beard, or in her neck, or in the places adjacent to the ribs, and beneath the hip bones.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If however the descent is over his feet, then in the chest, and his ribs in the middle.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it should be that he holds the awl with his right hand: and lays the wound on himself between the fingers of his left hand: and inserts with ease, and fastens the awl in one of those places which we said, until he has reached the hole.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then fasten on the other side of his awl, or a third, if you are able to: so that it is equal contraction, and does not decline to the side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then let it be extended with an equal extension, and does not extend only according to the rectitude, but also move on all sides, so that it relieves his exit: as happens when a tooth is removed in the process of extraction.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And should be in him who is between that, so that the extension is softened.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	That if a part is retained from him, then it should be that the midwife puts some fingers with oil, and inserts them on the side, so that they rotate with it, because it holds.
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If then a part of the fetus comes out, then change the awls to another place that is higher: do this until the whole fetus has come out.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If then a hand comes out ahead of the other, and it is not possible to reduce it by coarsening: then should be that a cloth is wrapped over it.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then draw it out until when all is coming out, cut it or insert it into the socket of the hand, or into the bed: and so should you do to the other hand, and to the two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If then the head of the fetus is large, or has a coarsening during its exit, or there is water in his head: then should be that it inserts between the fingers of the Spatulimile spinosum, and finds with it the head, and draws out the water: or breaks it up with an instrument called Almisdach: whose shape comes with the forms of other instruments in the following chapter.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Similarly, if the fetus has a large head, then the umbilical cord should be cut: or else it should be pulled out with the hand, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then, pull out the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	If the head comes out, and the cord is around the neck: then cut off, until the moisture which is in the chest is let out.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If it is not complicated, and does not submit to delivery: then cut off the head prematurely, as far as you can do it.
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If the lower limb is deformed, or there is hydrops in it: then you should cut off the member, until the moisture which is in it has run out.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	But if the fetus is above its feet, then the attraction of it is easy, and the direction of it towards the mother's mouth is gentle.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	But if the cord is around the gut, or the chest: then you should take a piece of cloth which you have on your hand, and cut off the member, until the moisture which is in it has run out.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If other limbs are also taken away, and then the head comes out: then let the midwife put her left hand in.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	But if the mother' s mouth is open, then let the woman put her hand in deep into the vagina, and look at the head, and attract it with her fingers up to the mouth: then let her put in a hook, or two hooks, and attract it with it.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the mouth of the mother is closed, because of the hot swelling which has happened to it: then it is not necessary that she should work on the fetus, but rather at that time you should administer to her the flowing fluids, thick: and apply plasters: and let her sit in water which softens and moistens.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its side, then it is possible that it will be quiet: then administer to it what we have said about a single fetus.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do so, then incise quickly and remove it.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And you should not leave anything inside at all after the second incision.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	Since you have completed your operation, then administer what we said in the apostemes of the hot things that happen in the wombs.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If a flow of blood occurs, then let it go down in water of rigor, and administer the remaining cure.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I have already seen a woman, in whose womb the fetus was dead: and then she became pregnant again on top of that same womb, after which the other fetus also died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	So it happened to her after a long time that an apostema appeared in her navel, and it swelled up until it was opened, and it began to discharge pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	So I was called to her cure, and I treated her for a long time: and the wound did not heal.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I then placed over it some strong adhesive plasters: and it came out of place from the mouth.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then a few days passed, and another outlet came out from her mouth.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I was amazed then that there is no outlet in the womb when there is an outlet in the mouth.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I thought, since there are bones of a dead fetus.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I inquired about the wound, and I pulled out many bones, while she was in a better state of health: and now she did not live for such a long time, and she began to discharge pus from the site little by little.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I do not make this foreign to you, unless there is knowledge and aid for it, which the skilled healer can administer with his hand in the cure.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	On Forms Of Instruments Necessary For The Extraction Of The Fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter LXVII. On The Head.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here is the form of the Strigulator, which are joined at equal intervals to two rods, with two twines.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	However, this vertigo should be made less coarse than the striga, and so it is made either of ebony or of wood from the buss tree.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And let the width of all the wood be as wide as two fingers: and the margin of each of them is as wide as a finger, and their length is as a palm and half; and in the middle of the two woods there are two additions of the same kind of wood, which have already been set firm on both, the length of which is the half of the palm and slightly more; and the width of each is almost two fingers, or slightly less.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additions are inserted into the jaw bone, so that it opens with them when you turn your two wheels.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the jaw opening.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	There is another one similar to it, which is smaller and lighter.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	Let it be made of ebony wood, or pine wood, according to the similarity of the claws.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	However, at the end there are two additions, as you can see here above: and the length of each of them is almost a palm: and the width of each is that of two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	But when you open the jaw with it, then make the woman sit on a bed, her feet hanging down, open what is between her shoulder blades.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then insert these two additions joined together into the jaw: and you, holding the end of the instrument between her thighs.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument as you do with the claws, equally according to the quantity that you wish by opening the mouth of the jaw, until the midwife does what she wants to do.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The form of the second wheel, which is different from that which the ancient people spoke about, as it pushes forward the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The form of Al-Misdar, by which the great head is turned: and resembles the claws, with teeth at the end, as you can see.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is turned inwards, as the claw does according to this form, as you can see, with teeth like a saw, which cuts and turns inside.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of Al-Misdar, by which the small head is turned.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	Form a Vncinis with one spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	Form a Vncinis with two spines.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	Make a forceps which has serrated teeth and which grasps the head of the fetus.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	Form a scissor with two ends for cutting off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	Also form two scissors for holding open.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are all used and the more their kinds multiply and they are prepared for use by artifice, the quicker they are in their work and the higher they stand among men because of their number.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Do not then despise these instruments, even if they do not exist with you; rather, have them prepared for you.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is not excusable to need them.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	§ On the Extraction of the Second.
Caput LXXVIII.	Head 78.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second is retained at childbirth, then you must take care to hold back the weakling so that it does not hold its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make her sneeze with a squeeze; and tightly grasp your hand over her nose.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If then she comes out through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then take a club, and pierce through the roof; and put in it herbs opening the mouth of the mother, such as calamus, rue, aniseed, camomile, chamomile, and cassia bark, and some of these herbs; and dip them in water, and place them on the fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then put a twig of hawthorn on the hole in the roof, and another end at the mouth of the mother; and let her hold it until the steam from the birth has cooled down.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make her sneeze, as we have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The second is then born with ease.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If, however, it remains after this care and does not come out: then instruct the Midwife to dip her hand in sesame oil or mucilaginous aloe.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then he inserted himself into her vagina and inquired about her second birth.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	So when he found her, then he took her, and he slowly stretched her out.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	But if she is attached in the depths of the womb, then he should insert his hand, according to what we have said above, until such time as he finds the second one and gradually pulls it out according to the straightness so that the womb does not fall due to a sudden pull: at the front it should be exchanged with ease from right to left: then it is added in quantity.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	For she will obey then and spread herself out, and she will separate herself from the adhesion.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	That if the opening of the womb is constricted, as we have already related: take care of it with a sternutation, and from the medication of the wound with herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	But if she does not come out with all that we have said above, then take care not to tire her out in the process of extraction.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	But it is necessary for what comes out at the opening of the womb from her to be tied up on the woman's thigh.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then clean her with a four-part ointment.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	For this will make her rot and dissolve after a few days, and she will come out.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	But when it is rotten, a bad smell comes out of it towards the stomach and head, and it hurts that part.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary then that appropriate suffumigations be administered to her.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancient ones who have already been experienced are the suffumigations of mustard and dried figs.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	Form a tool with which to suffume the woman during the retention of the second birth and the months.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be made from a similar wool or from hemp: and let it be placed on a wide end over fire: and the suffumigation should be placed on plums: hold it, until that suffumigation is consumed: and then take another one.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	As for the treatment of women who have not been penetrated.
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter LXXIX.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys were born, and their hams were not pierced, which the sutures of the delicate sirocco had already opened.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary that the midwife pierce that sirocco with her finger: and if she does not, she should pierce it with a sharp spatulim: and let her beware of touching the snake, lest she be bitten.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put a woolen cloth, soaked in wine and oil, on top of it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with ointment, until it heals.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	But if you guess that he is drunk, then put a lead plunger in the hole for many days, and remove it when the boy wishes to defecate.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And it also happened that the boys were drunk because of the concusiveness of the wine or pus.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary that you remove that consolidation, and then care for it with the above-mentioned things after removing it.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	Regarding the cure of fistulas that occur in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Chapter LXXX.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas that occur in the lower part are a nodding and grossness which occurs near the anus of a particular animal: or in the space of one part: and there is one fistula, or many.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When that grossness is cured, it opens, and from it issues a watery moisture of white pus or a subtle pus.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And when they are penetrating from these fistulas.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Thus the penetrating ones are recognized by that which issues from defecation, and their wetness, when a person with an illness defecates: and perhaps they issue from them naked.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And there are fistulas from which they penetrate into the space all the way to the bone, and up to the vertex of the hip.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And some of them penetrate all the way to the joint of the hip, and up to the root of the tail.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From that one from which the penetrating fistula all the way to an animal is recognized, and also not from a non-penetrating one, is, when you put your index finger into the anus: and try to push a thin piece of metal or brass into the fistula: if there is no tortuosity.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	If there is a twist in it, then insert into it a thin probe, or a nail from the nails of the equines, until you feel it trying, or a nail in your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel it thoroughly, and there is no discharge from the wound, nor any pus, nor is it as I have said: then know that it is not penetrating: therefore approach again to the cure.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula penetrates as far as the skin, or to the bladder: then the sign of it is the flow of urine from it, and its prohibition from this so that the place with the medicines consolidates.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If it penetrates as far as the joint of the hip, or to the jaw: then the sign of it is that it reaches with a probe as far as there, if there is no twist in it up to the jaw: and there is pain on the circumference of the part, and pus always comes out from it: and that it does not scar with ointment, and consolidates.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And in all these fistulas which penetrate completely there is no cure at all: and the cure of them is work and vanity to him from foolish doctors, on whom a form is made up.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	In that one, or if it is not penetrating, and is not ancient, there is hope for a cure with a knife: for I tell you, and I have tested this myself: and it is, so that the sick man lies in your hands on his back: and trim the legs of him up to above his hips, and his hips are bent towards his venter.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then insert a probe or air, if it is a twist fistula, until you know where the probe reaches.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	But if he feels it on a certain part, then you should put your finger on that part.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	But if you feel the probe already penetrate itself by your finger, besides that you feel it between your finger and the skin, or flesh: then know for sure that it is penetrating: so do not work on it, because its cure is not as I said.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They said that he heals some people's flesh, and from the medicine which he hopes will benefit them, it is as if he sets fire to a cautery of fine fire according to the width of the fistula, as has been said before, and he inserts it in the fistula until it reaches a certain point.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then he does this again twice or three times, until you know that all the added filtered flesh, which is like a feather, has dried up and become similar to a feather.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then he cares for that with liniments soaked in butter until the dried-up flesh comes out: and then he cares for it with ointments that generate meat and consolidate it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If then he heals, it is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, then he does not heal with any other cure ever.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if it comes out and does not reach your finger, which is in the anus, and is between it and a hard piece of flesh or a blade: and you see a fistula on it that follows the skin's surface, then dry off the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and dry out with the towel what is in the fistula, until you reach the place where the end of the towel reaches, and let the towel fall and drop.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then clean those filtered flesh, which are like a feather, so that nothing remains of them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however the blood hurts you, and dissolves between you and your surgery so that it solves those flesh: then it is better if it happens, and quicker in its benefit, to cauterize it with fire, or with sharp medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For the cautery with fire brings good habits together, to the burning of that flesh which is added, and to the stopping of blood, and drying up of moisture.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then he cares for that with liniments soaked in butter, or with crushed leaves, until the place gives off pus, and dried-up flesh comes out in the pus.
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then the cure for the scar when the wound has hardened with ointments, producing hard flesh: and there are medicines in which are stigmatis and drying out.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	For when it is being treated, then it is being healed: and do not put off repetition.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	But if the fistula has reached to a great depth of the anus, and has elongated from the excess fluid of the body: then insert your finger into the anus, and feel with it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	But if you feel a pulsatillenesse and between yourself and her is some kind of a defect, or flesh, and is near to penetration: then there is no operation in that, unless by the second time of confidence and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	That is, because it is done in him one of the two ways: or as it is cauterized itself, as we have said: or separate it, until the consequence of its concavity comes about, so that it is possible for you to introduce a scalpel, and cure from nearby.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed much with the incision, lest you fall into the trap of the continous anus, and happens on to a premature death of exhaustion without will.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then the cure for that with him which we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will be healed: or will elongate the defect, and clean it up all the way to near the anus, as we have said, or with a probe, or with another acute end of an instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then clean those filthy meats which are in the incision, all the way to where you can with examination.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then try to restore the wound of the whole limb with the incision, and the opening where it hardens: and remains a fistula open on the inside part of the anus, and will be lighter on to the premature death.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And when the fistula follows this way: and is, when you introduce a probe into the fistula: and is on the side of the anus near to the surface of the body with skin and the margin of the anus: then take hold of the probe's sharp end, which is like an accusative, that is, a preparative tool, according to this form.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And introduce into it a thread uncoiled from five threads, and wrap it around.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then introduce the thread with a hook into the fistula, until you feel its tension.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If then it is penetrating into the margin of the anus internally nearby, then remove the thread from that opening: so that you can introduce your finger in anum, and remove the end of the thread, and gather both ends together at once: and tighten both of them, and let it go one day, or two days: and to the extent that the thread bites into the flesh, tighten it well, until those muscles which are between the two ends of the thread fall down: then take care of the wound, until it hardens, and heals.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	If, however, the opening of the fistula is not penetrating: then make it penetrate in whatever way you prepare it for yourself, unless it is in a deep place.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For indeed it is not yours to do such a thing, so that you don't hurt yourself itself.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then do with it as we have said, until it heals.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The shape of the sharp needle where the fistula is found, whose curvature is acute greatly, and its other side is not acute, so that it does not hurt that which is not necessary, as you see.
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	Of the suture of hemorrhoids, from which runs blood from their incisions: and take care of the fissures.
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter LIII.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids according to two ways.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	Or indeed they are inside the anus, similar to charcoal, or like plums: or almost like small grains.
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And of them there are some little ones and some big ones: and blood runs from them always, and there is one, and many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the anus, and at its ends.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	Indeed these that are outside the anus, are according to most part few of moisture, from which runs yellow water, or a little blood with constant course: and they are according to color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the cure of that which is within the anus, you should instruct the sick person to straining; and it should be expressed until it comes out, and appears atheneum to you.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore therefore and hang with hooks: or hold them with your fingernail.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then therefore cut them at their roots.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If however they do not retain hooks, because of their moisture and their own softness: then take them with a rough cloth, or with a twine made of double-twined wool, and pull them out with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut them and sprinkle over them after the cut some warm powders so that they remain in place of cauterization.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what has preceded in the chapter on cauterizing.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with the remaining cure, until they are healed.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	That if the anus does not obey the ejection, then clench the sick with a small clister in which is a little mordicatio, so that it soothes with it what is in the ano, and obeys the ejection more quickly when it is expressed by the sick.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If however atheneum have been taken out of the ano, then the business is lighter and easier: and it is as if you were to take them with your fingernail, or take them with a hook, and cut them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said, until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And who hates cutting with iron, then you should administer to them a sutura in the following way.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a silk thread, and insert it into the anus.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then pull out the atheneum upwards, and let it penetrate with the needle into the root from the other side; and wrap the two ends of the silk thread around the lower part of the needle, and spread them out: and tighten the atheneum with a strong knot.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then tie off the silk thread, and pull out the silk thread.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this to all the atheneum, and leave one alone: and let his own be drawn out, so that it carries away the redundancy of blood.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then put a certain cloth soaked in rose-water, or neroli-water, on the part; and put the same on the part itself; and order the sick one to lie down.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let him lie down until he has fallen asleep.
