Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When the wound has therefore closed, take care of them with ointment, and with the other treatment, until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	§ On the treatment of wounds.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	For often accidents happen because of drying up of stool, and constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When they have been a little while wet, and do not suffer from medicine: then let them be scrubbed with the sponge of Spongia, or with your own finger, until they are moist, and let go off them the upper layer which prevents their being consolidated.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then take care of them, until they are consolidated according to what is necessary.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	But if they do not consolidate: then repeat the scrape with a more rough sponge than before, until they bleed much, and then take care of them, until they are healed.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	§ On the treatment of putrid wounds, and not putrid ones: and on the care of sore-mouth, and of swelled lips.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter LIII.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that Almirmar is only a round knot according to the color of the body, similar to a claw's head: and it happens in the whole body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and fingers: and it causes pain on walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Then let it be cut off what is in the circumference of the claw, and held with forceps, or with a hook, and Root it out from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then take care of that one: and if you have a caustic, treat it according to what has gone before in his chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	But from the sore-mouth there is only one little excellence, rough, filtered, round on the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And often it happens in the hands of boys.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its treatment is, that you spread out the sore-mouth, and let it fall; or that you tie it with silk thread: or with hair, until it falls down.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you see [a wound], cauterize it according to what has been said above with fire, or with sharp medicine; and now the athelias that are imposed are eradicated, and not imposed with an instrument that I call.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	But the ant is also a prominent little filter, coarse, on the surface of the body, wetting it deeply; and when it comes to coolness, it feels in it a similar stinging of an ant, and becomes in the whole body; and much of it is made in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its cure is that you take a tube from the beak of a goose, or a strong vulture's beak; and put that tube on the ant, until it holds a circle of the tube from its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then you will turn your hand with the tube, until you separate what is in the circumference of the ant; and put it in the depth of the flesh, and you eradicate the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you see it, do it with the tube of air or iron, according to this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the tube sit on top of the palm with a small piece of skin pulled, so that it does not hurt the touch of its grip and its retraction.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you see it, cauterize the ant according to what has been said above in cauterizing Athelil in the chapter on cauterization.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	About forms of instruments that are administered to clisters in the ailments of the bird, and the solution of the spring, and colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter Liii.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the clister is made of silver, or of gold-plated brass, or of ordinary brass, or of hammered brass.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when it is made from these small instruments, and from the large ones, according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	So then what is administered in the cure of young boys who are weak, or those who are sick, so that their clisters are weak too.
Clistere magnum.	The large clister.
Cistere paruum.	Cysts in the lungs.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	Cistere paruum.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	The cysts in the lungs are wide and round. The opening of the cysts is wide enough for a small piece of cloth or a feather to pass through; their base is rounded. The opening of one side should be closed, that is, not open, smooth, slightly curved, and reaching down towards the hip. On one side there are two openings, and on the other side there is one opening.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And many holes are pierced in the cysts, as it were, and there is a space that is the width of a finger between each hole.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then introduce into these holes a strong thread made of raw silk, which has ten threads, or a little more, and tie it together with the same thread.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When this cloth is placed in the cysts, tighten it in the top part of the cysts with a strong knot between two distinctions.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then tighten the cloth.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the shape of a circle as it is depicted here, and the holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of tightening the cloth is this: fill it with a medicine from the pharmacy that has been heated according to the tolerance of the nurse; and do not make it too hot or too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the sick person should lie on his back, and raise his legs up; and place something under him, that is, a mattress above which the people sleep, or a blanket.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then dip the tip of the cloth in oil, or in alum, or in mucus of fenugreek, or like it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then introduce it into the anus easily.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then take a servant with his two hands and squeeze it hard until all that is in the cysts has been discharged into the intestines.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the cloth, and raise the sick person's legs up towards the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If medicine can save him to the end, then he should hold on as long as possible.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with her all night, it is even more of a last resort in healing.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you enema him with a solution of the sixth water and his death is imminent: then do another enema until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	That if there are hemorrhoids or itching painful blisters then do a mild enema frequently, gently, from the enemas with which the boys are enema
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this should be the form of a gentle enema over which there is a strict skin.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	Of the treatment of head wounds without fracture of the bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter LIII. Of the treatment of head wounds without fracture of the bone.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already said in the division of the treatment of wounds which concerned the book, and I say here the cure of these with the hand, and with the help of doctors according to the second aid.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say, therefore, that wounds differ according to the cause of their being, and according to the place on which they fall.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore the wounds that are often caused, are like shots of stones: or cuts of a knife, or a blow with a lance, or a piece of wood, or an arrow: and similar things from many other things.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds that are caused according to the places of the body are, such as a wound that falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or an organ: and similar ones from the members.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am telling the treatment of certain wounds, that I may set forth the reasoning and rule for the remaining wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I shall begin with simple head wounds: because the memory of the teacher will come at the beginning of Chapter III.
Dico ergo.	I say, therefore:
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When it comes to a simple wound on the head, and there is no fracture of the bone: then consider if it is from a shot of stone, or similar, and has broken the skin only: and it is a severe wound, and fear about the outcome of blistering fever: then make an immediate phlebotomy on the head: and do not delay that: and draw out his blood according to the quantity of its virtue: if there is no prohibition from phlebotomy, especially if it is the blood that flows out from the wound a little.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the bleeding come from the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	Let the sick person avoid food, wine, and heavy meals.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if there is a need to restrain something, then let it be restrained from food, and not approach meat or wine.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound if there is a feverish condition, hot poultice with infused oil in rose water alone, or with wine where there is a stenosis.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are free from a feverish condition, then place over the wound if it is new with its own blood, and has not changed its air, the powder which I will describe after a little while: and if it has already changed its air, then place over it some ointment, until it is healed.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large, or is from an incision of a sword, and similar: and its lips are not gathered by poultices, then gather it with a stitch, according to what I will describe in wounds of the leg about their stitches.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if the wound has already been detected from a bone, and hangs, and there is no retention of it, except in a small suspender: then incision that wound.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with medicines, and restore it to its place of tough skin, and order the sick person to eat food in which there is a fermentation, such as heads of animals and cooked wheat, until it becomes like a pulse: and let them eat similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	That if the wound is in the skin and does not adhere to the bone: then incision all that part which is putrefied, and throw it away: and then care for it.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	But if there is an artery in these wounds, or a new one from which blood flows: and does not become separated by medicines, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	But if you do not cut that wound, then dry it up with Spike-root, or bind it up.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	That if necessity forces you to do this before what I have said is done, then burn it, until blood stops flowing from it.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If, however, these wounds are small and simple, then the matter is easy and light: so that the powder applied to them can be easily absorbed: because it solidifies before it changes by air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	The method of the powder for healing wounds.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take a part of olibanum, and two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of non-extinguished limestone: all are to be well mixed together, and sieved: then fill it with the powder, and bind it firmly in place until it sticks well to itself and congeals with blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then tie the powder above it, and leave it, and do not remove it until it has remained in place: so that it does not crumble.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For the medicine will not be removed from it until it is healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And when this lime is made alone by itself, when you do not have on hand olive oil either, and dragon' s blood also makes the same operation in many large wounds when it is put on them and bound together, and are recent wounds with their own blood, which has not been changed by air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	That if the air has already somewhat altered it, especially when it is in the summer season, then the intention of this powder is not in place: so take care to put on it some digestible ointment that we have mentioned, or put on it a paste made from barley flour, prepared with water and honey, until pus is discharged.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the rest with the usual cure, until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If, however, there is a broken fracture of a bone and it is small, then extract it with the help of a hook: for I will now speak about the treatment of fractures of the skull.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Regarding wounds in the neck area.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter LXXXV on the head.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If a wound has occurred in the neck, then there is no difference in treatment between it and a wound of the head, when the latter is simple.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if the incision has already reached the nerve of the neck or an artery: then if it is a nerve, there is no skill in it, unless treatment with it causes a harsh constriction, like the cinchona and other such things.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they harm the nerves, and turn them back.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not put any cold thing on a wound at all: for the substance of the nerves is cold, and their extension is with the brain, which is an exalted member of the body: and let such a one be cured with medicines of softness, as the lime, when it is poured out with sweet water sometimes infused with oil, or with rosin oil, and turpentine, when it is washed also with sweet water: and other mineral stones, in this fashion, and humid unguents.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then administer a stitch: or cover its lips with dust.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of yourself, until you are healed.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound is deep, or has occurred a pocket of pus in its lower part, then pierce it in a more depressed place.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	That if the incision has already reached the nerve of an artery, and the flow of its blood is followed: then separate it, or dry it up, and bind it: or burn it, if necessity compels to do so.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the incision has already reached the spine's joint, or all of it, and so on as if it were a horse's joint: then join the skin's lips together with a stitch over the joint, and do not touch the joint, but rather make it fit the natural form.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then tighten it with a tightening that decreases gradually, and leave it for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then take care of yourself with unguents that cause dryness and healing.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then examine it: then if there are any fragments of bone, remove them all, or as many as you can: and what is not prepared, leave it, until the wound decays, and separates and discharges its excrement.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the wound is fresh, then dust the powder on top of the powder that I have laid down.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if it is a case of a broken bone and a fistula: then take care of it with the Remedy that comes in the chapter about it.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On Wounds in Spatulas.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter LXVIII. On wounds in spatulas.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If the wound is caused by a lance or a knife, and you can see its depth, then examine it carefully.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	But if there is a flow of pus from the wound, and the patient groans because of it, then know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if it is not deep and is fresh with its blood: then do not put the powder on it at first hour, nor bind it up so that the blood does not hold in its depth and returns to the heart and makes him sick; but put on it a attracting ointment and undo it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if you do not have the ointment present, then put on the wound a used cloth, so that it sucks out what comes from it by moisture: and let the patient sleep on the wound so that what is gathered in it runs out.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if three or more days have passed since the wound and there has been no spasms, no bad tremor of the heart, no tightness in breathing, and the other signs of it are good, then know that the wound is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Take care of it and with ease, and with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if the healing of it is slow and it opens again always, then know that it has already become a fistula.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Take care of it from the chapter about it.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the bone is from an incision of a sword or a knife, and it is simple on the surface of the back, or the back of the neck: then take care of the wound with the Remedy that preceded it from the sutura, if it is large: or with powder, if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If, however, he has already made an impression on the bone and has struck out from it a piece of fracture: then inquire about the rib, and approach towards extracting those fractures if they are separate.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If, however, they are not separated, then let them go until the rib has putrefied, for the extraction of these will be облегчена.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But as regards the remains of injuries and accidents in the remaining members, it is a question of judgment in the treatment, which I have mentioned.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Regarding wounds in the belly and the exit of the intestine and the exit of them.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LXXVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The rupture that has occurred in the belly is great, medium, and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	So then when and how often the intestine emerges, or the number of intestines.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Why do they get mixed up, and their sewing is more painful and difficult?
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small rupture also is difficult from another mode.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	So then, in order that the reduction of them may be more difficult, if you do not hurry up to bring it back to its place: for it swells, opens, and thickens: why does entry into it become difficult?
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore the middle disruption is better than the small one: for since the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is difficult to reduce these two species.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the縫合 of the belly is according to four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	The two common sutures meet in the Suture of the belly and in the Suture of the remaining wounds of the body: and the other two particular sutures communicate to the rest of the wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, they are more proper when it is a matter of the Suture of the belly: and I will tell you one thing at a time, with an explanation.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say, that when the rib is small and has come out a little of the intestine, and it is difficult to reduce it: then it is on account of one or both of these two ways.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Or because of the swelling due to cold air in the intestine, as we have said:
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When then is this so? Then it is necessary to warm him up, so as to submerge a sponge or a wet cloth in warm water.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you cook it in squirted water and cypress and garlic and simmer with it the intestines until the swelling is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When then does this wine which has fever make? And it is better than water alone in resolving the swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When then do you see that the swelling has already been resolved, then wet the intestines with the water in which it was cooked, or dry them.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For by this his entry will be eased with the small object.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if his return is excused after this treatment, then find in the disruption a little, with the instrument with which they cut the hemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first cure is better when prepared, than the incision: and it does not require a force to cut after need and want of instruments.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be acute and the other obtuse, and the extremities be a little sharp, rather blunt; and this is like a cauda, as you see it.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When then does the knot grow larger and enters into the intestine, then it is necessary that there be a return of him according to his natural form in his own place, if possible above it: for it is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	But when the rupture is wide in the lower part of the groin: then it is necessary that you let lie the sick one on his back, and set his legs higher than his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the groin, then set his head and his chest higher than his lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And also if the rupture is on one side of the groin, then set your intention and your attention always in this, that part in which is the knot be higher on the other side.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it should be that you administer this to large wounds and to medium-sized wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But regarding small wounds, place it as you have prepared it for yourself.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make it present between the hands of a pious minister who holds the whole laceration in his hand: and spread out its lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then find someone who follows who has some thread; and this is the way of a common single stitch.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And there are those who take as much as you want, or count as much as you want according to the width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the end of the laceration by the amount of your finger, that is, the doctor: and fasten now one after you have inserted it in at both ends of the skin, with two ends of the thread that are under the skin from within, until you have made it penetrate from the other side, and you have already joined together the two ends of the skin, and the two ends of the thread: and there are four orders.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tighten with double thread around the needle from both sides at the same time, until the two lips of the wound have been brought together by the decreasing gathering.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go of the thickness of the finger as well, and fasten in them another: then make it straight with thread, just as you did with the needle first time.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	So you should not stop doing this with him as you go along from the beginning until you have completed the compression of the whole wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And there are medium needles between the thickness and the fineness: because the fine ones cut flesh quickly; and the thick ones enter difficult into the skin: therefore it is necessary that they be both of a middle size, and of a fineness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be fastened in both ends of the skin close together: so that the flesh does not quickly cut; and the wound does not open before its consolidation, and it does not elongate with the stitch, so that it does not prevent the wound from being consolidated.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the end of the acute edge so that it does not hurt the sick person in his sleep; and put on them little balls made from thin cloths from all parts that hold the ends of the sharp edges; and let them go until you know that the injury has already healed.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this type of stitch with acute points is much more convenient for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	Since it is sufficient in the stitch of their one, or two, or around them.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	But the second common stitch is to collect with the stitch the four ends: the ends of the two skins, and the ends of the two sfac in one thread, with an acute point in subtlety and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you penetrate with the acute point all four ends, draw them back from the part from which you started in order for the thread to come out from the upper part of the wound: so that the stitch is, like a stitch on cloth when cloth is stretched, and place between every stitch the amount of thickness of the little finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This stitch everyone knows.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitch I sewed a wound that occurred to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife, and the injury to the flesh was large with a palm's width: and it came out from the intestines about two palms from the middle intestine, and there was an injury in the middle of the stomach.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	So I reduced that after he had stood for twenty hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound was healed in a space that had been for about fifteen days: and I took care of it, and he was cured: and after that he lived for many years, thriving in his affairs.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the doctors judged that it would not heal.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	But by a miracle I did not cure that with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Since I was in a place where the ointment was not found, and there was no medicine.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	So I put on the wound a cotton cloth wetted with honey twice a day, and took care of its washing with honey water until it was cured.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	Two kinds of stitches I shall call by their own names according to the speech.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is as follows, beginning with an acute stitch: and insert it from the outside to the inside part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle enters the skin, and runs through the length and width of the whole body: let go of the end of the thread where you inserted the needle, and let it penetrate another end from the inside to the outside in an opposite direction.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate again at this same end from the outside to the inside: and let go of the end of the thread that is in this side, and make it penetrate another end from the inside to the outside - opposite direction - from this same end: and when you make it penetrate, then make it penetrate by your penetration, which makes it penetrate in this end, that is on the opposite side, until it penetrates all of it.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then also from this same side, and take it by the end that is on the opposite side, and bring out the needle where it penetrated the skin.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then also reduce it in that skin, and take its end that is on the opposite side, and bring it together with this end where you are; and bring out from the skin that which was brought out from the opposite side: and make that one go out before the other - as many times as necessary - until they are completely outside according to that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the upper part of this stitch is as follows; it is that their stitches should be close together, like those that make the skin smooth: so that its end of the thread is brought out from one side of the skin; and let go of it on the other side until you have finished it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of stitch belongs to Galen.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This speech of his has been told, that their stitches should be made similar in such a way as some doctors make them, so that they gather together all the parts by their natural shape: and they bring the end of the thread to one another, and this end where it is brought together with its opposite.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this I will tell you next.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You should make the incision at this point, close to the outer edge near you, and make it penetrate into the inside, in that same place only: and you shall leave two ends of the incision, rifacendo.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the incision around, and make it penetrate from the outside to the inside at both ends, that is to say on each side: rifacendo.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both sides around, and make them penetrate from the inside to the outside at both ends, that is to say on each side opposite: rifacendo.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of stitching is better than the common easy stitch, and it is a stitch which has a memory: the one before it.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is thus the speech of Galen also.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And certain ones said.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The stitch of the hand with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is to say, that you should put into them both one wire: and begin with the inserting of the needle, since it is with you, and make it penetrate to the other side, from one side to another, in accordance with the stitches of those which are equal.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And you should know, that when the break is in the middle of the hand: then the stitch of it is more difficult than at any other part of the hand.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	Judgment indeed of the treatment of wounds, is judgment of all wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is to say, because when you have made the wound clean with its own blood, before it cools itself: and you have reduced the entrails, and they themselves, and made them fit: then put on the poultice of scar.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	That is to say, if the air has already altered the wound: then put on the poultice of some ointment which is near you, until it makes the pus: and let the wires drop off, and be firm on each side, and the incision close up.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then take care for that wound as is taken care of all wounds, until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	If you have not the medication for that wound, then put on it immediately, so that it may begin to emit pus, and change the poultice twice a day, as I taught you, until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	But if there are no other conditions, and the wounds are simple, then there is no need for medication.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If, however, you should come to the conclusion that there is an injury to the main member of the body, then it is necessary to immerse the wound in a cloth dipped in oil of moderate temperature, or in rosin oil: and place it around the places that are between the hips, and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	That if it feels pain, or prickings, or putrefaction in its intestines (for this often happens), then cleanse the bowels with astringent wine, black, hot: especially if putrefaction has already reached the intestines and a penetrating gangrene has taken hold up to the peritoneum.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what is from the large intestine is easier to heal: and that which is from the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called the jejunum does not accept healing from a wound that has occurred in it at all: and this is because of its multitude, since it is made up of loops, and because of its size, and because of its softness, and because of the closeness of its nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if the wound that has come from it is not deep, and you are able to grasp it well: reduce it according to your own judgment, reducing the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if there is a space that has been passed through it, and it has already become bright or black: then you should tighten it with a thread above the place that has been discolored by it, so that blood does not flow.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the loop there are arteries and veins.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and place two ends of a thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside the body: so as to relieve its pull on you, and to extract it toward the opening of the loop, and to emit the pus of the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remembrance of the wound that happened in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When disruption occurs in the intestine and is slight: then it is possible to restore it in some people; because I saw one who was wounded in his abdomen with a lance, and there was an old wound on the right side of his stomach, and it had healed up; and a fistula was made, and came out of it belching and wind.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I therefore applied the treatment, until I was confident in his recovery; and I did not cease to examine him carefully, until he was well and the site had been strengthened.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	Once I saw the place was now consolidated, I feared for the disease that might come upon him in his abdomen: and it did not happen to him from that accident any evil.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better health, eating and drinking, and enjoying himself, and entering a bath, and exercising his body.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some experimenters said, for when disruption occurs in the intestine and is slight: then it should be tied according to this method.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, that you take ants of large heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather two lips of the wound, and put one ant on them which has an open mouth over the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	Then when the head is on it, and it tightens its mouth, cut off the head; for it clings to it, and does not come off.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then put another ant next to the first, and do not stop doing this with the ant after the second amount of wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce the wound, and tie up the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	Those heads remain annexed to the intestine, until it is fed by the intestine, and is healed, and does not happen to the sick person any evil inside.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is possible that the intestine be tied also with a thin thread; which is taken from the animal's intestine, annexed to it after it enters into the nest.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is, that you take the end of this thread out of the intestine, and cut off a lot of it.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie his filament with a thin silk thread.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that filament into the cavity, and sew it to the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce the wound.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of sewing with the awl and intestine is no more than a second opinion of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You know, a wound that is large and broad, especially if it is in one of the thin intestines; then it is not a skill but a delicate operation, and its healing is not at all certain.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Regarding the care for the small intestine and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter LXXVIII.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You should know that every wound, or suppurating sore when it has healed over and become old, and has formed a ulcer, and still discharges pus always, and does not heal: then we call it universally a fistula wherever it may be in the body; and we name it Zuchemen itself.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is, in fact, a kind of filiation according to the nature of the part affected; it is hard and white: there is no pain with it, but there are curly feathers: and because of this it is called by some people Risati, that is, feather-like.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is sometimes moist, discharging pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps it heals by granulation in some hours.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	When this moisture is much, and there is little: and when it is thick, and when it is thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	I have already پیش in the division, then when I said wounds, that every ulcer which does not heal, and does not form new flesh, is not a wound at all but a fistula for nine causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of these causes is, or because there is a lack of blood in the body; or because of its malicious nature; or because it is between itself and over its lips hard flesh, which prevents the growth of new flesh; or because it is full of dirt and filth; or because the wound is putrid within itself, and the matter which it discharges is of bad quality; or because medicine is incompatible in its cure; or because corruption by falling into a region is a kind of pestilence, or per se in that region: for this reason digestion of ailments is difficult, and healing of ulcers by nature is delayed; or because there is only one opening, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown you all the causes and signs of them, and their treatments with physicians in detail; and it is necessary here that I make you know the treatment of the fistula and of thezuken, which is made by a surgical opening with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	So you know that the fistula happens in all parts of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For these are the fistulas that reach the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or to the intestines, or to the urethra, or to some of the ribs on the back, or to some of the joints of the body by composition: like the hands and feet: and those that flow close to the main member, and others.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Now which of these fistulas is according to this way, it is from diseases that are difficult to cure, and does not accept treatment, and the work with her is labor and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	That if there is any fistula whose depth does not reach these places that I said: and you hope, and you trust in its cure, and you seek to come to its knowledge, then you accept a trial from bronze or iron if the fistula extends according to rectitude, and you search it with itself.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is any fistula that has a tortuosity, then investigate it with a thin lead.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For because the lead with its gentleness softens itself to the body, and it is concerned about the tortuosity.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	That if the fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to indicate on it with a lead.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	So make a hole from its holes from its holes.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For because the moisture that clisterizes itself, runs towards other openings, and flows out of them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then investigate and find out according to how you can be able to: that you may know if there is a mouth or nerve, and the fistula is hidden far away or near: or is a single fistula whose openings are many, and it is over all that with great strength of your own: with your questioning, which you ask the sick person, and by finding out the pain when compressing with your hand on the spot, and similar indications and causes of accident.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when you are standing still, stationary and stable, then turn to treatment with confidence: and it is as if you consider that, if there is a fistula that appears close by, or in a place far from the juncture, or from a nerve, or an artery, or a vein, or one of the places I told you, then dry up the fistula according to what I have previously said in my narrative, and remove what is in it from filtration, and腐敗した肉、それはその穴から生じるから、またはそれに似たもの: and cure it until it is healed.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is of great depth, and straight: then you should separate it in the depth as much as you can.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it from all of its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then apply the poultice of wet wool in acute medicines: and insert it into the fistula which you have enclosed with iron: do this several times, until the acute medicine has completely corroded what remained in the enclosure of the fistula from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointment that generates healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal with this, then cauterize it according to what we have described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	But if the cause of the fistula is an opening, and this is certifed to you: then inquire about it, and dry it up according to what I have told you: if it does not prohibit you from any vein, or nerve, or main member, as we have said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	But if it is discovered to you that there is an opening, and there is some corruption, and blackening: then shave it, until all the corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for this person with what incarnates flesh, until he is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	That if it does not heal, and it discharges pus as it did: then know, that you have not achieved total eradication of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore, examine it again, and carefully consider whether there is some rational explanation for its condition, and cleanse it with your last strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore him.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	So if he recovers, it is good; and if not, then you know that that corruption is far away in the depths of the body, which you have not reached.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	So you do not have such an art, unless you let it go by nature itself.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	That if the corruption is in a small hole, and it is possible for you, draw it out with delicate forceps which are suitable for that.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then inquire about their attraction, and do not let go of any of them with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If any of them make you afraid because there is a contrary moisture, and there is no fear or mistake in cutting them: then cut those moistures and the meat, if there is any, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If you do not have the preparation to remove the bones from your time, then place over the wound that it may rot: and let go of it until it rots what is around those bones of meat and moistures.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the bone so that it does not harden again.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let it be constricted as you followed in your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	At the bottom place over the wound, if you are able, a trodden-in with oil of sulfur: or a trodden-in in Egyptian ointment, or any kind of ointment.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those moistures rot, and the bones separate from them, their removal is eased, and their attraction is gone.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If there is one large bone, such as a thigh or hip bone, and that which is corrupted from it is part of the great bone, then cut it with the last rasp, until it is taken away by the black and corruption.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the bone.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If, however, what is corrupted in it is a large part, and the corruption has already reached the bone's marrow, then you need to cut it off, and cut all of it up to the place where the corruption reaches: then take care of it, until it hardens again.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you a story about what happened to a man in his leg: that you may have an example and helper for your own operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man of about thirty years of age to whom it came to pass that he had pain in his leg, through some cause which entered into him from within the body, that is, from within, until it reached his limb; and there formed upon it a great ulcer, and not for any external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	So then with this time of error of the doctors, until the ulcer opened up, and there came many substances to him.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his cure was delayed until his leg had been bound up, and many openings were made in him: all of which were emitting pus, and moistures from the body.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	So he was treated by a number of doctors for about two years, and there was no wise man in the art of hands, until I was called, and I saw his leg, and the matter which was flowing out from those openings in great quantity: also all of his body had become yellow, and his color was citron-like.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	So then I entered into one of the openings, and came to the mouth.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings: and I found them coming together at a place from all parts of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	So then I took hold of it, and followed up on one of the openings, until I detected a part of bone: and I found it corroded: which was already corroded, and discolored, and rotten, and pierced, until it penetrated all the way down to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	So then I broke off what had been detected by me, and prepared it from corrupt bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I took hold of what was not in the bone but that corruption which I had broken off, and I made it sharp, and I broke it off.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	So then I had already roots.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I set about the root of the ulcer with cementing medicines in a long space.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	And then I tried again, and grabbed the second bone above the first fracture: and I found continuous damage with the bone; and I tightened that which also seemed to me from that same corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I grabbed it again, and I did not stop hitting the bone in detail, and tried to restore it: and it was not restored until I hit a little palm of the bone and pulled it out with its medulla.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the help of physicians, and it was quickly consolidated, and healed: and this repetition in its operation, and section, would not have been necessary, except for the weakness of the nurse, and her lack of tolerance, and my fear of it from death; because it happened to him at all times from an excessive bad syncopis.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore completely healed: and new bone grew in place of the old one, and good order was restored in his body, and his strength returned: and he recovered his health, and returned to his habits: and he did not experience any harm at all during walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however a prominent bone is already broken in the place of the body: then it should be fixed like this: you take a ligament, and tighten it on the end of the prominent bone: and order someone who will stretch it upwards: and put another grosser ligament on the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then you fasten the ligament on top of the meat that is the bone: and extend its end so that you pull the meat downwards: and you cover the meat over the place that you want to fix, so as not to hurt it when you cut the meat.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a ligament, or a board under the bone below to the side: for when you do that, you should not stop to cut the corrupted meat.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it should be fixed on the place of corruption slightly, so that there is not the risk of the bone's fracture: and it does not appear from its appearance to the sense, and compels to the force of its own fixing.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the jaw is corrupted and is not prominent, then a part of it continues with another part: and corruption is in the middle of it, or in some part of it: then discover flesh from all parts altogether.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then put wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then tighten that from the first part where there is corruption until it continues with the lock from the other part: and tighten the second according to the length of corruption just a little, as I said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is in the joint, then cut that joint that is corrupted, and tighten the jaw where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no skill in that except for abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the hand or foot plank: then the thing in it is difficult to do very much.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary that you inquire how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And abrasion it, and make clean that according to what seems to you possible, and with whatever skill you can correct it: when it does not give you a contrary vein, or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that there are many saws and drills to cut these bones according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness and lightness, and their size and smoothness, and their magnitude and hardness, and their rarity.
