Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare for each kind of operation a tool suitable to that operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require your attention to the instrument with which you work, when you have a long study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the ways of this art is a witness to the way of sickness: for then you will find that which suits him out of instruments to every disease.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments, which you may put as examples of what you cut, and proof of what you experience on others.
Forma Serrae.	Surgical instruments.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of a serrated blade.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of a serrated blade of another kind.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of a serrated blade of another type.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This illustration shows the shape of a serrated blade that is slightly off-center.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let his bow be made of steel; let its sharpness be from a whetstone; and let its handle be made of boxwood and slightly pyramid-shaped.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of the razor's blades are joined together.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of the razor follow the form of a star-shaped claw; and let its cuts follow the shape of a star's points.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	It does not fit together unless the heads of the razor blades touch and move together when they are closing; it has a large and wide mouth.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The shape of the larger of the two razor blades.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The shape of the middle razor blade.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The shape of the wider razor blade.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape of the razor blade that is closed together.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape of the other thinner razor blade.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of the curved extreme end of the other razor blade.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of a small and thin blade for the tongue.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of the razor blade that cuts bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape of the larger razor blade as well.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a ray and the end is like a serrated knife; it is shown in many places of the skull's bone-cutting.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of the razor blade that closes onto the cuts made by the other razor blades through the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular and its angles are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it should be so that all that we have said about the razors, the incisers, and the serrations should be applied to them.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Regarding the cutting of bones and the serrations on them.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends putrifiy, either because of an external cause, or for an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	But when you have cured the disease with medicine, and there is no benefit from the cure; and you see corruption affect a limb, but it does not spread to any other part of the body; then you should cut off that limb all the way up to the place where the infection stops; so that the sick person may be saved from death or from a greater disease by means of this limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this happened is that the limb is disfigured until it is healed; either it has burned itself up or rotted after yellowing; until this putrefaction comes to that part which follows the limb, and creeps all over the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when it is incised like this, and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the beating of certain fruits: as in the case of the sea scorpion, and the wasp, and the nettle, and others like them.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If then corruption or a blow is in the extreme part of the finger, then cut the finger, and not leave room for corruption, so that it may be incised all the way to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root with fire, and not leave room for corruption, until it is taken in the arm of fire.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if a wound has happened in it, then cut the arm at the hip where it joins.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption has passed over, and you see it all around the hip: then death is in that person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to add to this cure, there is a quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do for the foot, when a wound has happened in the finger, then cut it near one of the joints: and if it enters into the shank, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	Which if corruption has already reached above the knee, there is no remedy but to cut it off and let go of the sick one to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to cut a limb or to bend it is, so that you stretch the ligament in the lower part, which you want to incise: and stretch another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one minister of the ligaments stretch to the inferiores: and let another minister of the ligaments stretch upwards to the superior.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a sharp instrument, until all the flesh is seen.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be incised, or stretched.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth on all sides and not touch the sound place with the saw: and happen to the sick person a wound added, and a poultice hot.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, a flow of blood occurs inside while you are working, then quickly cauterize the place: or put on it some powder that stops the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then turn your attention to your own medication until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the injured member with a suitable bandage and take care of him, until he recovers.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same accident that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened in his black foot, with a burn that resembles fire; and that corruption first occurred in his toe, until it began to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Then the man from his own fever, after he saw the corruption enter into his limb with its violence, which he felt in pain and burning; and because of that infection he cut himself where it joins, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after he had passed a long time, the same corruption happened to him again in the first joint of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I tried to remove that excess with him when I put on the hand from the medicines after purifying his body: and the excess did not respond, and began to affect another finger: until it started to affect the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called me to cut off his hand; and I did not want to do so, hoping for a response from within to that excess: and I was afraid also of causing death to him by cutting off his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the strength of the man was above his destruction.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Then, when he was disappointed with me, he turned back to his land; and he came back to me, because he hoped for healing, and he cut off all his hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	I did not bring this story forward unless it should serve as an aid to what concerns this kind of sickness; and so that it should make clear what is made clear, and in accordance with what is relevant.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of ulcers and the quality of poultices with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter X.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an aphma occurs in some fleshy member and the space of the aphma is prolonged until it forms a collection: then it bursts, or pierces, and what is contained within it comes out, leaving a hollow place like a wound, and the skin above it, as though it were a thin cloth; and does not spread to the last extent of corruption in itself, nor prints into the mouth, nor into the nerves, nor into the ligaments: it deserves to be called a sinus: yet if it prolongs the space, until it impresses corruption on some of these members, then it is called a fistula, or a pudenda.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is that you should strike all the skin off as though it were burned up; and above all when it has become thin, and is like a cloth: and be confident that it would not stick to the place because of its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and does not bring about the last corruption: and if there is a thickness of flesh on the skin, then care for it with poultices; and you are to consider in regard to a sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor: then poultice it with Egyptian medicine, which is acid, and oil, and myrrh, parts equal, blended together in water: and let them boil on the fire until the medicine turns red: and let it come to a syrup.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and poultice it with the sinus: and tighten the opening of it, and let the medicine flow into it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with expression: make those days until the sinuses are cleaned and the smell is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is sometimes clotted with blood and water of ash, when this remedy is not present with you: and it is, so that you take the ash of dried wood, or the ash of oak wood: and you pour over it water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then wrap it up, and clatter it with it until you are confident that the sinuses have been washed away.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the tolerance of the Egyptian remedy is not good, and neither the water of ash, then clatter it with water and honey, to which has been added some crushed zircon.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clatter it with honey and wine mixed, because the property of honey is to clean and wash away: and the wine makes it adhere to the sinuses, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this occasionally, and are confident that the corruption of the sinuses has already been removed: then clatter it with it so that flesh is born in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is so that you take the dyophin from plaster: and dissolve it with rose oil, and wine astringent: or clatter it with some other remedies, of which I have written about their properties in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the orifice of the sinus is tight, in which the cannula of the clister does not enter: then enlarge it with iron a little: or put in it the lyme-tree that is stirred in Egyptian ointment, or in basilic ointment until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And likewise if the orifice is also wide, then join the lips of it with a stitch: and let go from it as much as is added to the clister without any addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And likewise if the orifice of it from which the pus runs is raised upward: then dry it out in a lower place where it is located, so that the pus runs from it downward: because when the pus is held back in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being born in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut around the bottom of the sinus, according to what you wish: then try to prepare the member in such a way that a pus comes out easily, according to how it prepares itself for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try not to leave anything behind in it at all: and take the solid medicines that are placed over the mark, fitting for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the fabric of linen.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let there be such a quantity of cloth so that it communicates with all of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps into the direct opening of the sinus hole, making a slightly larger opening in the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend with linen pads from another cloth, according to the quantity of the opening: and place it on the body in a distant position from the hole, so that the exit of pus from it is facilitated: and do not remove the large cloth, unless after a few days a single sheet.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But the one who is on the sinus opening is the one whom you remove at all times, so that it comes out what is accumulated in it from pus: and know, that which runs out of it virus, is very much, or little: or digested, or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this repeatedly consider the place of the sinus itself, whether the master feels pain there, or not have pain in it, and whether it is in it a swelling, or not: and if it is in it a swelling, great or small; and if it is hard or soft.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When then your medicine is extended thus, and you see the material that comes out over the sinus opening, know that the sinus has already come together, or is approaching coming together: so then loosen it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you loosen the knot, then change the linen cloth, and rub with unguents.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however comes out from the sinus after a long space a subtle virus, then do not despair about its coming together, for its cure approaches, because there are those who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act in the opposite way.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If it has come out of the sinuses after many days of being indignant, then you will know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If, then, the adhesion of the sinus is delayed, and its duration is prolonged: then add to the exiccation of medicines, it is true that physicians make them so that they are in their own substance of moisture, and in their own strength dry: like unguentum diacuminicon when added thereto an excess of addition by zeyi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last, because it is cured when you take unguentum diacuminicon and dissolve it with rose oil and return to the same old wine in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then bind it to it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it does the same action when you do not have with you unguentum diacuminicon, honey, when you cook it, until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh and aloe and olive oil: all of them, and grind them into powder and sprinkle it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then bind a strip of cloth over the sinus and tie it: and bind the strip with honey that you have cooked until it thickens: and sprinkle the powder on the strips, and put it on the cloth, and tie it up.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when you administer to it long aristochaus, and the roots of the sky lily, and the lily itself: and the herb powder, and the daisy.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or mixed together, stir it up, and strain it: and sprinkle the powder over the honey that you have cooked, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the sinus is prolonged and does not heal with this cure: then you will know that there is corruption in its depth: or it already makes an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members of the body, or on the ligaments: then care for the sinus with Fistularum cures, according to what has been stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Regarding the cure of Panăritus and the grinding of a fingernail and incising a finger and cutting it off:
Caput XCI.	Chapter LXXI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	The finger nail grows from under the thumb of the hand or foot, and possibly also from the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it is then allowed to grow on and neglected with regard to its care, and is made an ulcer with heat: or if it is corrupted, and discharges pus, until it corroded the nail's root: and perhaps it corrupts all of it, and possibly the corruption reaches the mouth, until it has a foul smell: and makes the end of the finger large, and makes its color dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When then you shall care for it, with what concerns the above-mentioned, and your treatment does not benefit it: then you must cut away the whole superfluity that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the caustic of the wound is very hot.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the mouth is healthy, and the nail also is healthy, and the nail's additions of thin blood press on the flesh towards the inside, and begin to sting it, and hurt it: then you should put a small radium under the edge of the nail that stings the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut the flesh easily, and put on what remains of the flesh from the medicines burning, and corroding, until it has all fallen away.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for that with the nail-oil, until it is healed.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if the corruption has already imprinted itself into the mouth, then you should cut away that mouth, and take it out: for it is not healed at all while it remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see that the corruption and ulcer are running down the finger, then cut it off at one of its ends, according to what has been said above in regard to the reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if a nail is broken or struck: and there is sharp pain with it, then you should take away the blood first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula, cutting across from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful so that the cut does not go down to the flesh that is under the nail, for then you will cause a very painful sore to arise, and it will be a reason for the birth of flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with the same ointment that soothes pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger that is added which is born in some hands of men, perhaps is fleshly all over; and perhaps there are bones in it, and perhaps a nail is born in it: and perhaps its birth is in the root of the joint, or its birth is in some nods of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So then who is born in some nods of the finger does not move; and who is born next to a joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	But of that which is fleshly there is an easy way to cut it.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, so that you strike yourself at the root with a sharp spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But of that which its birth is in the root of the joint, there is a difficult treatment.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So then abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that which is born in the finger up to the very nods, then it is necessary so that you strike the first flesh of its round incision all the way to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then tighten the mouth with one of those sharp things that are suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the flesh so that it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the healing that happens to fingers from one side to another, often happens because it is born with man, that is, it is born with him; or from the healing of a wound, or from burning of fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	So then let there be separation of that healing so that fingers grow back to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a leather strip, or rags soaked in rose oil: so that they do not quickly come together and separate them: or place between them a thin lead strip, so that the place heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise if some fingers with the palm are consolidated, then dry out that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and suits the figure of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ On Incision.
Caput XCII.	Chapter LII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Wounds are veins that are swollen, thick, and full of melancholic excesses which occur in many parts of the body; and most of them are found in the legs, especially in those who walk a lot or work hard, and those who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, you should provide for the discharge of the body from black cholera by a strong expiration sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then take blood from the patient with a large blade.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these wounds with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is that they sit and black blood is drawn from them.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that a vein is lifted and all of it is drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	But the sectioning thereof is according to this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Wrap the leg first with warm water until the thick, foul blood resolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the leg of the patient by an nurse from the upper part of the thigh up to the lower part of the knee with a string.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry a vein in one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then draw blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top and at the top it should be that the phlebotomist draws blood from the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the nail down to the tip: until it exits with an amount of blood that you see sufficient to meet its strength and endurance.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it up: and command him not to abstain from foods that cause black cholera: and repeatedly draw blood and bleed when the veins are filled, and let the patient suffer.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	But the lifting thereof is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Cut the leg of the patient if there are many hairs.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce yourself into the bath; or apply a warm damp cloth to his leg, until it turns red and the veins swell; or exercise him strongly, if there is no bath present, until the limb warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin with a towel along the course of the vein; or at the heel of his leg, or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrape the vein from all sides until you feel it; and at its appearance, that is when you see it turn red from black to white.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore you remove the skin, you will see it white as a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce underneath it the hook with a blunt point, until it comes out and leaves the skin; hang it by the blade of the hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another piece of skin next to that piece of skin with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then rub it with rays as you did before, and hang it by another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another piece of skin, or more pieces if you can endure it.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then rub it and cut it at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the piece that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this, until you pull it out from the upper part; or higher parts of the skin, until it comes out all the way; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not obey you in being pulled out and rubbed: then introduce a sharp wire into it, bind it, and pull it out; or introduce a hook underneath it: and rotate your hand around all its parts, until it comes out all the way.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Then caustice, lest it cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts, it will be difficult for you to rub it well; and introduce yourself into the wound with a needle.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have drawn it all out: then place it on the wound, soaked with wine and oil, or just oil, and care for it, until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, and has twists to it which require stretching out towards the ends, and is not like what we have said according to its straightness: then you must find out over it to all parts of its twisting, and the places of its stretching out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it up with hooks until you have completely stretched it out: and be careful when you cut your piece above it so that you do not hit a vein, or wound: for it would be difficult to stretch it out over you, or to draw it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your wits.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The shape of the incision when the vine is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the incision when the vine is blind.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not a gentle curve like the rest of the vine, and it does not have a sharp extreme, so that it does not hurt the skin: and it has a coarse flexibility, soft: for if it were thin, it would bump into the skin with its thinness: but its coarse flexibility makes it suitable, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Of the extraction of a vein from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Head 83.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is born in the legs in warm countries, like the alnet, and the land of the Arabs, and in arid, warm lands, scarce of tenderness, that is, where no grass grows, nor trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is born in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from decay which happens under the skin, like what happens inside the bodies of snakes and worms, and worms are generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is that which happens in the leg: there is a violent inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the spot becomes sore.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out from the spot of its sore, like a root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When this extreme end therefore appears from her, then you should fasten a lead screw on it, the weight of which is from a drachm to two drachms and a mark; and let go the lead that is suspended in the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything therefore comes out of her to the outside, fasten it in lead, and mark it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	That if it is prolonged for a long time, then cut off a part of it, and fasten the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut her off by the roots before she has come out all at once.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you should cut it, it will contract, and go into the flesh; and it will cause a boil, and decay in the place, and a sore wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently, and taken out little by little, until it has come out from the last of its own; and nothing remains in the body from it: and from this vein comes out in some men who are five palms long and ten fingers wide.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And already has come to me, for she has brought forth a son from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If however you should cut yourself in the time of your treatment: then drive in a lead screw into the hole, and pierce her through the length, with the body, until all that is in her comes out from that matter; and administer decay to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of this cure for boils.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the ankle of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many openings, and comes out from every opening a branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Take care therefore for this cure, as we have said in the division, and with what follows that which has been mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the section on worms that are generated under the skin, and it is called Boona Disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 82
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This Disease is called in some country Bouina Disease; because it often happens to the worms, and it is a scaly one-sided skin: it is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And he felt all over the body, ascending and descending; and his sense was shown to him by his walking with a member from one part of the body to another, until he stopped wherever he should stop on the skin, and left it.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And his progeny is from the decay of some of the humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happen worms and snakes, that is, lombrics and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they fear his wickedness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when he himself felt all over the body and went up to the head and came to a place: then perhaps it opens within him and leaves, and destroys his eye: and this happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are to treat him, and take him out, then it is not done except by his walking and showing of his sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, it should be that you hold back what is above him, and what is under him with strong constriction by a ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry up on top of him, and take him out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	That if it penetrates into the flesh, and not into his body: then put on the place a caustic with fire, until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than that which is feared, is his decay, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see him already coming to a head near the eye, then tie under him a good superciliary constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry up on top of him, and take him out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it should be that the sick one uses his own body purification, with physicians dissolving bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him guard himself from foods that generate decay.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the division above infirmity of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Head 105.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This infirmity is called in our land Nakir, and it is a pain that happens in some member; then it changes from one part of the body to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have already seen him, according as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I have been called to attend a sick woman in some trouble.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And he felt the arm and saw the swelling of the lung in the rope of the forearm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after a while I saw one swelling rise with a feverish heat as if it were a wound, going up to his shoulder faster than he could run: so that it looked like silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	So the pain left that spot and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then he sat for a while, and then he ran all over his body until he reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was shaking all over his body, according to which I saw it.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	So I was amazed at the speed with which he moved from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I too had not seen this illness with my eyes before, moving in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I saw many who suffered from one limb to another: and I did not see him with my eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that was because it is so, that he was from those who are afflicted with dry gangrene of the skin: hence this seems to indicate the windiness that is moved.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary so that it does not appear in this way in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, hidden gangrene.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	Then when you are treating his cure and the patient feels pain: then if it appears to you with your eye as we have said, then tie him down tightly on top of it and quickly dry him off under it until this windiness is driven away: and burn the spot.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see the spot with your eyes: then take care of the body with the scrubbing and with it driving out the windiness, and dyeing them red with bitter herbs, and with herbs of serapina, and others similar to these.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LVI. On the extraction of arrows.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their kind and the places in which they enter the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Indeed there is a difference between them, since some have large points, and some small; and some are curved, and some straight.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these there are three-angled ones.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these there are language arrows.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And of these there are tethers.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Indeed the ones that enter the limbs fall according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or if they enter the principal limbs, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and those like them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into one of these limbs, and you see signs of death, which I will describe to you afterwards, then you should extract the arrow from it, for death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see these bad signs, and the arrow does not appear to be embedded deeply in the limb, then you should extract it, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the arrow falls into the brain and penetrates the skull and exits through a sinus that is above the brain, it causes a violent fever, and opacities in the eyes, swelling, dizziness, redness of the eyes, blushing, spasms, confusion of thought, and loss of memory, and cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps it will exit blood from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is severed, and language is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And it will exit from the wound a white moisture similar to spittle.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it will exit from it a liquid-like meat.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If you see these signs, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it has not already exited.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that falls into the heart are: it is close to the left nipple; and feels as if it were fixed in a hard object, not in a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And the arrows move in a way similar to the pulsation; and black blood runs from the ulnar bone.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And then follows the cold of the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So know that death has come near.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And when the arrow hits the lung, there is a spray of dark blood from the ulnar bone; and the veins that run along the neck, turn pale, and change color in the nurse's hands.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out great breath, deep; and seeks the coolness of air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	That if the arrow falls into a hole, which is in the chest: then it is near the back for a few inches; and it causes great pain with a sharp ache, with a sigh: and all the arms of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then it is likely that something undigested has come out of the ulnar bone from food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach and remains there: then something like dung comes out of the ulnar bone, or a knuckle, or an intestine that has already been broken.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	So there is no hope for his cure, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	That if the arrow falls into the bladder and comes out as urine: and it proceeds from it something that goes outside, and the pain is stronger on the sick person: then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, and the neck, and the tongue, and the spatula, and the aid, and the spine, and the fork, and the hip, and the leg, and those similar to the limbs are healed according to many dispositions: but if the arrow does not hit an artery or a nerve; and there is no deadly arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I saw of these arrows, that you may understand with regard to your own cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, for a certain man, an arrow fell into his eye, into the lacrimal eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I removed it from him on one side, below the fat of his ear; and he was healed, and there was no injury to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I took out another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen to him in the fat of his eye below his lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not succeed in taking it out except for its end, which touched his skin, having been wedged in his wood: and this was a great arrow of Turkish arrows, with a soft iron, in which the ears are not.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and there was no harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I took out another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And this was an Arabic arrow, and it had ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed up on top of him between two teeth: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was delicate when I took it out, until I took it out: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I took out another arrow from a man which had fallen to him in his belly; and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Then after forty days I passed on behind him, and there was nothing changed in his appearance from his habits, so I followed up the arrow; and I carefully considered it over, and took it out: and he was healed, and there was no harm to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom the arrow had fallen on his back, and a piece of wood had been set over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Then after seven years the arrow came out at the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and a piece of wood had been set over it, and the arrow remained within her; and she did not change from her habits in anything, and the woman did not find any harm in him from his natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen on his face; and a piece of wood had been set over it, and it remained, not finding much pain in him: and there were many similar things like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	I extracted a arrow from the king's face, which had fallen on his middle nose, and had already inclined towards the right side by about as much: and the whole arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called to cure him after the arrow fell for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Then I found a sturdy arrow shaft.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I examined it with a careful touch, and did not feel it out: and he himself felt the prick and pain on his right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that was a prick from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered over the place with a plaster that attracts and draws on its strength, and assured myself, that if the place were to heal up, I would show you a sign of the arrow, so that I might cut off what followed it: and no such accident happened, meaning that the arrow had gone straight.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I applied the plaster over it for many days: and no accident happened, and the bone was consolidated in between: and he remained weak because of having had the arrow extracted from him for a space of days, until one day he felt the arrow within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put on the bone an acute medicine, which I kept for many days, until it was open: and when I examined him, I felt a slight bump of the arrow that clung to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that acute medicine, until we could see clearly the end of the arrow: and there passed away from me with that space of time about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the bone had grown bigger, and might possibly have been inserted into it with a fork, and moved it back and forth: then I did not cease to be careful, and devised ways for it, until one day I came upon it with a pair of forks made shorter, according to which their form became at the end of the chapter, so that I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I healed the fracture.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the doctors say that if the nasal cartilage is not restored, the nose will be disfigured.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I then restored it, and the fracture was consolidated, and the broken part was healed with complete health: nor did it cause him any harm at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of a certain type of incision: so that you may place that rule and meaning over it, which I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts and distinctions of this art are not contained in the telling: nor does that book contain them, and the crafty workman compares little with much: and when he describes what is present, he makes mention of what is absent: and he discovers a new operation, and a new instrument, on account of the descent of foreign things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say then, that the arrows do not come out of the member from which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by being drawn out of a place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by being drawn on the contrary side of another part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out from where it entered, or is an arrow going into flesh: and being drawn, it goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not yield to the exit at the time when it falls: then you must leave it for a few days until the flesh which is around it rots: and the attraction of it will be allayed, and its exit will be eased.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is broken into a bone, and does not yield to you at the exit, then leave it for several days: and again and again with attraction and motion every day until it goes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if it does not yield to you at the exit after several days, then you must cut around the arrow in the bone with a sharp knife, until the arrows become larger.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and take it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in one of the bones of the skull, and has already gone into one of the vents of the brain, and there appears to be some of the accidents I have mentioned: then abstain from attracting the arrow, and leave it until it has grown used to being after several days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	If the arrow has struck the liver, then death should not be prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	If the arrow has not become fixed, but remains only in the body of bone and does not penetrate as far as the liver: and he remains weak for several days, and nothing happens to him from these injuries: then the skill lies in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is very fixed, and does not submit to you for attraction: then administer lead weights around the arrow, as I told you: then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is now buried deep in the body, and hidden and concealed from sensation: then feel for it with your hand.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then attract it with some instruments suitable for attracting it.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot bring it to the surface because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow deep inside: and there is no bone, nerve, or vessel there: then look for it until the limb becomes bigger, and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	That if they are ears which it holds fast, then free the flesh that is fixed to them on all sides, with all the skill you can muster, and the skill of others also: but if it cannot be brought to bear on the ears, or their distortion, until he is healed.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you, when you perform the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is, then use your twisted hands with forceps to all parts, until you make it bleed: and the smallest detail, so that the arrow does not break, and it becomes difficult for you to attract it, and to extract it.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	That if you cannot bring it out all at once, then leave it for a few days, until what is around it begins to rot.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the extraction: for surely bandages ease pain: but if you feel opposition from the flow of blood, then administer what I have said in my book on healing: and guard your skill from cutting into bone, or a nerve, or a vessel.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And employ skill in every way that you can to heal the patient of the arrow wound: and let it be with ease, and quietness, or slowness, and steadfastness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you bring the bowstring with care, so that the patient is in the shape of the arrow, according to what was at the time of the fall of the arrow on itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more sure.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for you to do this, then employ what you can out of the shapes.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow which comes from the opposite side, or has already gone out a little towards the outside: or makes a protuberance on the extreme end of the arrow by sensation from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it sticking out: so cut off above it, and let the section be according to the quantity that they hold in it the bowstring.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract it: for it becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is held in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundedness, until it presses on the arrow in the bone, and makes it more strong for itself: and then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: dismiss it with days: and then try again, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	That if the arrowwood is in it, then push it out with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If it has fallen on the wood, and you are able to give a push: then introduce an instrument into it, so that the hole of it goes into the end of the arrow: and then push it out with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is closed up, then push it out with an instrument which enters into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is made light by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	That if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary that you should put on meat all over which is the poison: if you are able to do this.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with that which comes into contact with it.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is lodged in the chest, or in the belly, or in the urethra, or in the side: and it is near to you because you feel pain when you press upon it, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and take care not to wound the vein, or the nerve, and draw it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then saw off the limb, if you see it, and be careful about that one, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the hooks with which arrows are drawn out.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let them be made similar in length to the point, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not let go of it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of them, large and small, medium, according to the quantity of the arrow, and its size, and the width of the wound, and the contraction of it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	This is the form of the hooks for driving out an arrow.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And this is the form of the hooks for driving out an arrow but they are thick.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the end of a hook like a radium, so that it may direct its entrance into the conjoined arrow, and push with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This end of a hook for driving out an arrow is conjoined like a feather, so that it may direct its entrance into the conjoined arrow and push with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Regarding phlebotomy (bloodletting) from veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head 57.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are phlebotomized, of which custom runs in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these in the head are sixteen: two pulsating veins, which run behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries, which appear in two tempi; and two veins, which run in two nostrils of two eyes, called the two ASPECTIVE; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide-veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins, which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two wounds that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are wounds which are called Algecirich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And these two wounds that are beneath the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	But the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms, are five wounds in the whole arm.
