Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is Cephalica, and it is from the lateral forest; and it is called by the common name a wound of the head.
Et Fusca.	And Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the middle wound, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilical and a branch of the Cephalical: and it is called by the common name a wound of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilical, which is placed on the lateral domestic: and it is also called the Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And this one is called a wound of the leg.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And theFunis brachii, and it is placed on the back; and this one is that which appears above the little finger by a visible indentation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Salutatella: and this one is between the ring finger and the little finger; and these two are the branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three wounds.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is beneath the little finger's knuckle, from the lateral forest.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second one is the Saphenous vein; and its place is at the heel bone on the lateral domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the third one, which is called the Nerve; and its place is at the heel bone from the lateral forest.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three similar wounds.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Now, about the phlebotomy of two wounds behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of two wounds behind the ears is an ancient procedure which has been used to treat hemiplegia, hemorrhage in the brain, sahafa (a term for a medical condition), and bad sores on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is according to that which I have narrated.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, when one rubs the head with an ointment: and it rubs the occipital region of the skull between two wounds with a rough friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the injured man tightened his neck with a cord until two veins appeared.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are after the ears on the two depressions of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So ask them with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of their ears under your finger, there are the marks with the firebrush.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the scalpel-wielding phlebotomist, and he is the one who is called "the incision.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce him under the vein at the cut, until the phlebotomist reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wash your hands with the blood and skin on the upper side, and make an incision of the vein with the skin-cut slash.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision is as much as two fingers spread out, or about that: and you make it come out with as much blood as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tighten it with a firebrush, and let it go, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And already ahead in the beginning of the book on the incision of their ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	The phlebotomy of the two arteries at the times:
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The two arteries that are in the two times of phlebotomy by way of a strapping, are for an ancient hemianopsia: and salt water, and perspiration of the acuteness that flows towards the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of them is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Then tighten the injured man's neck much, until two veins appear with a noticeable appearance: and he shows the pulse of their ears under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	For then are the marks with the firebrush.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then wash the skin on top of the vein with your index finger, and introduce the phlebotomist from underneath, and wash the vein on top.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And make an incision of it, as you did with the two veins: and make the blood flow according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then dissolve the constriction with the help of a surgical instrument, and place your finger on it for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place a cotton wadding over it and the pus, and tightly bind it above the constriction with a strong bandage: and remove the bandage when the wound has healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And the memory of them, and their incision, and their extraction is at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	De the venesection of the forehead after the venesection of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The instrument for venesection of the forehead is after the venesection of the head, to cure old diseases of the face; and to cure headaches, and red faces; and bad ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of venesection is according to whether I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	A constricted neck with a purple color, until the blood appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the surgical instrument which is called a chisel.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose this shape is.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Then place the sharp end which is in the chisel on top of the blood, and pierce it with a pin or some other thing in this way: and let the blood run according to how much you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the piercing with the help of an instrument, and tightly bind it, until it has healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens with a venesection on the side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that the phlebotomist be of acute temperament, as are other phlebotomists, but rather of a moderate temperament.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And venesect the blood according to its transmutation: for the mouth is near: and perhaps in this the phlebotomist may break when it is thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	De venesection of the veins in the two lacrimal ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	However the instrument for the two veins which are in the two lacrimal ducts of the two eyes, is to cure an eye from a scabies and a headache; and bad vision in an eye, and diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of venesection of them is, to bind the constricted neck with blood.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then let him draw blood; and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And so let the phlebotomy be made according to the length of a little bit, with a small one, at a bit of an angle, for there is no blood in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If then the phlebotomist is fine at the end, perhaps it is broken.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let him make the blood run out as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put a cloth over them and tie them up for one night and then release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Now of the phlebotomy of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	But the veins of the nose are used for a acute fever and a rushing pulse, and diseases of the face, such as a headache, and a ruddy color that comes to the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that he should squeeze the sick neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take his nose with your left hand and take a small phlebotomy that is long, and fasten it in the middle of his nose, between what distinguishes the nose according to its length.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not show itself to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And let your hand with the phlebotomist be a little behind: and let him make the blood run out according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it up for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For this is quickly healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Now of the phlebotomy of the Guiy's veins.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Of the two phlebotomies of Guiy there is a constriction for the constriction of a dry fever and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholy diseases, andImpetigo and bad sores, andcorrosive, that is, scabs of scabies.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that he should squeeze the sick under each on his neck with a ligament: and let the artisan stand over the head, and let the sick person sit on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then phlebotomy a young one for the length phlebotomy broadish sort of.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood quantity of temperature, or according to that which you see from necessity that is to that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with another young one.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligaments, and tighten two veins tightly in the middle: so that the sick person does not become weakened.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it remain until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound will heal.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	As for the phlebotomy of Albigeric.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	But the phlebotomy of Albigeric is a thing to be avoided: because it conveys to the alcohol in the mouth, and corruption of the tongue: and sores on the lips, and ulcers also, and even those which are in the nose, and round about it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you should make the sick person sit before you: and tighten his neck with a rope.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then open the lips and look at two veins, the one on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left: and the demonstration of both is by the blackness of amber.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: for there are small veins round about them, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Then cut each of the two veins as they are cut.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if doubt is upon you, and you do not know which of them is which: then approach to the incision of the greater one of them, and make known its two veins.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do likewise with the two veins which are in the upper lip: and very much so does habit run with it: and cut two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	As for the phlebotomy of Veins under the tongue, after the phlebotomy of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The two veins which are under the tongue have a rule: that is, the phlebotomy of the head is for those pre-occupations which are in the throat, and the sickness of the throat, and the sicknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that the sick person sits between your hands before the sun: and anoint his tongue, and look at it under his tongue on one side, and under his tongue on the other: and the color of both goes away to darkness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomize him on both sides: and guard, that you do not put your hand into his blood.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under him are the arteries, and perhaps it happens that the flow of blood comes out from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins on the bed.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	And the three veins that are phlebotomized in the bed, are in which the custom of phlebotomy runs in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy is done on them according to two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or with the prick and the phlebotomist's needle on the side: or oiling at the point of decline: or drying with the phlebotomist's knife, and it is Anaesthetizer.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Anæsthesizer is, that he may be useful for the cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And of them are species broad, and subtle according to the length of the veins and their narrowness: and the form of phlebotomy'a needle is broad, as you see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is useful to open closed veins, full, coming from the body, apparent, thick, and those which contain blood thick, turbulent.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomist is of less latitude, and more subtle at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is useful to phlebotomize veins that contain blood thinner, citrin-colored
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	But that which is one of the three veins to be phlebotomized, it is a helpment.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because he draws blood from the diseases that are under the throat and the neck, from which comes to the chest and the belly: and it is useful for the phlebotomist to pass over them with care, since an artery lies under them.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If he makes an error and adds to the puncture with phlebotomy, he will cut the artery and cause a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, when puncturing with phlebotomy, it is necessary to cut through the vein: with Alne's knife, cut only a little.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the church does not appear with a visible apparition, then you must remove it and change it to another one, or ask someone else's opinion: or if he cannot find anyone, he will make a knot in his thread of the brachial artery.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is evident, and cut it with Alne's knife as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you want to make a phlebotomy in his own hand, then you must touch the spot on the brachial artery before it is tightly tied up, so that you know where to cut.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with caustic powder, and afterwards the arm, and cut the thread in a closed section with Alne' knife as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And so that the knot does not fall through the space from the spot of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see it, as you tighten the knot, the swelling in the spot that you have marked with caustic powder, then this swelling is an swelling of the artery: so remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rise during phlebotomy, like a boy's urine, and it is thin blood, red in color: then you will know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore place your hand on the spot and let it rest there for a long time, and then remove your hand.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is separated (for it is often separated) then tighten the arm and let go of it: and let him be careful to move his hand: and place it on his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let him not be in pain for several days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not separate and it hurts you: and there is no present remedy for you in your moment of need, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	The extremities of it are cut off, and blood is shed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the fistula at its extremities, and cut it off; or take half of it, and tightly bind it to the place where the stricture is, with a ligament and powder until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is shed, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then the care of him with that which preceded his memory from the place of the flux of blood, from which he is cut off: and the cutting off of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, on account of the small wound, and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	A phlebotomy of the veins of the foot.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the phlebotomy of the veins of the foot is a remedy, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: for this reason, it is composed of a branch of the Basilica, and a branch of the Cephalica, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it belongs to the phlebotomist that he should be on his guard against phlebotomy of him, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	But if he adds anything to the piercing of the phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, there occurs in it an stupor, and a difficult cure is made, and perhaps a thorough cure does not take place.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is concealed in some men, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then you should put your phlebotomy so that the phlebotomist may make a section with the Alnesil, and remove the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	That if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the cerebral vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the phlebotomy of the cerebral vein is a remedy, for it draws blood from the head, and is applied to the diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein to use an oil-phlebotomy, or a myrrh-phlebotomy, for it is salutary for all veins, because it is not under an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Yet it is fitting that you should go to the phlebotomist's house, so that you may have the head lacerated only, and inquire about a milder place; and it does no harm to him, unless it is discovered upon his body with a first punch, so that he may return to it from time to time with phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Yet perhaps you should avert your eyes from certain people when they are not phlebotomized in the first punch, but it does no harm to him if that aversion is in some measure.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the Benefit of Phlebotomy and Care to be Taken with It.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The Quality or Advantage of Phlebotomy, and the Consequences of It; by which You Should Take Thought for Correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Then first of all you should know that phlebotomy is not performed except for the preservation of health, and its perseverance, and the care to avoid any illness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so that phlebotomy may be performed on one of the three which are in a bed, namely the Cephalica, and the Fusca, and the Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that phlebotomy may be performed at the beginning of spring on a fast, and during the summer, and autumn after a meal, when there are signs of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And so that phlebotomy may be performed on the first or third day after having passed three hours since the last day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But phlebotomy which is performed in illness has not determined time; but when it occasioned convenience and necessity to it, at night, or by day, and at all times, and in all places.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary that boys should be phlebotomized until they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a woman who is pregnant be phlebotomized until the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should elderly people who have passed sixty years be phlebotomized.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When then whoever desires to be phlebotomized for any reason should wash his bowels well before phlebotomy with a laxative, if there is much feces in them: so that the fresh blood does not attract the eyes of the phlebotomist from the intestines when it flows, which injures the chief parts.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Do not let the patient suffer from fainting, that is, nausea; nor do they have a cramp, nor does their sweat come from drunkenness until they get rid of it themselves.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor is the patient ill with hydrops.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let the phlebotomy be repeated after a colic passion, and vomiting, and flow of blood, and increase of sexual intercourse, and work, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and any that dissolves virtue out of the bodily or animal realm.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider with subtlety the humors before that, if the blood is thick with food and drink and medicines: if it can be made possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him bathe in cold water, if he does not forbid anything: or let him exercise himself in some kind of exercise, that the blood may be refined.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And let his phlebotomy be placed in his chest, about the third day as we have said: and be careful so that his chest is emptied of all animal bad accidents on that day: such as anger, fear: and all body accidents, such as work, punishment, excesses, and the like.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make his own presence of such things with which custom of men runs according to the use: from aromatizing, and fragrance, and revelry, and similar things through quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit on a raised chair, that it may be higher than the one where phlebotomy is done: then he shall take his arm out and rub it with his own hand twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him tighten the ligature with a strap, and turn it two times.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be of moderate tension, for a constriction that is uneven, or by excess in the constriction, then it forbids the course of blood: or in softening, then also it forbids the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, let the phlebotomist rub his hands together, face to face, until they are warmed, and present a sensation to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist dried off the bleeding with a little oil, according to custom.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he put his index finger of his left hand on the vein where he wanted to take the bloodletting, a little: so that the blood doesn't run away, and so that the pulsation isn't interrupted.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Since it is from the veins that bleeding takes place like a running string during bloodletting, and from those that are full of blood: and when you put the phlebotome on it, it is pressed under the phlebotome, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and it does not open the vein: and if it does open it, it is tight. Therefore it is necessary for the phlebotomist to tighten it, and be diligent in these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then put down the phlebotome.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then one vein opens out of many, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then go back to the other vein a little below that one, or above it with a rush: if not, choose a place.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	Which if it is put out of joint, or causes pain to the patient, then let go of it for a day, or two days: and do not tighten the ligament.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For maybe it draws the blood because of the heat.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And don't put it in the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then go back to the bloodletting, if he loves it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	Which if the opening is small, or the blood runs gently: and be careful not to lose a quantity of blood which you wish to take from him: then go back with the phlebotome into that same hole, and add a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it quickly, before that place is put out of joint, since this place goes out of joint in many people during the procedure.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If then you see that he has already been bloodletting, then don' go back to that place at all, for nothing excuses you with him for anything.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something of animal fat on the top of it: since it soothes the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than itself oil, and how other olive oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly apply oil of olive to all your phlebotomies, when the course of blood is prohibited: and make that tyriaca alfarach, and the red sage, when it is put from one of them on the spot.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is thinned and resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If it has happened in the spot of phlebotomy a big apostema, for many times it happens, especially to him who is not phlebotomized but only that time, or is a small opening of the vein, then put right and place over the spot a sponge steeped in water and salt, heated slightly: and tie it one hour: because it is resolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it should be that you do that after the exit of blood from his own vein, with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	That if it remains in the place after a certain time of blackening or of the color green, it does not harm that: and if there is a vein, put over itself some oil, or of myrrh dissolved: or some juice of mint, that is, of calamus or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times happen apostemata and eminenties at the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So put your hand over it, then if it is soft and damp when you compress it over itself, then that eminence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Take care so that you put over it some of what I have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But put a plaster on him with what is there that stipticitas, so that the place endureth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of himself with the other cure, until he is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it should be that you keep from every man all his blood after the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what seems from the color shining over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let him not go out, until it shines red: and likewise if you see him thick: then let him not go out, until he thins out: and likewise if it is sharp, then let its sharpness be taken away.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	He who is full, strong, and inclined to the extraction of blood at once, so that the phlebotomy of the veins may be increased, and the phlebotomist be wide, should sit on his left side; but he who is feeble should sit on his right side.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he should extract himself in the viscera, and that the opening be tight; and it is better if that which is administered in the phlebotomy of the veins is transverted section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this mode of phlebotomy is salutary against the flow of blood, and from incising a nerve; and it is more praiseworthy and healthier than phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who is accustomed to falling ill after phlebotomy, let him eat a little bread soaked in grape juice water; or secernatabine, if it be warm; and let him extract the blood in three viscera, or in four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if his complexion is cold, then let him take before phlebotomy bread soaked in honey syrup, or in honey syrup seasoned with spices, or in syrup seasoned with odorous substances.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	That if it happens that syncopes occur after phlebotomy, and is a cause of the exit of blood much: then let him drink in a cup water of meat, and syrup of odoriferous things: and he should use fragrance with algalia, and rub his breast while so: and let him use the rest which we have said in the division about syncopes from discharge.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But he who wishes to let his arm go and let his blood flow again: it is necessary that him to whom the phlebotomy is for a great euacuation, and whose power is feeble, should let his blood flow little by little through a quantity of power in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But he who wishes to let his arm go and let his blood flow again, and whose body is strong: then let him do it after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his own body towards the opposite part to that which he inclines should do so on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	But in case the body of this person has much blood that has been warmed and has become sharp and causes fever: it is necessary that he should go out of his body in one direction and draw out a great deal of blood, and increase the opening until fever occurs: after you have kept all the conditions of phlebotomy: and so that you place your hand on his pulse at the course of blood, so that death does not occur at the site of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For many times this has happened when the phlebotomist does not know and falls by neglect.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not appropriate when you wish to draw the arm and draw blood on the second day, while the opening of the vein has already closed, and the exit of the blood becomes difficult so that it presses on him with a sudden movement, and it bends quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For this is bad to draw suddenly, far from letting go until the second day of phlebotomy.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or if you wish to move it with sharp phlebotomy that has coagulated blood in the opening of the vein, and place a little dissolved salt on him in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place a little of the tarry fluid or sage green on him, and place the person under compression, until blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein has already been stretched, then let go of it, and do not press on it until it relaxes.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	That if necessity forces to draw blood on the second day, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize him above that place or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But if you draw the arm of a person at the place of Fusca and Basilica, when they are not found and hidden, since it is composed of them:
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that he should put his weak hand in warm water until it turns red, and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tie it above with a slight constriction of the ligature in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then make a second incision below, gradually and not straight across, nor along its length; and let the opening be wide and your phlebotomy shall come therewith a little over the tourniquet.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If it is forbidden that the blood should flow out, then again put your hand in warm water and let the blood run into the water until you have eased your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if it were summer days, then you should be excused from putting your hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed the course of blood in warm water is put forward many times in wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And this kind of phlebotomy is healthier for all the limbs, since there is no pulsating blood under it, nor nerves.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	But phlebotomy of the right hand does indeed confer health on patients with liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is such that you should tie the hand with a tourniquet and, after you have put it in warm water, until the blood hardens, and it is clearly felt to be very hot.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then make the incision across it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not hurt him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And keep your hand away from the phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the nerves of the fingers bare from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then again put your hand in warm water and let the blood run into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not put it in warm water, the blood will clotted up in the incision, and it is forbidden to flow along its course.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	But when you have extracted the quantity of blood necessary, then put on the incision oil and salt: so that it does not quickly harden.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise you should do, as you do with every tight ligature.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	But the binding of the phlebotomy from the left hand is: for it is conferring on patients with sicknesses of the spleen: and likewise do you in this phlebotomy as you did in the second one in equal measure.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The treatment of the saphenous vein, on the other hand, is for ailments in the lower part of the body such as those of the mother, retention of the menstrual fluids, kidney infirmities, old ulcers of the hips and thighs, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that one should dip his sick foot into hot water; and he should make friction there until the blood comes up; and he should tie a bandage above the ankle with a strap.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the place of the vein is near the heel, visible towards the thumb; and many branches sprout from it and extend on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	So phlebotomy should be done in one of its main branches, or at the heel where it originates; for it is better and more beneficial.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	That if you phlebotomy on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that lie under it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy where you want to phlebotomy across from it, as if you didn't want to hit it directly: and let the phlebotomist be seated.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If however the exit of blood is prevented, then turn his foot again into hot water: and let the blood not run in it until it has drained.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	That if the phlebotomist's vein is missed in the first attempt, then continue with phlebotomy to some degree higher, for the place is sounder; and do not wait on it with evil intent, when you are drawing from the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And also with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is near the heel from the sides of the pine tree.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the treatment of this phlebotomy is for the pain in the ankle, when there is hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is such that one should dip his sick foot into warm water and walk; and tighten his shin with a string from the ankle up to the heel, four fingers wide, not revealing it for anything else: for it does not appear except for that reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then cut off the vein in accordance with whatever ability you have, or according to transgression; and it is better, or as if you were to strike it with an incision, or sever it by sectioning.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the site of this is healthier, and itself is a great secret in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If it is not enlarged and does not appear at all to the sense: then cut off some of its branch, and that which appears on the back of the foot and toward the ear; and cause it to run with a certain quantity of blood that you want.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the bandage tightly, and place flesh over the site of phlebotomy, and tighten the spot.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is quickly healed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Regarding Ventilation, and quality of use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter LXXVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	The vents are made from horns, and from air, and from heat.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Ventilation is made in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When with scarring and extraction of blood: and the other is ventilation without scarring.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this Ventilation which is without scarring, is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or indeed is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventilations that are administered with scarring and extraction of blood are four-십여 places in the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is Ventilation of the Crown, and it is lastly of the head: and Alkhel, and is in the middle of the neck: and ventilations of Al-Hadhdahim, and they are two layers of the neck on both sides simultaneously: and ventilations of the mind, and is under the mandible in the lower mouth: and ventilations of two spatulas: and ventilations of Al-La'il at the end of the tail: and ventilations of two fires, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and ventilations of two chaps: and ventilations of two calves.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed does not extract blood from you from small sparse veins in the flesh, and because of it does not fall virtue from them, such as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not appropriate that the application of tar be done with fire or without fire in any illness that occurs from fullness until the whole body is emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity compels to the application of tar in illness or by custom, we shall administer it at the beginning, end, and middle of the month, and at any time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is because a person becomes bald when blood multiplies within him until it needs to be extracted by tar application, and finds himself bald, and does not remain except with shaving.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them is he who finds fullness and redness on his face, his head, and his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them is he who finds itching on his face, his forehead, darkness, and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them is he who scratches the place where he applied tar.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is he whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And among them is he who finds the taste of blood in his mouth, or who spits it out with his tongue, and does not remain except by drinking blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is he whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among them is he who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and those who have been slain, and plagues, and similar things.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of them, and especially if it is in the middle of the third month: We order tar application to be done after two or three hours have passed from the day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	But the application of tar on the back is this: because it brings baldness to the head, and it drips down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is appropriate that it be done after the whole body has been emptied.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this tar is a place of phlebotomy on the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not appropriate that he who has a cold complexions should use it, or in whom there is a croupy cough.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Since they are not old enough to use these, nor do they have any diseases of cold in their heads.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But those who become too accustomed to it, lose their memory.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason, you should tell Ventosator to put his hand down a little when he is blowing on it, out of fear of losing his memory.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Al-Khel is the place of the phlebotomy of Fusca, and the phlebotomy of Basilica, and for this reason it confers asa-mus, and constriction of anhelius, and fissures of the instrument of anhelius, and coughs, and fulfillment.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be that Ventosator is blown a little by Al-Khel, because if it is put down, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosation on the other hand, confers pain on accidental injuries in the head, and on the eyes, and on headaches, and on piercing, and on pain in the roots of the teeth; and it is the place of the phlebotomy of Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should tell Ventosator not to touch the skin with his scarification instrument so that he does not hit an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	But Ventosation under the chin, confers alcohol in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar diseases that are in the mouth: and it is the place of a different kind of phlebotomy, which is in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	But Ventosation with the spatula, confers to Al-Khajah, which is done by a replexion and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventosation of the inner parts confers a favor to phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalica: because she herself attracts blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh: and these small veins attract those other larger veins until they reach the attraction of the three.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary that you do not let the scalpel go too far into the scarification: for the place is stripped of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But the ventosa which is applied to the anus, it brings hemorrhoids and ulcers of the lower parts.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you should order the scalpel to be big, and that it is made of iron: because the place needs strong suction, and perhaps the fine scalpel are broken: and let the scarification be done with a big scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	But the ventosa of the legs diminishes the visible reduction: because they attract blood from all over the body, and bring old pains in the veins, and membranes, and vesicles: they induce menstruation, and bring fever, and constriction: and stand in the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	But they weaken the body very much, and make many people faint.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the alhorcobeni of the ventosa is a near relationship to the iuuamento of the two legs of the ventosa.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the ventosa is that you put the ventosa in the first place, and suck with moderate suction: and do not prolong the position of the ventosa, but put them quickly, and move them quickly, so that they go to the place of exudation equally: and do not stop repeating this and continuing, until you see the place already red and swollen, and the blood appears: then therefore scarify, and repeat the suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who is of tender flesh, and few pores, it should be scarified once only, not more: lest the place be ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And order the scalpel to make the scarification bigger, and deeper a little: and moderate the suction in ease, and speed, and smooth motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	That if there is grossness in the blood, then it should be that you scarify him twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Indeed, the first incision opens the way for the subtlety of blood, and its watering; and, indeed, the second is for the exquisite examination of the extraction of gross blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is indeed putrid, then let the third incision be made: so that the result may be the last.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And to the end, when we wish to extract blood little by little, or a little at a time, one incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	That if we wish to extract blood many times, then let us make multiple incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure, that the blood is thick: then it is necessary so that a deep incision should be made: and the equal term in the incision, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which needs to be administered from oils at the placement of vents, and what does it cause?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	IN that which has the skin thick, hard, dark and whose pores are tight, one should anoint the places of the Vents with open, soothing, حل  oils: if it is in the time of summer, such as is a strong oil, or a mild oil, or an almond oil, or a seed oil of cucumber.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then olive oil, or violet oil, or chamomile oil, or sage oil: and these are similar.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If the superfluity is thick, cold: then let there be bitter oil, or olive oil, or alburnum oil, or annerbitz oil: and these are similar.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If the wind is of large pores, tender flesh: then one should prohibit from oil, and it should be washed after ventilation with rosy water, or cold water, or sun water, or cucumber water, or portulaca water: and these are similar.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But that which has blood of much moisture, washes the vents with vinegar, or with myrtle water, and sumach: and these are similar.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whoseever are the fluid excesses, wash them away with old wine, or with water of samshuk, or with a decoction of aniseed, or of chamomile; and for these alike.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that the cooling should be done in a bath or in a foot-bath; and it is necessary also that an administrate after leaving the bath for one hour, or two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary that anyone should sleep after cooling.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is it, then, for which the treatment of cooling and phlebotomy is administered before cooling?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after this, it is necessary that you consider first of all: if the person is bilious and his blood is sharp and inflamed, then he should take cooling things, such as granatum muzum; also vinegar and lettuce, with secani-bin and juleb; and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And put before him the foods that dry up his flesh, and meat of a kind to make him thirsty, and prepared foods with grapes: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if his disposition is cold, he should take in a drink of syrup of honey, or of mulberry, or of secani-bin made from seeds; and he should take medium wine that is sharp, which is between sweet and sour; and let it be commanded that he eat sparingly.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put before him the foods that dry up his flesh, and tarragon; and pigeons, that is, many birds: and let him eat pigeon-meat often baked.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink of the day after cooling and phlebotomy be stronger than food; and it is necessary that a medicine be given in a drink to some men containing tyrrhene or alfaroch, or a remedy made from musk, that is musca-ta, or alselith before cooling: and before phlebotomy, or after it, so as to comfort the main limbs, and subtilize the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	They should not take it out of a hot pot.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On Ventosis without scarring.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	But the venesections that are without scarring, are venesections that are put on the skin, and the liver, and the spleen, and on the belly, and places of the ribs, and the anus: for these limbs do not endure the scarification on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought after them, except that the blood flow from one member to another: as we put the venesection on the breasts in a flu of blood from the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them, that we solve a cold venesection on one member to another: as we put the venesection on the belly, and the umbilical cord.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it itself tightens the member, and warms it, and moves away the pain, because it has solved the venesection.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	Also is put on the kidneys, when it happens to them a deposit, or a stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For with his virtue of attraction he might perhaps open a deposit, or eradicate a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And also does when it is put on the liver, and the spleen next to a venesection that should heal in them both: for he moves away the pain from them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these Venesections are administered with a sharp knife with only a slight cut.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And when they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in the case of a pleural illness: and that is so, so that the venesection is large, and there is only warm water, or water in which herbs have been cooked.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	Form of administration of the Venesections with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of his opening be two fingers wide, according to which we made it: and let the quantity of it in the depth be half a palm: and let it be in the back of its side which is near the middle of it, small hole, second to the quantity that it is cooked inside itself: so it is made from brass, or yellow copper, large margin, soft, equal, third: so that it does not hurt the member at its position on itself: and let it be in the middle of it a wire crossing from brass, or iron, where a candle is put with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And this has also been very useful, greater than we have described, and less by a little, according to the disease and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For young people, the winds are useful, and others, which weaken, greater than the winds that men use, and for those who have large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of this wind-making when set on fire on a limb is such, that you kindle the linden wood with fire from off-center linen, or place a small candle made of wax: and put it on the middle of the arm across-way that lies in the middle of the wind-making. so that the fire all around may be lower than the wind-making, so that the body is not burned up.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then let it be placed on the limb: and let the finger be placed over the opening that I said, as long as we hold the wind-making: while we are holding it, let us take off the finger, and steam will come out over that opening, and the wind-making will immediately cease.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then set fire to the linden wood in the manner described, and do this again if you can bear it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	But the wind-making that is administered in pleural pain with water has no across-way limb or opening; and it is not administered, unless it fills with water, and is placed on the limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this wind-making is the better when it is larger, so that it takes in a lot of water, for that is good.
